{"location": "Pacific", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sri Lanka", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4459546", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus (44): Singapore, alert, travel advice", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4459546", "date": "2016-09-02 05:18:59", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS (44): SINGAPORE, ALERT, TRAVEL ADVICE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 30 Aug 2016 6:37 pm EDT\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-singapore-idUSKCN1150HM\n\n\nConfirmed cases of Zika virus in Singapore rose to 82 on [Tue 30 Aug 2016], as the United States joined a growing list of countries warning pregnant women or those trying to get pregnant to avoid travel to the city-state.\n\nThe mosquitoborne Zika virus, which has caused explosive outbreaks in the Americas and the Caribbean since late last year [2015], poses a particular risk to pregnant women because it can cause microcephaly, a severe birth defect in which babies are born with abnormally small heads and underdeveloped brains.\n\nOn [Tue 30 Aug 2016], the United States warned pregnant women not to travel to Singapore, joining Australia, Taiwan, and South Korea.\n\nThe warnings followed news that Zika transmission appears to be occurring outside of the original cluster, with at least 5 of 26 new cases confirmed late on [Tue 30 Aug 2016] detected in the Aljunied area in the southeast of Singapore, the health ministry and National Environment Agency (NEA) said in a joint statement.\n\nSingapore has advised pregnant women to take a free Zika test if they showed any symptoms or if their partners tested positive. \"This is regardless of whether they have been to Zika-affected areas,\" health officials said in a statement.\n\nThe outbreak and advisories come as the tourism industry in one of the world's busiest travel hubs already faces weak global economic growth. Singapore's Tourism Board said it was premature to consider any impact on the sector, adding it remained a \"safe travel destination\".\n\nMore than 55 million people pass through Singapore's Changi airport every year. In the 1st half of this year [2016], tourism arrivals topped 8 million, around 1 million more than a year earlier [2015].\n\nSingapore reported its 1st case of locally-transmitted Zika at the weekend [27-28 Aug 2016], and the number of confirmed infections has risen steadily since then. At least 3 dozen patients have made a full recovery.\n\nNeighboring Malaysia and Indonesia have stepped up protective measures, introducing thermal scanners at airports and border checkpoints with the island state. Such measures, however, will only identify symptomatic cases of Zika, but only one in 5 people have symptoms of the virus, which include fever, rash, joint pain, and pink eye.\n\nSingapore residents responded to government calls to be vigilant and to take precautions against mosquito bites. Online retailer Lazada Singapore said sales of insect repellents jumped 5-fold in the past 3 days. FairPrice supermarkets and Watsons pharmacies said their sales of such products had doubled.\n\nMost of the early infections were among foreign workers, hundreds of thousands of whom, mainly from the Asian sub-continent, work on Singapore's construction sites and in the marine sector. The Singapore government has not said where the infected foreign workers are from. The foreign ministry directed queries to the health ministry, which did not respond to Reuters questions on the issue. The Ministry of Manpower also did not respond to a request for comment made outside working hours.\n\nThe High Commission of Bangladesh, which represents the largest community of foreign workers, said none of those infected were Bangladeshis, and the Thai foreign ministry said none were from Thailand. The embassies of China, India, Sri Lanka, and Myanmar said they had not been notified by Singapore whether their citizens were among those infected.\n\nAuthorities inspected thousands of homes in 7 parts of Singapore, including 5 foreign worker dormitories, spraying insecticide, and removing potential mosquito breeding habitats. The NEA has inspected about 5000 premises in and around the initial outbreak area, issuing 400 notices to owners of buildings they could not access. The NEA can force entry into those premises if needed.\n\nZika was 1st discovered in Uganda in 1947. It caused clusters of human infections from the 1960s to 1980s across Africa and Asia, according to the World Health Organization. The outbreak in the Americas was caused by a Zika strain from Asia, possibly carried to Brazil through travel to a sporting event. Many experts believe once infected, Zika produces lifelong immunity. \"Unfortunately, it is not clear the level of immunity that is currently in Asia,\" said Alessandro Vespignani of Northeastern University in Boston. WHO declared Zika a global health emergency because of its link with microcephaly. In Brazil, Zika has been linked to more than 1800 cases of microcephaly.\n\n[byline: Marius Zaharia]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Zika virus infection has similar clinical signs to dengue, and may be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common. There is no cure for Zika virus disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. Prevention and control relies on reducing the breeding of aedes mosquitoes and minimizing contact between mosquito vectors and people by using barriers (such as repellents, insect screens), reducing water-filled habitats supporting mosquito larvae in and close to dwellings, and reducing the adult mosquito populations around at-risk communities.\n\nBoth _Ae. aegypti_ and _Ae. albopictus_ have been implicated in large outbreaks of Zika virus. _Ae. aegypti_ is confined to tropical and sub-tropical regions, while _Ae. albopictus_ can be found in tropical, sub-tropical and temperate regions. _Ae. albopictus_ has spread from Asia and become established in areas of the South Pacific, Africa, Europe, and the Americas in recent decades. In the South Pacific, _Ae. hensilli_ was implicated in the spread of Zika virus on Yap Island in 2007, while _Ae. polynesiensis_ was suspected to spread Zika virus in French Polynesia in 2013. Neither of these endemic species had been recognized as a Zika virus vector before, indicating that as this emerging disease spreads to previously unaffected countries, the potential exists for other endemic _Aedes_ species to play a role in transmission (http://www.wpro.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs_05182015_zika/en/).\n\nMaps of Singapore can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/singapore_pol_05.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/150. - Mod.ST]\n\n[Autochthonous transmission of Zika in Singapore is not surprising given ongoing dengue transmission there. One wonders whether this new transmission is due to (re)-introduction of the virus from South America or represents ongoing transmission discovered because of heightened awareness and surveillance. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\nZika virus (43): Americas, Europe: Tampa Florida area, research 20160823.4436991\nZika virus (42): Americas, Europe 20160821.4430310\nZika virus (41): Americas, Asia, Europe Americas 20160722.4361791\nZika virus (36) - Americas: USA (FL, UT) RFI 20160720.4356276\nZika virus (34): Americas, Asia, Africa, Europe 20160707.4331999\nZika virus (33): Americas, Asia, Europe 20160701.4321150\nZika virus (32): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Europe 20160622.4303191\nZika virus (31): worldwide, WHO 20160617.4290853\nZika virus (30): Americas, Asia, Atlantic, Europe 20160616.4292221\nZika virus (29): Americas, Asia, Europe 20160529.4253278\nZika virus (28): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Atlantic, Europe 20160524.4240474\nZika virus (27): Americas, Asia, Europe 20160511.4214303\nZika virus (26): Americas, Asia, Europe, Indian Ocean 20160504.4202525\nZika virus (25): Americas 20160501.4195452\nZika virus (24): Americas 20160422.4177323\n.................................................st/mj/mpp/lm/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "1947-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Myanmar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": {"location": "Pacific", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sri Lanka", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4436991", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus (43): Americas, Europe: Tampa Florida area, research", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4436991", "date": "2016-07-20 12:24:14", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS (36): AMERICAS (USA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Florida: local transmission\n[2] Utah: local transmission\n\n******\n[1] Florida: local transmission\nDate: Tue 19 Jul 2016, 6:54 PM\nSource: Miami Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.miamiherald.com/news/health-care/article90617692.html\n\n\nFlorida health officials are investigating a Zika infection in Miami-Dade County that may be the 1st acquired within the state, according to an announcement late Tue [19 Jul 2016]. Health officials reported they are conducting an epidemiological investigation in collaboration with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nNo details were provided regarding the potential mode of transmission. Zika is primarily transmitted by the bite of infected _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_ mosquitoes, though the CDC has also reported cases of the virus spreading through blood transfusions, from pregnant mothers to their newborn children, and by sexual transmission.\n\nFlorida health officials reported 7 new cases of Zika infection on Tue [19 Jul 2016], all acquired by people while traveling outside the country. The cases included 3 in Broward County, 3 in Orange County and 1 in Miami-Dade. Miami-Dade has the state's largest number of Zika [virus] infections, with 88 people having contracted the virus this year.\n\nZika can be difficult to diagnose in part because only 1 in 5 infected people show symptoms, which include fever, joint pain, rash and red eyes lasting 7-10 days.\n\nWhile the CDC has not confirmed local transmission of Zika anywhere in the continental United States, evidence emerged this week that the virus is spreading in ways that are still a mystery to scientists. On Mon [18 Jul 2016], the CDC announced that epidemiologists are investigating a case in Utah involving a family member of an elderly man who contracted Zika while traveling outside the country and later died from complications of the disease after returning home. CDC officials reported that epidemiologists are interviewing and conducting blood tests of the dead man's family members and healthcare workers who may have had contact with the man, who died in Jun [2016].\n\nHealth officials are also trapping mosquitoes in Utah and testing them for the virus to assess the potential for local transmission. However, the 2 species known to transmit Zika are not known to be present in Utah.\n\nFlorida health officials said Zika prevention kits and repellent will be available for pick up in Miami-Dade and distributed in the area under investigation, which was not disclosed. Zika kits are intended for pregnant women, the health department said. County mosquito control has already conducted spraying and other prevention efforts in the neighborhood being investigated.\n\nPregnant women and their children are considered to be at greatest risk from the disease. Researchers have concluded that prenatal Zika infection can cause microcephaly and other brain disorders. According to the health department, there are 43 pregnant women in Florida who have contracted the virus this year.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Chang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Presumably, a viremic individual returned to Florida and provided an infectious blood meal for a vector mosquito that subsequently infected a local person. This is not surprising. In the past, there have been locally transmitted dengue viruses in Florida. The same vector mosquito transmits both viruses. Additional locally acquired cases where _Aedes aegypti_ is present in the southern USA can be expected during this transmission season.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Florida can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6998 and map of Florida sowing the location of Miami-Dade county at the southern tip of the state can be accessed at http://geology.com/county-map/florida.shtml. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] Utah: local transmission\nDate: Mon 18 Jul 2016\nSource: CDC Media Statement [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/s0718-zika-utah-investigation.html\n\n\nCDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] is assisting in the investigation of a case of Zika in a Utah resident who is a family contact of the elderly Utah resident who died in late Jun [2016]. The deceased patient had traveled to an area with Zika and lab tests showed he had uniquely high amounts of virus -- more than 100 000 times higher than seen in other samples of infected people -- in his blood. Laboratories in Utah and at the CDC reported evidence of Zika infection in both Utah residents.\n\nState and local public health disease control specialists, along with CDC, are investigating how the 2nd resident became infected. The investigation includes additional interviews with and laboratory testing of family members and health care workers who may have had contact with the person who died and trapping mosquitoes and assessing the risk of local spread by mosquitoes.\n\nA CDC Emergency Response Team (CERT) is in Utah at the request of the Utah Department of Health. The team includes experts in infection control, virology, mosquito control, disease investigation, and health communications. \"The new case in Utah is a surprise, showing that we still have more to learn about Zika,\" said Erin Staples, MD, PhD, CDC's Medical Epidemiologist on the ground in Utah. \"Fortunately, the patient recovered quickly, and from what we have seen with more than 1300 travel-associated cases of Zika in the continental United States and Hawaii, non-sexual spread from one person to another does not appear to be common.\"\n\nAs of 13 Jul 2016, 1306 cases of Zika have been reported in the continental United States and Hawaii; none of these have been the result of local spread by mosquitoes. These cases include 14 believed to be the result of sexual transmission and 1 that was the result of a laboratory exposure.\n\nSince early 2016, CDC has worked with state, local, and territorial public health officials to protect pregnant women from Zika infection, through these activities:\n\n- Alerts to pregnant women to avoid travel to an area with active Zika transmission, to women in these areas to take steps to prevent mosquito bites, and to partners of pregnant women to use a condom to prevent sexual transmission during pregnancy.\n- Development and distribution of PCR and IgM testing kits to confirm Zika virus infection.\n- Establishment of CDC Emergency Response Teams to rapidly deploy to assist with Zika-related preparedness and response activities in the United States.\n- Deployment of experts to assist in enhancement of mosquito surveillance and testing.\n- Collaboration with FDA, blood collection centers, and other entities in the public and private sectors on enhancement of surveillance of blood donations.\n- Guidance to prevent sexual transmission, particularly to women who are pregnant.\n- Guidance for clinicians on the care of pregnant women who may have been exposed to Zika [virus].\n- Studies in collaboration with Brazil, Colombia, and other countries to better understand the link between Zika infection and birth defects, including microcephaly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The obvious question is -- how did the caretaker become infected. Mosquitoes are unlikely as the source of the virus in this situation because no competent mosquito species is believed to be present in Utah. The source of the virus must have been the elderly man who subsequently died. He is reported to have had a very high viremia. Presumably there were substantial amounts of virus in urine and saliva as well. The importance of virus in saliva or urine as a source of transmissible virus has not been established. Clearly, this is an unusual case. With over 1300 Zika virus infected individuals reported in the USA, the only locally acquired cases were sexually transmitted, until now. ProMED would be interested in the results of the investigations by CDC and state specialists. - Mod. TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the USA showing the location of Utah can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.TY]\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/246.]\nSee Also\nZika virus (35): Americas, Asia, Europe 20160714.4346031\nZika virus (34): Americas, Asia, Africa, Europe 20160707.4331999\nZika virus (33): Americas, Asia, Europe 20160701.4321150\nZika virus (32): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Europe 20160622.4303191\nZika virus (31): worldwide, WHO 20160617.4290853\nZika virus (30): Americas, Asia, Atlantic, Europe Americas 20160419.4168370\nZika virus (22): sexual transmission 20160416.4162854\nZika virus (21): Americas (Brazil) diagnostic imaging 20160415.4160993\nZika virus (20): Americas, Pacific, Asia, 20160108.3921447\n.................................................ml/ty/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Broward County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami - Dade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami Herald", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4430310", "date": "2016-07-20 12:24:14", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS (36): AMERICAS (USA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Florida: local transmission\n[2] Utah: local transmission\n\n******\n[1] Florida: local transmission\nDate: Tue 19 Jul 2016, 6:54 PM\nSource: Miami Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.miamiherald.com/news/health-care/article90617692.html\n\n\nFlorida health officials are investigating a Zika infection in Miami-Dade County that may be the 1st acquired within the state, according to an announcement late Tue [19 Jul 2016]. Health officials reported they are conducting an epidemiological investigation in collaboration with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nNo details were provided regarding the potential mode of transmission. Zika is primarily transmitted by the bite of infected _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_ mosquitoes, though the CDC has also reported cases of the virus spreading through blood transfusions, from pregnant mothers to their newborn children, and by sexual transmission.\n\nFlorida health officials reported 7 new cases of Zika infection on Tue [19 Jul 2016], all acquired by people while traveling outside the country. The cases included 3 in Broward County, 3 in Orange County and 1 in Miami-Dade. Miami-Dade has the state's largest number of Zika [virus] infections, with 88 people having contracted the virus this year.\n\nZika can be difficult to diagnose in part because only 1 in 5 infected people show symptoms, which include fever, joint pain, rash and red eyes lasting 7-10 days.\n\nWhile the CDC has not confirmed local transmission of Zika anywhere in the continental United States, evidence emerged this week that the virus is spreading in ways that are still a mystery to scientists. On Mon [18 Jul 2016], the CDC announced that epidemiologists are investigating a case in Utah involving a family member of an elderly man who contracted Zika while traveling outside the country and later died from complications of the disease after returning home. CDC officials reported that epidemiologists are interviewing and conducting blood tests of the dead man's family members and healthcare workers who may have had contact with the man, who died in Jun [2016].\n\nHealth officials are also trapping mosquitoes in Utah and testing them for the virus to assess the potential for local transmission. However, the 2 species known to transmit Zika are not known to be present in Utah.\n\nFlorida health officials said Zika prevention kits and repellent will be available for pick up in Miami-Dade and distributed in the area under investigation, which was not disclosed. Zika kits are intended for pregnant women, the health department said. County mosquito control has already conducted spraying and other prevention efforts in the neighborhood being investigated.\n\nPregnant women and their children are considered to be at greatest risk from the disease. Researchers have concluded that prenatal Zika infection can cause microcephaly and other brain disorders. According to the health department, there are 43 pregnant women in Florida who have contracted the virus this year.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Chang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Presumably, a viremic individual returned to Florida and provided an infectious blood meal for a vector mosquito that subsequently infected a local person. This is not surprising. In the past, there have been locally transmitted dengue viruses in Florida. The same vector mosquito transmits both viruses. Additional locally acquired cases where _Aedes aegypti_ is present in the southern USA can be expected during this transmission season.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Florida can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6998 and map of Florida sowing the location of Miami-Dade county at the southern tip of the state can be accessed at http://geology.com/county-map/florida.shtml. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] Utah: local transmission\nDate: Mon 18 Jul 2016\nSource: CDC Media Statement [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/s0718-zika-utah-investigation.html\n\n\nCDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] is assisting in the investigation of a case of Zika in a Utah resident who is a family contact of the elderly Utah resident who died in late Jun [2016]. The deceased patient had traveled to an area with Zika and lab tests showed he had uniquely high amounts of virus -- more than 100 000 times higher than seen in other samples of infected people -- in his blood. Laboratories in Utah and at the CDC reported evidence of Zika infection in both Utah residents.\n\nState and local public health disease control specialists, along with CDC, are investigating how the 2nd resident became infected. The investigation includes additional interviews with and laboratory testing of family members and health care workers who may have had contact with the person who died and trapping mosquitoes and assessing the risk of local spread by mosquitoes.\n\nA CDC Emergency Response Team (CERT) is in Utah at the request of the Utah Department of Health. The team includes experts in infection control, virology, mosquito control, disease investigation, and health communications. \"The new case in Utah is a surprise, showing that we still have more to learn about Zika,\" said Erin Staples, MD, PhD, CDC's Medical Epidemiologist on the ground in Utah. \"Fortunately, the patient recovered quickly, and from what we have seen with more than 1300 travel-associated cases of Zika in the continental United States and Hawaii, non-sexual spread from one person to another does not appear to be common.\"\n\nAs of 13 Jul 2016, 1306 cases of Zika have been reported in the continental United States and Hawaii; none of these have been the result of local spread by mosquitoes. These cases include 14 believed to be the result of sexual transmission and 1 that was the result of a laboratory exposure.\n\nSince early 2016, CDC has worked with state, local, and territorial public health officials to protect pregnant women from Zika infection, through these activities:\n\n- Alerts to pregnant women to avoid travel to an area with active Zika transmission, to women in these areas to take steps to prevent mosquito bites, and to partners of pregnant women to use a condom to prevent sexual transmission during pregnancy.\n- Development and distribution of PCR and IgM testing kits to confirm Zika virus infection.\n- Establishment of CDC Emergency Response Teams to rapidly deploy to assist with Zika-related preparedness and response activities in the United States.\n- Deployment of experts to assist in enhancement of mosquito surveillance and testing.\n- Collaboration with FDA, blood collection centers, and other entities in the public and private sectors on enhancement of surveillance of blood donations.\n- Guidance to prevent sexual transmission, particularly to women who are pregnant.\n- Guidance for clinicians on the care of pregnant women who may have been exposed to Zika [virus].\n- Studies in collaboration with Brazil, Colombia, and other countries to better understand the link between Zika infection and birth defects, including microcephaly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The obvious question is -- how did the caretaker become infected. Mosquitoes are unlikely as the source of the virus in this situation because no competent mosquito species is believed to be present in Utah. The source of the virus must have been the elderly man who subsequently died. He is reported to have had a very high viremia. Presumably there were substantial amounts of virus in urine and saliva as well. The importance of virus in saliva or urine as a source of transmissible virus has not been established. Clearly, this is an unusual case. With over 1300 Zika virus infected individuals reported in the USA, the only locally acquired cases were sexually transmitted, until now. ProMED would be interested in the results of the investigations by CDC and state specialists. - Mod. TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the USA showing the location of Utah can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.TY]\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/246.]\nSee Also\nZika virus (35): Americas, Asia, Europe 20160714.4346031\nZika virus (34): Americas, Asia, Africa, Europe 20160707.4331999\nZika virus (33): Americas, 20160108.3921447\n.................................................ml/ty/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Broward County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami - Dade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami Herald", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4412646", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus (41): Americas, Asia, Europe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4412646", "date": "2016-07-20 12:24:14", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS (36): AMERICAS (USA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Florida: local transmission\n[2] Utah: local transmission\n\n******\n[1] Florida: local transmission\nDate: Tue 19 Jul 2016, 6:54 PM\nSource: Miami Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.miamiherald.com/news/health-care/article90617692.html\n\n\nFlorida health officials are investigating a Zika infection in Miami-Dade County that may be the 1st acquired within the state, according to an announcement late Tue [19 Jul 2016]. Health officials reported they are conducting an epidemiological investigation in collaboration with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nNo details were provided regarding the potential mode of transmission. Zika is primarily transmitted by the bite of infected _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_ mosquitoes, though the CDC has also reported cases of the virus spreading through blood transfusions, from pregnant mothers to their newborn children, and by sexual transmission.\n\nFlorida health officials reported 7 new cases of Zika infection on Tue [19 Jul 2016], all acquired by people while traveling outside the country. The cases included 3 in Broward County, 3 in Orange County and 1 in Miami-Dade. Miami-Dade has the state's largest number of Zika [virus] infections, with 88 people having contracted the virus this year.\n\nZika can be difficult to diagnose in part because only 1 in 5 infected people show symptoms, which include fever, joint pain, rash and red eyes lasting 7-10 days.\n\nWhile the CDC has not confirmed local transmission of Zika anywhere in the continental United States, evidence emerged this week that the virus is spreading in ways that are still a mystery to scientists. On Mon [18 Jul 2016], the CDC announced that epidemiologists are investigating a case in Utah involving a family member of an elderly man who contracted Zika while traveling outside the country and later died from complications of the disease after returning home. CDC officials reported that epidemiologists are interviewing and conducting blood tests of the dead man's family members and healthcare workers who may have had contact with the man, who died in Jun [2016].\n\nHealth officials are also trapping mosquitoes in Utah and testing them for the virus to assess the potential for local transmission. However, the 2 species known to transmit Zika are not known to be present in Utah.\n\nFlorida health officials said Zika prevention kits and repellent will be available for pick up in Miami-Dade and distributed in the area under investigation, which was not disclosed. Zika kits are intended for pregnant women, the health department said. County mosquito control has already conducted spraying and other prevention efforts in the neighborhood being investigated.\n\nPregnant women and their children are considered to be at greatest risk from the disease. Researchers have concluded that prenatal Zika infection can cause microcephaly and other brain disorders. According to the health department, there are 43 pregnant women in Florida who have contracted the virus this year.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Chang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Presumably, a viremic individual returned to Florida and provided an infectious blood meal for a vector mosquito that subsequently infected a local person. This is not surprising. In the past, there have been locally transmitted dengue viruses in Florida. The same vector mosquito transmits both viruses. Additional locally acquired cases where _Aedes aegypti_ is present in the southern USA can be expected during this transmission season.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Florida can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6998 and map of Florida sowing the location of Miami-Dade county at the southern tip of the state can be accessed at http://geology.com/county-map/florida.shtml. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] Utah: local transmission\nDate: Mon 18 Jul 2016\nSource: CDC Media Statement [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/s0718-zika-utah-investigation.html\n\n\nCDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] is assisting in the investigation of a case of Zika in a Utah resident who is a family contact of the elderly Utah resident who died in late Jun [2016]. The deceased patient had traveled to an area with Zika and lab tests showed he had uniquely high amounts of virus -- more than 100 000 times higher than seen in other samples of infected people -- in his blood. Laboratories in Utah and at the CDC reported evidence of Zika infection in both Utah residents.\n\nState and local public health disease control specialists, along with CDC, are investigating how the 2nd resident became infected. The investigation includes additional interviews with and laboratory testing of family members and health care workers who may have had contact with the person who died and trapping mosquitoes and assessing the risk of local spread by mosquitoes.\n\nA CDC Emergency Response Team (CERT) is in Utah at the request of the Utah Department of Health. The team includes experts in infection control, virology, mosquito control, disease investigation, and health communications. \"The new case in Utah is a surprise, showing that we still have more to learn about Zika,\" said Erin Staples, MD, PhD, CDC's Medical Epidemiologist on the ground in Utah. \"Fortunately, the patient recovered quickly, and from what we have seen with more than 1300 travel-associated cases of Zika in the continental United States and Hawaii, non-sexual spread from one person to another does not appear to be common.\"\n\nAs of 13 Jul 2016, 1306 cases of Zika have been reported in the continental United States and Hawaii; none of these have been the result of local spread by mosquitoes. These cases include 14 believed to be the result of sexual transmission and 1 that was the result of a laboratory exposure.\n\nSince early 2016, CDC has worked with state, local, and territorial public health officials to protect pregnant women from Zika infection, through these activities:\n\n- Alerts to pregnant women to avoid travel to an area with active Zika transmission, to women in these areas to take steps to prevent mosquito bites, and to partners of pregnant women to use a condom to prevent sexual transmission during pregnancy.\n- Development and distribution of PCR and IgM testing kits to confirm Zika virus infection.\n- Establishment of CDC Emergency Response Teams to rapidly deploy to assist with Zika-related preparedness and response activities in the United States.\n- Deployment of experts to assist in enhancement of mosquito surveillance and testing.\n- Collaboration with FDA, blood collection centers, and other entities in the public and private sectors on enhancement of surveillance of blood donations.\n- Guidance to prevent sexual transmission, particularly to women who are pregnant.\n- Guidance for clinicians on the care of pregnant women who may have been exposed to Zika [virus].\n- Studies in collaboration with Brazil, Colombia, and other countries to better understand the link between Zika infection and birth defects, including microcephaly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The obvious question is -- how did the caretaker become infected. Mosquitoes are unlikely as the source of the virus in this situation because no competent mosquito species is believed to be present in Utah. The source of the virus must have been the elderly man who subsequently died. He is reported to have had a very high viremia. Presumably there were substantial amounts of virus in urine and saliva as well. The importance of virus in saliva or urine as a source of transmissible virus has not been established. Clearly, this is an unusual case. With over 1300 Zika virus infected individuals reported in the USA, the only locally acquired cases were sexually transmitted, until now. ProMED would be interested in the results of the investigations by CDC and state specialists. - Mod. TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the USA showing the location of Utah can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.TY]\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "microcephaly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami - Dade County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pacific", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4378060", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus (39): Americas, Europe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4378060", "date": "2016-07-20 12:24:14", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS (36): AMERICAS (USA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Florida: local transmission\n[2] Utah: local transmission\n\n******\n[1] Florida: local transmission\nDate: Tue 19 Jul 2016, 6:54 PM\nSource: Miami Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.miamiherald.com/news/health-care/article90617692.html\n\n\nFlorida health officials are investigating a Zika infection in Miami-Dade County that may be the 1st acquired within the state, according to an announcement late Tue [19 Jul 2016]. Health officials reported they are conducting an epidemiological investigation in collaboration with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nNo details were provided regarding the potential mode of transmission. Zika is primarily transmitted by the bite of infected _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_ mosquitoes, though the CDC has also reported cases of the virus spreading through blood transfusions, from pregnant mothers to their newborn children, and by sexual transmission.\n\nFlorida health officials reported 7 new cases of Zika infection on Tue [19 Jul 2016], all acquired by people while traveling outside the country. The cases included 3 in Broward County, 3 in Orange County and 1 in Miami-Dade. Miami-Dade has the state's largest number of Zika [virus] infections, with 88 people having contracted the virus this year.\n\nZika can be difficult to diagnose in part because only 1 in 5 infected people show symptoms, which include fever, joint pain, rash and red eyes lasting 7-10 days.\n\nWhile the CDC has not confirmed local transmission of Zika anywhere in the continental United States, evidence emerged this week that the virus is spreading in ways that are still a mystery to scientists. On Mon [18 Jul 2016], the CDC announced that epidemiologists are investigating a case in Utah involving a family member of an elderly man who contracted Zika while traveling outside the country and later died from complications of the disease after returning home. CDC officials reported that epidemiologists are interviewing and conducting blood tests of the dead man's family members and healthcare workers who may have had contact with the man, who died in Jun [2016].\n\nHealth officials are also trapping mosquitoes in Utah and testing them for the virus to assess the potential for local transmission. However, the 2 species known to transmit Zika are not known to be present in Utah.\n\nFlorida health officials said Zika prevention kits and repellent will be available for pick up in Miami-Dade and distributed in the area under investigation, which was not disclosed. Zika kits are intended for pregnant women, the health department said. County mosquito control has already conducted spraying and other prevention efforts in the neighborhood being investigated.\n\nPregnant women and their children are considered to be at greatest risk from the disease. Researchers have concluded that prenatal Zika infection can cause microcephaly and other brain disorders. According to the health department, there are 43 pregnant women in Florida who have contracted the virus this year.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Chang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Presumably, a viremic individual returned to Florida and provided an infectious blood meal for a vector mosquito that subsequently infected a local person. This is not surprising. In the past, there have been locally transmitted dengue viruses in Florida. The same vector mosquito transmits both viruses. Additional locally acquired cases where _Aedes aegypti_ is present in the southern USA can be expected during this transmission season.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Florida can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6998 and map of Florida sowing the location of Miami-Dade county at the southern tip of the state can be accessed at http://geology.com/county-map/florida.shtml. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] Utah: local transmission\nDate: Mon 18 Jul 2016\nSource: CDC Media Statement [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/s0718-zika-utah-investigation.html\n\n\nCDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] is assisting in the investigation of a case of Zika in a Utah resident who is a family contact of the elderly Utah resident who died in late Jun [2016]. The deceased patient had traveled to an area with Zika and lab tests showed he had uniquely high amounts of virus -- more than 100 000 times higher than seen in other samples of infected people -- in his blood. Laboratories in Utah and at the CDC reported evidence of Zika infection in both Utah residents.\n\nState and local public health disease control specialists, along with CDC, are investigating how the 2nd resident became infected. The investigation includes additional interviews with and laboratory testing of family members and health care workers who may have had contact with the person who died and trapping mosquitoes and assessing the risk of local spread by mosquitoes.\n\nA CDC Emergency Response Team (CERT) is in Utah at the request of the Utah Department of Health. The team includes experts in infection control, virology, mosquito control, disease investigation, and health communications. \"The new case in Utah is a surprise, showing that we still have more to learn about Zika,\" said Erin Staples, MD, PhD, CDC's Medical Epidemiologist on the ground in Utah. \"Fortunately, the patient recovered quickly, and from what we have seen with more than 1300 travel-associated cases of Zika in the continental United States and Hawaii, non-sexual spread from one person to another does not appear to be common.\"\n\nAs of 13 Jul 2016, 1306 cases of Zika have been reported in the continental United States and Hawaii; none of these have been the result of local spread by mosquitoes. These cases include 14 believed to be the result of sexual transmission and 1 that was the result of a laboratory exposure.\n\nSince early 2016, CDC has worked with state, local, and territorial public health officials to protect pregnant women from Zika infection, through these activities:\n\n- Alerts to pregnant women to avoid travel to an area with active Zika transmission, to women in these areas to take steps to prevent mosquito bites, and to partners of pregnant women to use a condom to prevent sexual transmission during pregnancy.\n- Development and distribution of PCR and IgM testing kits to confirm Zika virus infection.\n- Establishment of CDC Emergency Response Teams to rapidly deploy to assist with Zika-related preparedness and response activities in the United States.\n- Deployment of experts to assist in enhancement of mosquito surveillance and testing.\n- Collaboration with FDA, blood collection centers, and other entities in the public and private sectors on enhancement of surveillance of blood donations.\n- Guidance to prevent sexual transmission, particularly to women who are pregnant.\n- Guidance for clinicians on the care of pregnant women who may have been exposed to Zika [virus].\n- Studies in collaboration with Brazil, Colombia, and other countries to better understand the link between Zika infection and birth defects, including microcephaly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The obvious question is -- how did the caretaker become infected. Mosquitoes are unlikely as the source of the virus in this situation because no competent mosquito species is believed to be present in Utah. The source of the virus must have been the elderly man who subsequently died. He is reported to have had a very high viremia. Presumably there were substantial amounts of virus in urine and saliva as well. The importance of virus in saliva or urine as a source of transmissible virus has not been established. Clearly, this is an unusual case. With over 1300 Zika virus infected individuals reported in the USA, the only locally acquired cases were sexually transmitted, until now. ProMED would be interested in the results of the investigations by CDC and state specialists. - Mod. TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the USA showing the location of Utah can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.TY]\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/246.]\nSee Also\nZika virus (35): Americas, Asia, Europe 20160714.4346031\nZika virus (34): Americas, Asia, Africa, Europe 20160707.4331999\nZika virus (33): Americas, 20160511.4214303\nZika virus (26): Americas, Asia, Europe, Indian Ocean 20160504.4202525\nZika virus (25): Americas 20160501.4195452\nZika virus (24): Americas 20160422.4177323\nZika virus (23): Americas 20160419.4168370\nZika virus (22): sexual transmission 20160416.4162854\nZika virus (21): Americas (Brazil) diagnostic imaging 20160415.4160993\nZika virus (20): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Pacific, Atlantic 20160325.4118019\nZika virus (15): Americas 20160321.4109160\nZika virus (14): Americas, Europe, Atlantic Ocean 20160317.4102468\nZika virus (13): Americas, Asia, Europe, Pacific 20160311.4086075\nZika virus (12): Brazil, microcephaly 20160305.4070601\nZika virus (11): Americas, Europe, Asia 20160301.4059896\nZika virus (10): Americas, Asia, Europe, Pacific 20160229.4058161\nZika virus (09): Americas, Africa, Europe, Pacific 20160223.4042828\nZika virus (08): Americas, Asia, Europe, Pacific 20160217.4026836\nZika virus (07): update 20160216.4023810\nProMED-mail endorses sharing of Zika virus data 20160211.4012212\nZika virus (06): overview 20160209.4007411\nZika virus (05): Americas, Asia, Pacific 20160203.3990632\nZika virus (04): WHO declares worldwide PHEIC 20160201.3985366\nZika virus (03): Americas, Asia 20160128.3974426\nZika virus - Americas (02) 20160111.3925377\nZika virus - Americas (01) 20160108.3921447\n.................................................ml/ty/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4368191", "date": "2016-07-20 12:24:14", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS (36): AMERICAS (USA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Florida: local transmission\n[2] Utah: local transmission\n\n******\n[1] Florida: local transmission\nDate: Tue 19 Jul 2016, 6:54 PM\nSource: Miami Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.miamiherald.com/news/health-care/article90617692.html\n\n\nFlorida health officials are investigating a Zika infection in Miami-Dade County that may be the 1st acquired within the state, according to an announcement late Tue [19 Jul 2016]. Health officials reported they are conducting an epidemiological investigation in collaboration with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nNo details were provided regarding the potential mode of transmission. Zika is primarily transmitted by the bite of infected _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_ mosquitoes, though the CDC has also reported cases of the virus spreading through blood transfusions, from pregnant mothers to their newborn children, and by sexual transmission.\n\nFlorida health officials reported 7 new cases of Zika infection on Tue [19 Jul 2016], all acquired by people while traveling outside the country. The cases included 3 in Broward County, 3 in Orange County and 1 in Miami-Dade. Miami-Dade has the state's largest number of Zika [virus] infections, with 88 people having contracted the virus this year.\n\nZika can be difficult to diagnose in part because only 1 in 5 infected people show symptoms, which include fever, joint pain, rash and red eyes lasting 7-10 days.\n\nWhile the CDC has not confirmed local transmission of Zika anywhere in the continental United States, evidence emerged this week that the virus is spreading in ways that are still a mystery to scientists. On Mon [18 Jul 2016], the CDC announced that epidemiologists are investigating a case in Utah involving a family member of an elderly man who contracted Zika while traveling outside the country and later died from complications of the disease after returning home. CDC officials reported that epidemiologists are interviewing and conducting blood tests of the dead man's family members and healthcare workers who may have had contact with the man, who died in Jun [2016].\n\nHealth officials are also trapping mosquitoes in Utah and testing them for the virus to assess the potential for local transmission. However, the 2 species known to transmit Zika are not known to be present in Utah.\n\nFlorida health officials said Zika prevention kits and repellent will be available for pick up in Miami-Dade and distributed in the area under investigation, which was not disclosed. Zika kits are intended for pregnant women, the health department said. County mosquito control has already conducted spraying and other prevention efforts in the neighborhood being investigated.\n\nPregnant women and their children are considered to be at greatest risk from the disease. Researchers have concluded that prenatal Zika infection can cause microcephaly and other brain disorders. According to the health department, there are 43 pregnant women in Florida who have contracted the virus this year.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Chang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Presumably, a viremic individual returned to Florida and provided an infectious blood meal for a vector mosquito that subsequently infected a local person. This is not surprising. In the past, there have been locally transmitted dengue viruses in Florida. The same vector mosquito transmits both viruses. Additional locally acquired cases where _Aedes aegypti_ is present in the southern USA can be expected during this transmission season.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Florida can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6998 and map of Florida sowing the location of Miami-Dade county at the southern tip of the state can be accessed at http://geology.com/county-map/florida.shtml. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] Utah: local transmission\nDate: Mon 18 Jul 2016\nSource: CDC Media Statement [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/s0718-zika-utah-investigation.html\n\n\nCDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] is assisting in the investigation of a case of Zika in a Utah resident who is a family contact of the elderly Utah resident who died in late Jun [2016]. The deceased patient had traveled to an area with Zika and lab tests showed he had uniquely high amounts of virus -- more than 100 000 times higher than seen in other samples of infected people -- in his blood. Laboratories in Utah and at the CDC reported evidence of Zika infection in both Utah residents.\n\nState and local public health disease control specialists, along with CDC, are investigating how the 2nd resident became infected. The investigation includes additional interviews with and laboratory testing of family members and health care workers who may have had contact with the person who died and trapping mosquitoes and assessing the risk of local spread by mosquitoes.\n\nA CDC Emergency Response Team (CERT) is in Utah at the request of the Utah Department of Health. The team includes experts in infection control, virology, mosquito control, disease investigation, and health communications. \"The new case in Utah is a surprise, showing that we still have more to learn about Zika,\" said Erin Staples, MD, PhD, CDC's Medical Epidemiologist on the ground in Utah. \"Fortunately, the patient recovered quickly, and from what we have seen with more than 1300 travel-associated cases of Zika in the continental United States and Hawaii, non-sexual spread from one person to another does not appear to be common.\"\n\nAs of 13 Jul 2016, 1306 cases of Zika have been reported in the continental United States and Hawaii; none of these have been the result of local spread by mosquitoes. These cases include 14 believed to be the result of sexual transmission and 1 that was the result of a laboratory exposure.\n\nSince early 2016, CDC has worked with state, local, and territorial public health officials to protect pregnant women from Zika infection, through these activities:\n\n- Alerts to pregnant women to avoid travel to an area with active Zika transmission, to women in these areas to take steps to prevent mosquito bites, and to partners of pregnant women to use a condom to prevent sexual transmission during pregnancy.\n- Development and distribution of PCR and IgM testing kits to confirm Zika virus infection.\n- Establishment of CDC Emergency Response Teams to rapidly deploy to assist with Zika-related preparedness and response activities in the United States.\n- Deployment of experts to assist in enhancement of mosquito surveillance and testing.\n- Collaboration with FDA, blood collection centers, and other entities in the public and private sectors on enhancement of surveillance of blood donations.\n- Guidance to prevent sexual transmission, particularly to women who are pregnant.\n- Guidance for clinicians on the care of pregnant women who may have been exposed to Zika [virus].\n- Studies in collaboration with Brazil, Colombia, and other countries to better understand the link between Zika infection and birth defects, including microcephaly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The obvious question is -- how did the caretaker become infected. Mosquitoes are unlikely as the source of the virus in this situation because no competent mosquito species is believed to be present in Utah. The source of the virus must have been the elderly man who subsequently died. He is reported to have had a very high viremia. Presumably there were substantial amounts of virus in urine and saliva as well. The importance of virus in saliva or urine as a source of transmissible virus has not been established. Clearly, this is an unusual case. With over 1300 Zika virus infected individuals reported in the USA, the only locally acquired cases were sexually transmitted, until now. ProMED would be interested in the results of the investigations by CDC and state specialists. - Mod. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4361791", "date": "2016-07-20 12:24:14", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS (36): AMERICAS (USA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Florida: local transmission\n[2] Utah: local transmission\n\n******\n[1] Florida: local transmission\nDate: Tue 19 Jul 2016, 6:54 PM\nSource: Miami Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.miamiherald.com/news/health-care/article90617692.html\n\n\nFlorida health officials are investigating a Zika infection in Miami-Dade County that may be the 1st acquired within the state, according to an announcement late Tue [19 Jul 2016]. Health officials reported they are conducting an epidemiological investigation in collaboration with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nNo details were provided regarding the potential mode of transmission. Zika is primarily transmitted by the bite of infected _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_ mosquitoes, though the CDC has also reported cases of the virus spreading through blood transfusions, from pregnant mothers to their newborn children, and by sexual transmission.\n\nFlorida health officials reported 7 new cases of Zika infection on Tue [19 Jul 2016], all acquired by people while traveling outside the country. The cases included 3 in Broward County, 3 in Orange County and 1 in Miami-Dade. Miami-Dade has the state's largest number of Zika [virus] infections, with 88 people having contracted the virus this year.\n\nZika can be difficult to diagnose in part because only 1 in 5 infected people show symptoms, which include fever, joint pain, rash and red eyes lasting 7-10 days.\n\nWhile the CDC has not confirmed local transmission of Zika anywhere in the continental United States, evidence emerged this week that the virus is spreading in ways that are still a mystery to scientists. On Mon [18 Jul 2016], the CDC announced that epidemiologists are investigating a case in Utah involving a family member of an elderly man who contracted Zika while traveling outside the country and later died from complications of the disease after returning home. CDC officials reported that epidemiologists are interviewing and conducting blood tests of the dead man's family members and healthcare workers who may have had contact with the man, who died in Jun [2016].\n\nHealth officials are also trapping mosquitoes in Utah and testing them for the virus to assess the potential for local transmission. However, the 2 species known to transmit Zika are not known to be present in Utah.\n\nFlorida health officials said Zika prevention kits and repellent will be available for pick up in Miami-Dade and distributed in the area under investigation, which was not disclosed. Zika kits are intended for pregnant women, the health department said. County mosquito control has already conducted spraying and other prevention efforts in the neighborhood being investigated.\n\nPregnant women and their children are considered to be at greatest risk from the disease. Researchers have concluded that prenatal Zika infection can cause microcephaly and other brain disorders. According to the health department, there are 43 pregnant women in Florida who have contracted the virus this year.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Chang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Presumably, a viremic individual returned to Florida and provided an infectious blood meal for a vector mosquito that subsequently infected a local person. This is not surprising. In the past, there have been locally transmitted dengue viruses in Florida. The same vector mosquito transmits both viruses. Additional locally acquired cases where _Aedes aegypti_ is present in the southern USA can be expected during this transmission season.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Florida can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6998 and map of Florida sowing the location of Miami-Dade county at the southern tip of the state can be accessed at http://geology.com/county-map/florida.shtml. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] Utah: local transmission\nDate: Mon 18 Jul 2016\nSource: CDC Media Statement [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/s0718-zika-utah-investigation.html\n\n\nCDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] is assisting in the investigation of a case of Zika in a Utah resident who is a family contact of the elderly Utah resident who died in late Jun [2016]. The deceased patient had traveled to an area with Zika and lab tests showed he had uniquely high amounts of virus -- more than 100 000 times higher than seen in other samples of infected people -- in his blood. Laboratories in Utah and at the CDC reported evidence of Zika infection in both Utah residents.\n\nState and local public health disease control specialists, along with CDC, are investigating how the 2nd resident became infected. The investigation includes additional interviews with and laboratory testing of family members and health care workers who may have had contact with the person who died and trapping mosquitoes and assessing the risk of local spread by mosquitoes.\n\nA CDC Emergency Response Team (CERT) is in Utah at the request of the Utah Department of Health. The team includes experts in infection control, virology, mosquito control, disease investigation, and health communications. \"The new case in Utah is a surprise, showing that we still have more to learn about Zika,\" said Erin Staples, MD, PhD, CDC's Medical Epidemiologist on the ground in Utah. \"Fortunately, the patient recovered quickly, and from what we have seen with more than 1300 travel-associated cases of Zika in the continental United States and Hawaii, non-sexual spread from one person to another does not appear to be common.\"\n\nAs of 13 Jul 2016, 1306 cases of Zika have been reported in the continental United States and Hawaii; none of these have been the result of local spread by mosquitoes. These cases include 14 believed to be the result of sexual transmission and 1 that was the result of a laboratory exposure.\n\nSince early 2016, CDC has worked with state, local, and territorial public health officials to protect pregnant women from Zika infection, through these activities:\n\n- Alerts to pregnant women to avoid travel to an area with active Zika transmission, to women in these areas to take steps to prevent mosquito bites, and to partners of pregnant women to use a condom to prevent sexual transmission during pregnancy.\n- Development and distribution of PCR and IgM testing kits to confirm Zika virus infection.\n- Establishment of CDC Emergency Response Teams to rapidly deploy to assist with Zika-related preparedness and response activities in the United States.\n- Deployment of experts to assist in enhancement of mosquito surveillance and testing.\n- Collaboration with FDA, blood collection centers, and other entities in the public and private sectors on enhancement of surveillance of blood donations.\n- Guidance to prevent sexual transmission, particularly to women who are pregnant.\n- Guidance for clinicians on the care of pregnant women who may have been exposed to Zika [virus].\n- Studies in collaboration with Brazil, Colombia, and other countries to better understand the link between Zika infection and birth defects, including microcephaly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The obvious question is -- how did the caretaker become infected. Mosquitoes are unlikely as the source of the virus in this situation because no competent mosquito species is believed to be present in Utah. The source of the virus must have been the elderly man who subsequently died. He is reported to have had a very high viremia. Presumably there were substantial amounts of virus in urine and saliva as well. The importance of virus in saliva or urine as a source of transmissible virus has not been established. Clearly, this is an unusual case. With over 1300 Zika virus infected individuals reported in the USA, the only locally acquired cases were sexually transmitted, until now. ProMED would be interested in the results of the investigations by CDC and state specialists. - Mod. TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the USA showing the location of Utah can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.TY]\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/246.]\nSee Also\nZika virus (35): Americas, Asia, Europe 20160714.4346031\nZika virus (34): Americas, Asia, Africa, Europe 20160707.4331999\nZika virus (33): Americas, 20160108.3921447\n.................................................ml/ty/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Broward County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami - Dade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami Herald", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orange County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4356276", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus (36): Americas (USA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4356276", "date": "2016-07-20 12:24:14", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS (36): AMERICAS (USA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Florida: local transmission\n[2] Utah: local transmission\n\n******\n[1] Florida: local transmission\nDate: Tue 19 Jul 2016, 6:54 PM\nSource: Miami Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.miamiherald.com/news/health-care/article90617692.html\n\n\nFlorida health officials are investigating a Zika infection in Miami-Dade County that may be the 1st acquired within the state, according to an announcement late Tue [19 Jul 2016]. Health officials reported they are conducting an epidemiological investigation in collaboration with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nNo details were provided regarding the potential mode of transmission. Zika is primarily transmitted by the bite of infected _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_ mosquitoes, though the CDC has also reported cases of the virus spreading through blood transfusions, from pregnant mothers to their newborn children, and by sexual transmission.\n\nFlorida health officials reported 7 new cases of Zika infection on Tue [19 Jul 2016], all acquired by people while traveling outside the country. The cases included 3 in Broward County, 3 in Orange County and 1 in Miami-Dade. Miami-Dade has the state's largest number of Zika [virus] infections, with 88 people having contracted the virus this year.\n\nZika can be difficult to diagnose in part because only 1 in 5 infected people show symptoms, which include fever, joint pain, rash and red eyes lasting 7-10 days.\n\nWhile the CDC has not confirmed local transmission of Zika anywhere in the continental United States, evidence emerged this week that the virus is spreading in ways that are still a mystery to scientists. On Mon [18 Jul 2016], the CDC announced that epidemiologists are investigating a case in Utah involving a family member of an elderly man who contracted Zika while traveling outside the country and later died from complications of the disease after returning home. CDC officials reported that epidemiologists are interviewing and conducting blood tests of the dead man's family members and healthcare workers who may have had contact with the man, who died in Jun [2016].\n\nHealth officials are also trapping mosquitoes in Utah and testing them for the virus to assess the potential for local transmission. However, the 2 species known to transmit Zika are not known to be present in Utah.\n\nFlorida health officials said Zika prevention kits and repellent will be available for pick up in Miami-Dade and distributed in the area under investigation, which was not disclosed. Zika kits are intended for pregnant women, the health department said. County mosquito control has already conducted spraying and other prevention efforts in the neighborhood being investigated.\n\nPregnant women and their children are considered to be at greatest risk from the disease. Researchers have concluded that prenatal Zika infection can cause microcephaly and other brain disorders. According to the health department, there are 43 pregnant women in Florida who have contracted the virus this year.\n\n[Byline: Daniel Chang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Presumably, a viremic individual returned to Florida and provided an infectious blood meal for a vector mosquito that subsequently infected a local person. This is not surprising. In the past, there have been locally transmitted dengue viruses in Florida. The same vector mosquito transmits both viruses. Additional locally acquired cases where _Aedes aegypti_ is present in the southern USA can be expected during this transmission season.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Florida can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6998 and map of Florida sowing the location of Miami-Dade county at the southern tip of the state can be accessed at http://geology.com/county-map/florida.shtml. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] Utah: local transmission\nDate: Mon 18 Jul 2016\nSource: CDC Media Statement [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/s0718-zika-utah-investigation.html\n\n\nCDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] is assisting in the investigation of a case of Zika in a Utah resident who is a family contact of the elderly Utah resident who died in late Jun [2016]. The deceased patient had traveled to an area with Zika and lab tests showed he had uniquely high amounts of virus -- more than 100 000 times higher than seen in other samples of infected people -- in his blood. Laboratories in Utah and at the CDC reported evidence of Zika infection in both Utah residents.\n\nState and local public health disease control specialists, along with CDC, are investigating how the 2nd resident became infected. The investigation includes additional interviews with and laboratory testing of family members and health care workers who may have had contact with the person who died and trapping mosquitoes and assessing the risk of local spread by mosquitoes.\n\nA CDC Emergency Response Team (CERT) is in Utah at the request of the Utah Department of Health. The team includes experts in infection control, virology, mosquito control, disease investigation, and health communications. \"The new case in Utah is a surprise, showing that we still have more to learn about Zika,\" said Erin Staples, MD, PhD, CDC's Medical Epidemiologist on the ground in Utah. \"Fortunately, the patient recovered quickly, and from what we have seen with more than 1300 travel-associated cases of Zika in the continental United States and Hawaii, non-sexual spread from one person to another does not appear to be common.\"\n\nAs of 13 Jul 2016, 1306 cases of Zika have been reported in the continental United States and Hawaii; none of these have been the result of local spread by mosquitoes. These cases include 14 believed to be the result of sexual transmission and 1 that was the result of a laboratory exposure.\n\nSince early 2016, CDC has worked with state, local, and territorial public health officials to protect pregnant women from Zika infection, through these activities:\n\n- Alerts to pregnant women to avoid travel to an area with active Zika transmission, to women in these areas to take steps to prevent mosquito bites, and to partners of pregnant women to use a condom to prevent sexual transmission during pregnancy.\n- Development and distribution of PCR and IgM testing kits to confirm Zika virus infection.\n- Establishment of CDC Emergency Response Teams to rapidly deploy to assist with Zika-related preparedness and response activities in the United States.\n- Deployment of experts to assist in enhancement of mosquito surveillance and testing.\n- Collaboration with FDA, blood collection centers, and other entities in the public and private sectors on enhancement of surveillance of blood donations.\n- Guidance to prevent sexual transmission, particularly to women who are pregnant.\n- Guidance for clinicians on the care of pregnant women who may have been exposed to Zika [virus].\n- Studies in collaboration with Brazil, Colombia, and other countries to better understand the link between Zika infection and birth defects, including microcephaly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The obvious question is -- how did the caretaker become infected. Mosquitoes are unlikely as the source of the virus in this situation because no competent mosquito species is believed to be present in Utah. The source of the virus must have been the elderly man who subsequently died. He is reported to have had a very high viremia. Presumably there were substantial amounts of virus in urine and saliva as well. The importance of virus in saliva or urine as a source of transmissible virus has not been established. Clearly, this is an unusual case. With over 1300 Zika virus infected individuals reported in the USA, the only locally acquired cases were sexually transmitted, until now. ProMED would be interested in the results of the investigations by CDC and state specialists. - Mod. TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the USA showing the location of Utah can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.TY]\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/246.]\nSee Also\nZika virus (35): Americas, Asia, Europe 20160714.4346031\nZika virus (34): Americas, Asia, Africa, Europe 20160707.4331999\nZika virus (33): Americas, 20160108.3921447\n.................................................ml/ty/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Broward County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami - Dade", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami Herald", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"},
