Europe\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nAmericas\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in the Americas mentioned below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574; North America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106; Central America and the Caribbean at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455; and South America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nMexico and Central America\n---\nMexico. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) 222 cases of whom 53 are pregnant; States reporting as of week 13 (week ending 2 Apr 2016): Chiapas 112 cases, Oaxaca 85 cases, remaining cases in Guerrero, Jalisco, Michoac\u00e1n, Nayarit, Nuevo Le\u00f3n, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Veracruz, Yucat\u00e1n.\nhttp://lopezdoriga.com/nacional/suman-222-casos-de-infeccion-por-zika-en-mexico-ssa/ [in Spanish]\n\nHonduras. 1 Apr 2016. (reported) more than 15 000 cases; 1st case of peripheral neuropathy in 14 year old girl; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 18 new cases.\nhttp://www.latribuna.hn/2016/04/01/se-reporta-primer-caso-neuropatia-sensitiva-provocado-zika/ [in Spanish]\n\nPanama. 8 Apr 2016. (reported) since November 2015, 201 cases; Microcephaly 4 cases [no mention if Zika virus infected mothers or fetuses - Mod.TY]; Locality most affected: comarca Guna Yala 115 cases.\nhttp://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/casos-microcefalia-asociadas-registrado-Panama_0_905909581.html [in Spanish]\n\nCaribbean\n---\nCuba. 13 Apr 2016. (conf.) 10 cases of which 9 cases imported ex Venezuela, 1 case locally acquired.\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-04/14/c_135276237.htm\n\n[Although these cases are imported, Cuba has vectors that are sufficient for ongoing transmission. - Mod.TY]\n\nDominican Republic. 7 Apr 2016. (susp.) 1035 cases, (conf.) 55 cases of whom 19 pregnant; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 1 fatal case with previous Zika virus infection.\nhttps://es-us.noticias.yahoo.com/dominicana-registra-2-muertes-vinculadas-con-zika-151856088.html?nhp=1 [in Spanish]\n\nMartinique. 8 Apr 2016. (susp.) medical consultations 16 650 patients; Zika virus infected pregnant women119, 2 with fetuses with microcephaly (ultrasound); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 7 cases, 6 of whom confirmed post Zika virus infection; Localities affected: all except Lorrain.\nhttp://la1ere.francetvinfo.fr/martinique/zika-1260-cas-en-une-semaine-et-une-tendance-generale-la-baisse-348220.html [in French, trans. Corr.SB]\n\nPuerto Rico. 9 Apr 2016. (conf.) 436 cases, 8 of whom hospitalized, 60 pregnant (38 symptomatic of infection, 22 asymptomatic); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 5 cases.\nhttps://twitter.com/HelenBranswell/status/718557255961022464 [in Spanish]\n\nSt. Lucia. 8 Apr 2016. (conf.) 2 cases, locally acquired, the 1st cases on the Island.\nhttp://www.enca.com/world/zika-hits-caribbean-island-st-lucia\n\nTrinidad. 31 Mar 2016. (conf.) 9 cases.\nhttps://m.facebook.com/notes/ministry-of-health-trinidad-and-tobago/update-on-zika-virus/966139170108604/\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz). 1 Apr 2016. (reported) 16 cases; No new cases recently.\nhttp://www.la-razon.com/sociedad/Aumentan-chikunguna-Santa-Cruz-semana_0_2464553599.html [in Spanish]\n\nBrazil microcephaly. 12 Apr 2016. (under investigation) for the week 2-9 Apr 2016, 3836 cases, (conf.) 1113 cases.\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/images/pdf/2016/abril/12/COES-Microcefalias---Informe-Epidemiol--gico-21--SE-14-2016--12abril2016--11h24.pdf [in Portuguese]\n\nColombia:\n- National. 9 Apr 2016. (reported) 64 839 cases of whom 11 776 are pregnant; Microcephaly 30 cases under study, no officially reported cases due to Zika virus infection; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 sybdrome 416 cases with a history of febrile disease compatible with Zika virus infection.\nhttp://www.swissinfo.ch/spa/colombia-investiga-30-casos-de-microcefalia-sospechosos-de-estar-asociados-con-zika/42078100 [in Spanish]\n\n- Bucaramanga. 14 Apr 2016. (reports) local transmission [case numbers and dates of occurrence not given]; Travel notice issued by USA CDC.\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/cdc-issues-travel-notice-for-the-island-of-kosrae-due-to-zika-transmission-31946/\n\n[A map of the Federated States of Micronesia showing the location of Kosrae can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/fm.htm. - Mod.TY]\n\nAsia\n---\nChina (Guangdong province) 10 Apr 2016. (conf.) 2 cases, one of whom pregnant; 1st cases in country; Unclear if imported or locally acquired.\nhttp://www.thanhniennews.com/health/zika-virus-spreads-to-vietnam-with-first-2-confirmed-cases-60915.html\n\n[Maps of Viet Nam can be seen at http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCountries with cases but no ongoing transmission\n---\nNew Zealand. 13 Apr 2016. (reported) 85 imported cases, 2 (conf.) new cases, one ex Venezuela.\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/news/bites/301424/two-more-zika-cases-reported-in-nz\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New Zealand can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164. - Mod.TY]\n\nNorway. 13 Apr 2016. (reported) 88 cases of whom 11 are pregnant, all ex countries with active virus transmission; Localities with cases: Catalonia 28 cases, Madrid 23 cases, Castile 9 cases, Leon 9 cases, Aragon 7 cases, 3 cases each in Valencia Galicia, Andalusia, 2 cases each in Asturias, Murcia, Canaries, La Rioja and 1 in Basque country.\nhttp://www.plenglish.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4778881&Itemid=1\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Spain can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43. - Mod.TY]\n\nUruguay. 6 Apr 2016. (conf.) 1st case in the country, ex Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.\nhttp://www.prensa-latina.cu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4762611&Itemid=1 [in Spanish]\n\n[Although no ongoing transmission has been reported, Uruguay recently has had locally acquired dengue cases, indicating that the mosquito vector is present, with potential risk of local cases. Roland Hubner is thanked for sending in this report. - Mod.TY]\nhttp://www.plenglish.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4778881&Itemid=1\n\nUSA:\n- Case numbers mainland. Zika virus disease in the United States, 2015-2016 as of 13 Apr 2016\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html\nState/no. imported cases\nAlabama 2\nArizona 1\nArkansas 2\nCalifornia 29, 1 locally sexually transmitted case\nColorado 2\nConnecticut 1\nDelaware 3\nDistrict of Columbia 3\nFlorida 85\nGeorgia 11\nHawaii 5\nIllinois 10\nIndiana 6\nIowa 4\nKansas 1\nKentucky 3\nLouisiana 4\nMaine 1\nMaryland 7\nMassachusetts 7\nMichigan 2\nMinnesota 12\nMississippi 3\nMissouri 3\nMontana 1\nNebraska 2\nNevada 2\nNew Hampshire 2\nNew Jersey 8\nNew York 54\nNorth Carolina 9\nOhio 9\nOklahoma 3\nOregon 6\nPennsylvania 12\nTennessee 2\nTexas 27*\nUtah 2\nVirginia 8\nWashington 2\nWest Virginia 5\nTotal 358\n\n*One case of male to male sexual transmission in Dallas (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6514a3.htm?s_cid=mm6514a3_e)\n\n- Territories and Commonwealth\nAmerican Samoa 14 locally acquired\nPuerto Rico 3 imported 445 locally acquired\nUS Virgin Islands 1 imported, 12 locally acquired\nTotal locally acquired 471\n\n[A map of the USA showing the states mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Mosquito vectors. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) Federal health officials said in a joint conference today [11 Apr 2016] the mosquitoes species that spread the Zika virus are now in 30 states. This is more than double the 12 states they had been found previously.\nhttp://6abc.com/news/health-officials-says-mosquitos-that-spread-zika-now-in-30-states/1286128/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2016\nSource: The New England Journal of Medicine DOI: 10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 [edited]\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsr1604338?query=featured_home\n\n\nSonja A. Rasmussen, M.D., Denise J. Jamieson, M.D., M.P.H., Margaret A. Honein, Ph.D., M.P.H., and Lyle R. Petersen, M.D., M.P.H. Zika Virus and Birth Defects -- Reviewing the Evidence for Causality.\n\nSummary\n-------\nThe Zika virus has spread rapidly in the Americas since its 1st identification in Brazil in early 2015. Prenatal Zika virus infection has been linked to adverse pregnancy and birth outcomes, most notably microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. To determine whether Zika virus infection during pregnancy causes these adverse outcomes, we evaluated available data using criteria that have been proposed for the assessment of potential teratogens. On the basis of this review, we conclude that a causal relationship exists between prenatal Zika virus infection and microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. Evidence that was used to support this causal relationship included Zika virus infection at times during prenatal development that were consistent with the defects observed; a specific, rare phenotype involving microcephaly and associated brain anomalies in fetuses or infants with presumed or confirmed congenital Zika virus infection; and data that strongly support biologic plausibility, including the identification of Zika virus in the brain tissue of affected fetuses and infants. Given the recognition of this causal relationship, we need to intensify our efforts toward the prevention of adverse outcomes caused by congenital Zika virus infection. However, many questions that are critical to our prevention efforts remain, including the spectrum of defects caused by prenatal Zika virus infection, the degree of relative and absolute risks of adverse outcomes among fetuses whose mothers were infected at different times during pregnancy, and factors that might affect a woman's risk of adverse pregnancy or birth outcomes. Addressing these questions will improve our ability to reduce the burden of the effects of Zika virus infection during pregnancy.\n\n[Sections in the full article include:\n- Potential relationship between Zika virus infection and birth defects\n- Shepard's criteria\n- Other criteria\n- Assessment of criteria]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This paper presents an interesting counterpoint to the paper entitled \"Convicting Zika\" in the previous Zika virus: Americas update (ProMED-mail archive no. 20160411.4152933). That paper cautions that microcephaly has many causes, of which Zika is potentially just one. According to WHO, these include infection (e.g. toxoplasmosis, rubella, herpes, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and HIV), exposure to toxic agents, alcohol, genetic abnormalities, and severe malnutrition during pregnancy. However, the above NEJM paper makes a strong case for Zika virus' causality. The USA CDC agrees that Zika virus infections can cause microcephaly. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\nDate: Thu 14 Apr 2016\nSource: Euro Surveill. 21(15):pii=30199. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.15.30199 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21446\n\n\nGuzzetta G, Poletti P, Montarsi F, Baldacchino F, Capelli G, Rizzoli A, Ros\u00e0 R, Merler S. Assessing the potential risk of Zika virus epidemics in temperate areas with established Aedes albopictus populations.\n\nSummary\n-------\nBased on 2015 abundance of _Aedes albopictus_ in 9 northern Italian municipalities with temperate continental/oceanic climate, we estimated the basic reproductive number R0 for Zika virus (ZIKV) to be systematically below the epidemic threshold in most scenarios. Results were sensitive to the value of the probability of mosquito infection after biting a viraemic host. Therefore, further studies are required to improve models and predictions, namely evaluating vector competence and potential non-vector transmissions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The geographic distribution of _Ae. albopictus_ may well influence the areas that are at risk of Zika virus transmission to humans. These assessments will be difficult to quantify until the vector efficiency of this mosquito for Zika viruses in those areas is established and its feeding preferences are known. - Mod.TY]\nSee Indian Ocean", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4202525", "date": "2016-04-14 19:46:37", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS (20): AMERICAS, PACIFIC, ASIA, EUROPE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nAmericas\nMexico and Central America\n---\nMexico\nHonduras\nPanama\n\nCaribbean\n---\nCuba\nDominican Bucaramanga\n\nPacific\n---\nFiji\nKosrae\n\nAsia\n---\nChina (Guangdong province)\nViet Nam\n\nImported cases with no possibility of ongoing mosquito transmission\n---\nNew Zealand\nNorway\nSpain\nUruguay\n\nUSA:\n- Case numbers mainland\n- Territories and Commonwealth\n- Mosquito vectors\n\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nAmericas\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in the Americas mentioned below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574; North America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106; Central America and the Caribbean at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455; and South America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nMexico and Central America\n---\nMexico. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) 222 cases of whom 53 are pregnant; States reporting as of week 13 (week ending 2 Apr 2016): Chiapas 112 cases, Oaxaca 85 cases, remaining cases in Guerrero, Jalisco, Michoac\u00e1n, Nayarit, Nuevo Le\u00f3n, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Veracruz, Yucat\u00e1n.\nhttp://lopezdoriga.com/nacional/suman-222-casos-de-infeccion-por-zika-en-mexico-ssa/ [in Spanish]\n\nHonduras. 1 Apr 2016. (reported) more than 15 000 cases; 1st case of peripheral neuropathy in 14 year old girl; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 18 new cases.\nhttp://www.latribuna.hn/2016/04/01/se-reporta-primer-caso-neuropatia-sensitiva-provocado-zika/ [in Spanish]\n\nPanama. 8 Apr 2016. (reported) since November 2015, 201 cases; Microcephaly 4 cases [no mention if Zika virus infected mothers or fetuses - Mod.TY]; Locality most affected: comarca Guna Yala 115 cases.\nhttp://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/casos-microcefalia-asociadas-registrado-Panama_0_905909581.html [in Spanish]\n\nCaribbean\n---\nCuba. 13 Apr 2016. (conf.) 10 cases of which 9 cases imported ex Venezuela, 1 case locally acquired.\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-04/14/c_135276237.htm\n\n[Although these cases are imported, Cuba has vectors that are sufficient for ongoing transmission. - Mod.TY]\n\nDominican Republic. 7 Apr 2016. (susp.) 1035 cases, (conf.) 55 cases of whom 19 pregnant; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 1 fatal case with previous Zika virus infection.\nhttps://es-us.noticias.yahoo.com/dominicana-registra-2-muertes-vinculadas-con-zika-151856088.html?nhp=1 [in Spanish]\n\nMartinique. 8 Apr 2016. (susp.) medical consultations 16 650 patients; Zika virus infected pregnant women119, 2 with fetuses with microcephaly (ultrasound); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 7 cases, 6 of whom confirmed post Zika virus infection; Localities affected: all except Lorrain.\nhttp://la1ere.francetvinfo.fr/martinique/zika-1260-cas-en-une-semaine-et-une-tendance-generale-la-baisse-348220.html [in French, trans. Corr.SB]\n\nPuerto Rico. 9 Apr 2016. (conf.) 436 cases, 8 of whom hospitalized, 60 pregnant (38 symptomatic of infection, 22 asymptomatic); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 5 cases.\nhttps://twitter.com/HelenBranswell/status/718557255961022464 [in Spanish]\n\nSt. Lucia. 8 Apr 2016. (conf.) 2 cases, locally acquired, the 1st cases on the Island.\nhttp://www.enca.com/world/zika-hits-caribbean-island-st-lucia\n\nTrinidad. 31 Mar 2016. (conf.) 9 cases.\nhttps://m.facebook.com/notes/ministry-of-health-trinidad-and-tobago/update-on-zika-virus/966139170108604/\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz). 1 Apr 2016. (reported) 16 cases; No new cases recently.\nhttp://www.la-razon.com/sociedad/Aumentan-chikunguna-Santa-Cruz-semana_0_2464553599.html [in Spanish]\n\nBrazil microcephaly. 12 Apr 2016. (under investigation) for the week 2-9 Apr 2016, 3836 cases, (conf.) 1113 cases.\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/images/pdf/2016/abril/12/COES-Microcefalias---Informe-Epidemiol--gico-21--SE-14-2016--12abril2016--11h24.pdf [in Portuguese]\n\nColombia:\n- National. 9 Apr 2016. (reported) 64 839 cases of whom 11 776 are pregnant; Microcephaly 30 cases under study, no officially reported cases due to Zika virus infection; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 sybdrome 416 cases with a history of febrile disease compatible with Zika virus infection.\nhttp://www.swissinfo.ch/spa/colombia-investiga-30-casos-de-microcefalia-sospechosos-de-estar-asociados-con-zika/42078100 [in Spanish]\n\n- Bucaramanga. 14 Apr 2016. (reported) 1028 cases of whom 75 pregnant.\nhttp://caracol.com.co/emisora/2016/04/13/bucaramanga/1460582583_703064.html [in Spanish]\n\nPacific\n---\nFiji. 10 Apr 2016. (conf.) 13 cases.\nhttp://fijisun.com.fj/2016/04/10/how-to-be-proactive-when-it-comes-to-dengue-fever-chikungunya-zika-virus/\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167. - Mod.TY]\n\nKosrae, Federated States of Micronesia. 1 Apr 2016. (reports) local transmission [case numbers and dates of occurrence not given]; Travel notice issued by USA CDC.\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/cdc-issues-travel-notice-for-the-island-of-kosrae-due-to-zika-transmission-31946/\n\n[A map of the Federated States of Micronesia showing the location of Kosrae can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/fm.htm. - Mod.TY]\n\nAsia\n---\nChina (Guangdong province) 10 Apr 2016. (reported) 11 cases, several ex Venezuela.\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-04/10/c_135265628.htm\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of China can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/348. - Mod.TY]\n\nViet Nam. 5 Apr 2016. (conf.) 2 cases, one of whom pregnant; 1st cases in country; Unclear if imported or locally acquired.\nhttp://www.thanhniennews.com/health/zika-virus-spreads-to-vietnam-with-first-2-confirmed-cases-60915.html\n\n[Maps of Viet Nam can be seen at http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCountries with cases but no ongoing transmission\n---\nNew Zealand. 13 Apr 2016. (reported) 85 imported cases, 2 (conf.) new cases, one ex Venezuela.\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/news/bites/301424/two-more-zika-cases-reported-in-nz\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New Zealand can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164. - Mod.TY]\n\nNorway. 13 Apr 2016. (conf.) 12 cases of whom 5 are pregnant [all are presumed imported cases].\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-04/13/c_135275665.htm\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Norway can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/107 - Mod.TY]\n\nSpain. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) 88 cases of whom 11 are pregnant, all ex countries with active virus transmission; Localities with cases: Catalonia 28 cases, Madrid 23 cases, Castile 9 cases, Leon 9 cases, Aragon 7 cases, 3 cases each in Valencia Galicia, Andalusia, 2 cases each in Asturias, Murcia, Canaries, La Rioja and 1 in Basque country.\nhttp://www.plenglish.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4778881&Itemid=1\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Spain can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43. - Mod.TY]\n\nUruguay. 6 Apr 2016. (conf.) 1st case in the country, ex Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.\nhttp://www.prensa-latina.cu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4762611&Itemid=1 [in Spanish]\n\n[Although no ongoing transmission has been reported, Uruguay recently has had locally acquired dengue cases, indicating that the mosquito vector is present, with potential risk of local cases. Roland Hubner is thanked for sending in this report. - Mod.TY]\nhttp://www.plenglish.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4778881&Itemid=1\n\nUSA:\n- Case numbers mainland. Zika virus disease in the United States, 2015-2016 as of 13 Apr 2016\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html\nState/no. imported cases\nAlabama 2\nArizona 1\nArkansas 2\nCalifornia 29, 1 locally sexually transmitted case\nColorado 2\nConnecticut 1\nDelaware 3\nDistrict of Columbia 3\nFlorida 85\nGeorgia 11\nHawaii 5\nIllinois 10\nIndiana 6\nIowa 4\nKansas 1\nKentucky 3\nLouisiana 4\nMaine 1\nMaryland 7\nMassachusetts 7\nMichigan 2\nMinnesota 12\nMississippi 3\nMissouri 3\nMontana 1\nNebraska 2\nNevada 2\nNew Hampshire 2\nNew Jersey 8\nNew York 54\nNorth Carolina 9\nOhio 9\nOklahoma 3\nOregon 6\nPennsylvania 12\nTennessee 2\nTexas 27*\nUtah 2\nVirginia 8\nWashington 2\nWest Virginia 5\nTotal 358\n\n*One case of male to male sexual transmission in Dallas (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6514a3.htm?s_cid=mm6514a3_e)\n\n- Territories and Commonwealth\nAmerican Samoa 14 locally acquired\nPuerto Rico 3 imported 445 locally acquired\nUS Virgin Islands 1 imported, 12 locally acquired\nTotal locally acquired 471\n\n[A map of the USA showing the states mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Mosquito vectors. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) Federal health officials said in a joint conference today [11 Apr 2016] the mosquitoes species that spread the Zika virus are now in 30 states. This is more than double the 12 states they had been found previously.\nhttp://6abc.com/news/health-officials-says-mosquitos-that-spread-zika-now-in-30-states/1286128/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2016\nSource: The New England Journal of Medicine DOI: 10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 [edited]\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsr1604338?query=featured_home\n\n\nSonja A. Rasmussen, M.D., Denise J. Jamieson, M.D., M.P.H., Margaret A. Honein, Ph.D., M.P.H., and Lyle R. Petersen, M.D., M.P.H. Zika Virus and Birth Defects -- Reviewing the Evidence for Causality.\n\nSummary\n-------\nThe Zika virus has spread rapidly in the Americas since its 1st identification in Brazil in early 2015. Prenatal Zika virus infection has been linked to adverse pregnancy and birth outcomes, most notably microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. To determine whether Zika virus infection during pregnancy causes these adverse outcomes, we evaluated available data using criteria that have been proposed for the assessment of potential teratogens. On the basis of this review, we conclude that a causal relationship exists between prenatal Zika virus infection and microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. Evidence that was used to support this causal relationship included Zika virus infection at times during prenatal development that were consistent with the defects observed; a specific, rare phenotype involving microcephaly and associated brain anomalies in fetuses or infants with presumed or confirmed congenital Zika virus infection; and data that strongly support biologic plausibility, including the identification of Zika virus in the brain tissue of affected fetuses and infants. Given the recognition of this causal relationship, we need to intensify our efforts toward the prevention of adverse outcomes caused by congenital Zika virus infection. However, many questions that are critical to our prevention efforts remain, including the spectrum of defects caused by prenatal Zika virus infection, the degree of relative and absolute risks of adverse outcomes among fetuses whose mothers were infected at different times during pregnancy, and factors that might affect a woman's risk of adverse pregnancy or birth outcomes. Addressing these questions will improve our ability to reduce the burden of the effects of Zika virus infection during pregnancy.\n\n[Sections in the full article include:\n- Potential relationship between Zika virus infection and birth defects\n- Shepard's criteria\n- Other criteria\n- Assessment of criteria]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This paper presents an interesting counterpoint to the paper entitled \"Convicting Zika\" in the previous Zika virus: Americas update (ProMED-mail archive no. 20160411.4152933). That paper cautions that microcephaly has many causes, of which Zika is potentially just one. According to WHO, these include infection (e.g. toxoplasmosis, rubella, herpes, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and HIV), exposure to toxic agents, alcohol, genetic abnormalities, and severe malnutrition during pregnancy. However, the above NEJM paper makes a strong case for Zika virus' causality. The USA CDC agrees that Zika virus infections can cause microcephaly. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\nDate: Thu 14 Apr 2016\nSource: Euro Surveill. 21(15):pii=30199. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.15.30199 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21446\n\n\nGuzzetta G, Poletti P, Montarsi F, Baldacchino F, Capelli G, Rizzoli A, Ros\u00e0 R, Merler S. Assessing the potential risk of Zika virus epidemics in temperate areas with established Aedes albopictus populations.\n\nSummary\n-------\nBased on 2015 abundance of _Aedes albopictus_ in 9 northern Italian municipalities with temperate continental/oceanic climate, we estimated the basic reproductive number R0 for Zika virus (ZIKV) to be systematically below the epidemic threshold in most scenarios. Results were sensitive to the value of the probability of mosquito infection after biting a viraemic host. Therefore, further studies are required to improve models and predictions, namely evaluating vector competence and potential non-vector transmissions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The geographic distribution of _Ae. albopictus_ may well influence the areas that are at risk of Zika virus transmission to humans. These assessments will be difficult to quantify until the vector efficiency of this mosquito for Zika viruses in those areas is established and its feeding preferences are known. - Mod.TY]\nSee Roland Hubner is thanked for sending in this report. - Mod.TY]\nhttp://www.plenglish.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4778881&Itemid=1\n\nUSA:\n- Case numbers mainland. Zika virus disease in the United States, 2015-2016 as of 13 Apr 2016\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html\nState/no. imported cases\nAlabama 2\nArizona 1\nArkansas 2\nCalifornia 29, 1 locally sexually transmitted case\nColorado 2\nConnecticut 1\nDelaware 3\nDistrict of Columbia 3\nFlorida 85\nGeorgia 11\nHawaii 5\nIllinois 10\nIndiana 6\nIowa 4\nKansas 1\nKentucky 3\nLouisiana 4\nMaine 1\nMaryland 7\nMassachusetts 7\nMichigan 2\nMinnesota 12\nMississippi 3\nMissouri 3\nMontana 1\nNebraska 2\nNevada 2\nNew Hampshire 2\nNew Jersey 8\nNew York 54\nNorth Carolina 9\nOhio 9\nOklahoma 3\nOregon 6\nPennsylvania 12\nTennessee 2\nTexas 27*\nUtah 2\nVirginia 8\nWashington 2\nWest Virginia 5\nTotal 358\n\n*One case of male to male sexual transmission in Dallas (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6514a3.htm?s_cid=mm6514a3_e)\n\n- Territories and Commonwealth\nAmerican Samoa 14 locally acquired\nPuerto Rico 3 imported 445 locally acquired\nUS Virgin Islands 1 imported, 12 locally acquired\nTotal locally acquired 471\n\n[A map of the USA showing the states mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Mosquito vectors. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) Federal health officials said in a joint conference today [11 Apr 2016] the mosquitoes species that spread the Zika virus are now in 30 states. This is more than double the 12 states they had been found previously.\nhttp://6abc.com/news/health-officials-says-mosquitos-that-spread-zika-now-in-30-states/1286128/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2016\nSource: The New England Journal of Medicine DOI: 10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 [edited]\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsr1604338?query=featured_home\n\n\nSonja A. Rasmussen, M.D., Denise J. Jamieson, M.D., M.P.H., Margaret A. Honein, Ph.D., M.P.H., and Lyle R. Petersen, M.D., M.P.H. Zika Virus and Birth Defects -- Reviewing the Evidence for Causality.\n\nSummary\n-------\nThe Zika virus has spread rapidly in the Americas since its 1st identification in Brazil in early 2015. Prenatal Zika virus infection has been linked to adverse pregnancy and birth outcomes, most notably microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. To determine whether Zika virus infection during pregnancy causes these adverse outcomes, we evaluated available data using criteria that have been proposed for the assessment of potential teratogens. On the basis of this review, we conclude that a causal relationship exists between prenatal Zika virus infection and microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. Evidence that was used to support this causal relationship included Zika virus infection at times during prenatal development that were consistent with the defects observed; a specific, rare phenotype involving microcephaly and associated brain anomalies in fetuses or infants with presumed or confirmed congenital Zika virus infection; and data that strongly support biologic plausibility, including the identification of Zika virus in the brain tissue of affected fetuses and infants. Given the recognition of this causal relationship, we need to intensify our efforts toward the prevention of adverse outcomes caused by congenital Zika virus infection. However, many questions that are critical to our prevention efforts remain, including the spectrum of defects caused by prenatal Zika virus infection, the degree of relative and absolute risks of adverse outcomes among fetuses whose mothers were infected at different times during pregnancy, and factors that might affect a woman's risk of adverse pregnancy or birth outcomes. Addressing these questions will improve our ability to reduce the burden of the effects of Zika virus infection during pregnancy.\n\n[Sections in the full article include:\n- Potential relationship between Zika virus infection and birth defects\n- Shepard's criteria\n- Other criteria\n- Assessment of criteria]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This paper presents an interesting counterpoint to the paper entitled \"Convicting Zika\" in the previous Zika virus: Americas update (ProMED-mail archive no. 20160411.4152933). That paper cautions that microcephaly has many causes, of which Zika is potentially just one. According to WHO, these include infection (e.g. toxoplasmosis, rubella, herpes, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and HIV), exposure to toxic agents, alcohol, genetic abnormalities, and severe malnutrition during pregnancy. However, the above NEJM paper makes a strong case for Zika virus' causality. The USA CDC agrees that Zika virus infections can cause microcephaly. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\nDate: Thu 14 Apr 2016\nSource: Euro Surveill. 21(15):pii=30199. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.15.30199 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21446\n\n\nGuzzetta G, Poletti P, Montarsi F, Baldacchino F, Capelli G, Rizzoli A, Ros\u00e0 R, Merler S. Assessing the potential risk of Zika virus epidemics in temperate areas with established Aedes albopictus populations.\n\nSummary\n-------\nBased on 2015 abundance of _Aedes albopictus_ in 9 northern Italian municipalities with temperate continental/oceanic climate, we estimated the basic reproductive number R0 for Zika virus (ZIKV) to be systematically below the epidemic threshold in most scenarios. Results were sensitive to the value of the probability of mosquito infection after biting a viraemic host. Therefore, further studies are required to improve models and predictions, namely evaluating vector competence and potential non-vector transmissions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The geographic distribution of _Ae. albopictus_ may well influence the areas that are at risk of Zika virus transmission to humans. These assessments will be difficult to quantify until the vector efficiency of this mosquito for Zika viruses in those areas is established and its feeding preferences are known. - Mod.TY]\nSee (conf.) 1st case in the country, ex Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.\nhttp://www.prensa-latina.cu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4762611&Itemid=1 [in Spanish]\n\n[Although no ongoing transmission has been reported, Uruguay recently has had locally acquired dengue cases, indicating that the mosquito vector is present, with potential risk of local cases. Roland Hubner is thanked for sending in this report. - Mod.TY]\nhttp://www.plenglish.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4778881&Itemid=1\n\nUSA:\n- Case numbers mainland. Zika virus disease in the United States, 2015-2016 as of 13 Apr 2016\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html\nState/no. imported cases\nAlabama 2\nArizona 1\nArkansas 2\nCalifornia 29, 1 locally sexually transmitted case\nColorado 2\nConnecticut 1\nDelaware 3\nDistrict of Columbia 3\nFlorida 85\nGeorgia 11\nHawaii 5\nIllinois 10\nIndiana 6\nIowa 4\nKansas 1\nKentucky 3\nLouisiana 4\nMaine 1\nMaryland 7\nMassachusetts 7\nMichigan 2\nMinnesota 12\nMississippi 3\nMissouri 3\nMontana 1\nNebraska 2\nNevada 2\nNew Hampshire 2\nNew Jersey 8\nNew York 54\nNorth Carolina 9\nOhio 9\nOklahoma 3\nOregon 6\nPennsylvania 12\nTennessee 2\nTexas 27*\nUtah 2\nVirginia 8\nWashington 2\nWest Virginia 5\nTotal 358\n\n*One case of male to male sexual transmission in Dallas (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6514a3.htm?s_cid=mm6514a3_e)\n\n- Territories and Commonwealth\nAmerican Samoa 14 locally acquired\nPuerto Rico 3 imported 445 locally acquired\nUS Virgin Islands 1 imported, 12 locally acquired\nTotal locally acquired 471\n\n[A map of the USA showing the states mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Mosquito vectors. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) Federal health officials said in a joint conference today [11 Apr 2016] the mosquitoes species that spread the Zika virus are now in 30 states. This is more than double the 12 states they had been found previously.\nhttp://6abc.com/news/health-officials-says-mosquitos-that-spread-zika-now-in-30-states/1286128/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2016\nSource: The New England Journal of Medicine DOI: 10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 [edited]\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsr1604338?query=featured_home\n\n\nSonja A. Rasmussen, M.D., Denise J. Jamieson, M.D., M.P.H., Margaret A. Honein, Ph.D., M.P.H., and Lyle R. Petersen, M.D., M.P.H. Zika Virus and Birth Defects -- Reviewing the Evidence for Causality.\n\nSummary\n-------\nThe Zika virus has spread rapidly in the Americas since its 1st identification in Brazil in early 2015. Prenatal Zika virus infection has been linked to adverse pregnancy and birth outcomes, most notably microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. To determine whether Zika virus infection during pregnancy causes these adverse outcomes, we evaluated available data using criteria that have been proposed for the assessment of potential teratogens. On the basis of this review, we conclude that a causal relationship exists between prenatal Zika virus infection and microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. Evidence that was used to support this causal relationship included Zika virus infection at times during prenatal development that were consistent with the defects observed; a specific, rare phenotype involving microcephaly and associated brain anomalies in fetuses or infants with presumed or confirmed congenital Zika virus infection; and data that strongly support biologic plausibility, including the identification of Zika virus in the brain tissue of affected fetuses and infants. Given the recognition of this causal relationship, we need to intensify our efforts toward the prevention of adverse outcomes caused by congenital Zika virus infection. However, many questions that are critical to our prevention efforts remain, including the spectrum of defects caused by prenatal Zika virus infection, the degree of relative and absolute risks of adverse outcomes among fetuses whose mothers were infected at different times during pregnancy, and factors that might affect a woman's risk of adverse pregnancy or birth outcomes. Addressing these questions will improve our ability to reduce the burden of the effects of Zika virus infection during pregnancy.\n\n[Sections in the full article include:\n- Potential relationship between Zika virus infection and birth defects\n- Shepard's criteria\n- Other criteria\n- Assessment of criteria]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This paper presents an interesting counterpoint to the paper entitled \"Convicting Zika\" in the previous Zika virus: Americas update (ProMED-mail archive no. 20160411.4152933). That paper cautions that microcephaly has many causes, of which Zika is potentially just one. According to WHO, these include infection (e.g. toxoplasmosis, rubella, herpes, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and HIV), exposure to toxic agents, alcohol, genetic abnormalities, and severe malnutrition during pregnancy. However, the above NEJM paper makes a strong case for Zika virus' causality. The USA CDC agrees that Zika virus infections can cause microcephaly. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\nDate: Thu 14 Apr 2016\nSource: Euro Surveill. 21(15):pii=30199. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.15.30199 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21446\n\n\nGuzzetta G, Poletti P, Montarsi F, Baldacchino F, Capelli G, Rizzoli A, Ros\u00e0 R, Merler S. Assessing the potential risk of Zika virus epidemics in temperate areas with established Aedes albopictus populations.\n\nSummary\n-------\nBased on 2015 abundance of _Aedes albopictus_ in 9 northern Italian municipalities with temperate continental/oceanic climate, we estimated the basic reproductive number R0 for Zika virus (ZIKV) to be systematically below the epidemic threshold in most scenarios. Results were sensitive to the value of the probability of mosquito infection after biting a viraemic host. Therefore, further studies are required to improve models and predictions, namely evaluating vector competence and potential non-vector transmissions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The geographic distribution of _Ae. albopictus_ may well influence the areas that are at risk of Zika virus transmission to humans. These assessments will be difficult to quantify until the vector efficiency of this mosquito for Zika viruses in those areas is established and its feeding preferences are known. - Mod.TY]\nSee _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nAmericas\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in the Americas mentioned below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574; North America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106; Central America and the Caribbean at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455; and South America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nMexico and Central America\n---\nMexico. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) 222 cases of whom 53 are pregnant; States reporting as of week 13 (week ending 2 Apr 2016): Chiapas 112 cases, Oaxaca 85 cases, remaining cases in Guerrero, Jalisco, Michoac\u00e1n, Nayarit, Nuevo Le\u00f3n, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Veracruz, Yucat\u00e1n.\nhttp://lopezdoriga.com/nacional/suman-222-casos-de-infeccion-por-zika-en-mexico-ssa/ [in Spanish]\n\nHonduras. 1 Apr 2016. (reported) more than 15 000 cases; 1st case of peripheral neuropathy in 14 year old girl; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 18 new cases.\nhttp://www.latribuna.hn/2016/04/01/se-reporta-primer-caso-neuropatia-sensitiva-provocado-zika/ [in Spanish]\n\nPanama. 8 Apr 2016. (reported) since November 2015, 201 cases; Microcephaly 4 cases [no mention if Zika virus infected mothers or fetuses - Mod.TY]; Locality most affected: comarca Guna Yala 115 cases.\nhttp://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/casos-microcefalia-asociadas-registrado-Panama_0_905909581.html [in Spanish]\n\nCaribbean\n---\nCuba. 13 Apr 2016. (conf.) 10 cases of which 9 cases imported ex Venezuela, 1 case locally acquired.\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-04/14/c_135276237.htm\n\n[Although these cases are imported, Cuba has vectors that are sufficient for ongoing transmission. - Mod.TY]\n\nDominican Republic. 7 Apr 2016. (susp.) 1035 cases, (conf.) 55 cases of whom 19 pregnant; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 1 fatal case with previous Zika virus infection.\nhttps://es-us.noticias.yahoo.com/dominicana-registra-2-muertes-vinculadas-con-zika-151856088.html?nhp=1 [in Spanish]\n\nMartinique. 8 Apr 2016. (susp.) medical consultations 16 650 patients; Zika virus infected pregnant women119, 2 with fetuses with microcephaly (ultrasound); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 7 cases, 6 of whom confirmed post Zika virus infection; Localities affected: all except Lorrain.\nhttp://la1ere.francetvinfo.fr/martinique/zika-1260-cas-en-une-semaine-et-une-tendance-generale-la-baisse-348220.html [in French, trans. Corr.SB]\n\nPuerto Rico. 9 Apr 2016. (conf.) 436 cases, 8 of whom hospitalized, 60 pregnant (38 symptomatic of infection, 22 asymptomatic); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 5 cases.\nhttps://twitter.com/HelenBranswell/status/718557255961022464 [in Spanish]\n\nSt. Lucia. 8 Apr 2016. (conf.) 2 cases, locally acquired, the 1st cases on the Island.\nhttp://www.enca.com/world/zika-hits-caribbean-island-st-lucia\n\nTrinidad. 31 Mar 2016. (under investigation) for the week 2-9 Apr 2016, 3836 cases, (conf.) 1113 cases.\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/images/pdf/2016/abril/12/COES-Microcefalias---Informe-Epidemiol--gico-21--SE-14-2016--12abril2016--11h24.pdf [in Portuguese]\n\nColombia:\n- National. 9 Apr 2016. (reported) 64 839 cases of whom 11 776 are pregnant; Microcephaly 30 cases under study, no officially reported cases due to Zika virus infection; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 sybdrome 416 cases with a history of febrile disease compatible with Zika virus infection.\nhttp://www.swissinfo.ch/spa/colombia-investiga-30-casos-de-microcefalia-sospechosos-de-estar-asociados-con-zika/42078100 [in Spanish]\n\n- Bucaramanga. 14 Apr 2016. This is more than double the 12 states they had been found previously.\nhttp://6abc.com/news/health-officials-says-mosquitos-that-spread-zika-now-in-30-states/1286128/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2016\nSource: The New England Journal of Medicine DOI: 10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 [edited]\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsr1604338?query=featured_home\n\n\nSonja A. Rasmussen, M.D., Denise J. Jamieson, M.D., M.P.H., Margaret A. Honein, Ph.D., M.P.H., and Lyle R. Petersen, M.D., M.P.H. Zika Virus and Birth Defects -- Reviewing the Evidence for Causality.\n\nSummary\n-------\nThe Zika virus has spread rapidly in the Americas since its 1st identification in Brazil in early 2015. Prenatal Zika virus infection has been linked to adverse pregnancy and birth outcomes, most notably microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. To determine whether Zika virus infection during pregnancy causes these adverse outcomes, we evaluated available data using criteria that have been proposed for the assessment of potential teratogens. On the basis of this review, we conclude that a causal relationship exists between prenatal Zika virus infection and microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. Evidence that was used to support this causal relationship included Zika virus infection at times during prenatal development that were consistent with the defects observed; a specific, rare phenotype involving microcephaly and associated brain anomalies in fetuses or infants with presumed or confirmed congenital Zika virus infection; and data that strongly support biologic plausibility, including the identification of Zika virus in the brain tissue of affected fetuses and infants. Given the recognition of this causal relationship, we need to intensify our efforts toward the prevention of adverse outcomes caused by congenital Zika virus infection. However, many questions that are critical to our prevention efforts remain, including the spectrum of defects caused by prenatal Zika virus infection, the degree of relative and absolute risks of adverse outcomes among fetuses whose mothers were infected at different times during pregnancy, and factors that might affect a woman's risk of adverse pregnancy or birth outcomes. Addressing these questions will improve our ability to reduce the burden of the effects of Zika virus infection during pregnancy.\n\n[Sections in the full article include:\n- Potential relationship between Zika virus infection and birth defects\n- Shepard's criteria\n- Other criteria\n- Assessment of criteria]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This paper presents an interesting counterpoint to the paper entitled \"Convicting Zika\" in the previous Zika virus: Americas update (ProMED-mail archive no. 20160411.4152933). That paper cautions that microcephaly has many causes, of which Zika is potentially just one. According to WHO, these include infection (e.g. toxoplasmosis, rubella, herpes, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and HIV), exposure to toxic agents, alcohol, genetic abnormalities, and severe malnutrition during pregnancy. However, the above NEJM paper makes a strong case for Zika virus' causality. The USA CDC agrees that Zika virus infections can cause microcephaly. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\nDate: Thu 14 Apr 2016\nSource: Euro Surveill. 21(15):pii=30199. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.15.30199 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21446\n\n\nGuzzetta G, Poletti P, Montarsi F, Baldacchino F, Capelli G, Rizzoli A, Ros\u00e0 R, Merler S. Assessing the potential risk of Zika virus epidemics in temperate areas with established Aedes albopictus populations.\n\nSummary\n-------\nBased on 2015 abundance of _Aedes albopictus_ in 9 northern Italian municipalities with temperate continental/oceanic climate, we estimated the basic reproductive number R0 for Zika virus (ZIKV) to be systematically below the epidemic threshold in most scenarios. Results were sensitive to the value of the probability of mosquito infection after biting a viraemic host. Therefore, further studies are required to improve models and predictions, namely evaluating vector competence and potential non-vector transmissions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The geographic distribution of _Ae. albopictus_ may well influence the areas that are at risk of Zika virus transmission to humans. These assessments will be difficult to quantify until the vector efficiency of this mosquito for Zika viruses in those areas is established and its feeding preferences are known. - Mod.TY]\nSee Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nAmericas\nMexico and Central America\n---\nMexico\nHonduras\nPanama\n\nCaribbean\n---\nCuba\nDominican Europe\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nAmericas\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in the Americas mentioned below can be accessed at at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455; and South America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nMexico and Central America\n---\nMexico. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) 222 cases of whom 53 are pregnant; States reporting as of week 13 (week ending 2 Apr 2016): Chiapas 112 cases, Oaxaca 85 cases, remaining cases in Guerrero, Jalisco, Michoac\u00e1n, Nayarit, Nuevo Le\u00f3n, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Veracruz, Yucat\u00e1n.\nhttp://lopezdoriga.com/nacional/suman-222-casos-de-infeccion-por-zika-en-mexico-ssa/ [in Spanish]\n\nHonduras. 1 Apr 2016. (reported) more than 15 000 cases; 1st case of peripheral neuropathy in 14 year old girl; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 18 new cases.\nhttp://www.latribuna.hn/2016/04/01/se-reporta-primer-caso-neuropatia-sensitiva-provocado-zika/ [in Spanish]\n\nPanama. 8 Apr 2016. (reported) since November 2015, 201 cases; Microcephaly 4 cases [no mention if Zika virus infected mothers or fetuses - Mod.TY]; Locality most affected: comarca Guna Yala 115 cases.\nhttp://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/casos-microcefalia-asociadas-registrado-Panama_0_905909581.html [in Spanish]\n\nCaribbean\n---\nCuba. 13 Apr 2016. (conf.) 10 cases of which 9 cases imported ex Venezuela, 1 case locally acquired.\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-04/14/c_135276237.htm\n\n[Although these cases are imported, Cuba has vectors that are sufficient for ongoing transmission. - Mod.TY]\n\nDominican Republic. 7 Apr 2016. (susp.) 1035 cases, (conf.) 55 cases of whom 19 pregnant; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 1 fatal case with previous Zika virus infection.\nhttps://es-us.noticias.yahoo.com/dominicana-registra-2-muertes-vinculadas-con-zika-151856088.html?nhp=1 [in Spanish]\n\nMartinique. 8 Apr 2016. (susp.) medical consultations 16 650 patients; Zika virus infected pregnant women119, 2 with fetuses with microcephaly (ultrasound); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 7 cases, 6 of whom confirmed post Zika virus infection; Localities affected: all except Lorrain.\nhttp://la1ere.francetvinfo.fr/martinique/zika-1260-cas-en-une-semaine-et-une-tendance-generale-la-baisse-348220.html [in French, trans. Corr.SB]\n\nPuerto Rico. 9 Apr 2016. (conf.) 436 cases, 8 of whom hospitalized, 60 pregnant (38 symptomatic of infection, 22 asymptomatic); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 5 cases.\nhttps://twitter.com/HelenBranswell/status/718557255961022464 [in Spanish]\n\nSt. Lucia. 8 Apr 2016. (conf.) 2 cases, locally acquired, the 1st cases on the Island.\nhttp://www.enca.com/world/zika-hits-caribbean-island-st-lucia\n\nTrinidad. 31 Mar 2016. (conf.) 9 cases.\nhttps://m.facebook.com/notes/ministry-of-health-trinidad-and-tobago/update-on-zika-virus/966139170108604/\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz). 1 Apr 2016. (reported) 64 839 cases of whom 11 776 are pregnant; Microcephaly 30 cases under study, no officially reported cases due to Zika virus infection; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 sybdrome 416 cases with a history of febrile disease compatible with Zika virus infection.\nhttp://www.swissinfo.ch/spa/colombia-investiga-30-casos-de-microcefalia-sospechosos-de-estar-asociados-con-zika/42078100 [in Spanish]\n\n- Bucaramanga. 14 Apr 2016. (conf.) 1st case in the country, ex Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.\nhttp://www.prensa-latina.cu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4762611&Itemid=1 [in Spanish]\n\n[Although no ongoing transmission has been reported, Uruguay recently has had locally acquired dengue cases, indicating that the mosquito vector is present, with potential risk of local cases. Zika virus disease in the United States, 2015-2016 as of 13 Apr 2016\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html\nState/no. imported cases\nAlabama 2\nArizona 1\nArkansas 2\nCalifornia 29, 1 locally sexually transmitted case\nColorado 2\nConnecticut 1\nDelaware 3\nDistrict of Columbia 3\nFlorida 85\nGeorgia 11\nHawaii 5\nIllinois 10\nIndiana 6\nIowa 4\nKansas 1\nKentucky 3\nLouisiana 4\nMaine 1\nMaryland 7\nMassachusetts 7\nMichigan 2\nMinnesota 12\nMississippi 3\nMissouri 3\nMontana 1\nNebraska 2\nNevada 2\nNew Hampshire 2\nNew Jersey 8\nNew York 54\nNorth Carolina 9\nOhio 9\nOklahoma 3\nOregon 6\nPennsylvania 12\nTennessee 2\nTexas 27*\nUtah 2\nVirginia 8\nWashington 2\nWest Virginia 5\nTotal 358\n\n*One case of male to male sexual transmission in Dallas (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6514a3.htm?s_cid=mm6514a3_e)\n\n- Territories and Commonwealth\nAmerican Samoa 14 locally acquired\nPuerto Rico 3 imported 445 locally acquired\nUS Virgin Islands 1 imported, 12 locally acquired\nTotal locally acquired 471\n\n[A map of the USA showing the states mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Mosquito vectors. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) Federal health officials said in a joint conference today [11 Apr 2016] the mosquitoes species that spread the Zika virus are now in 30 states. This is more than double the 12 states they had been found previously.\nhttp://6abc.com/news/health-officials-says-mosquitos-that-spread-zika-now-in-30-states/1286128/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2016\nSource: The New England Journal of Medicine DOI: 10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 [edited]\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsr1604338?query=featured_home\n\n\nSonja A. Rasmussen, M.D., Denise J. Jamieson, M.D., M.P.H., Margaret A. Honein, Ph.D., M.P.H., and Lyle R. Petersen, M.D., M.P.H. Zika Virus and Birth Defects -- Reviewing the Evidence for Causality.\n\nSummary\n-------\nThe Zika virus has spread rapidly in the Americas since its 1st identification in Brazil in early 2015. Prenatal Zika virus infection has been linked to adverse pregnancy and birth outcomes, most notably microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. To determine whether Zika virus infection during pregnancy causes these adverse outcomes, we evaluated available data using criteria that have been proposed for the assessment of potential teratogens. On the basis of this review, we conclude that a causal relationship exists between prenatal Zika virus infection and microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. Evidence that was used to support this causal relationship included Zika virus infection at times during prenatal development that were consistent with the defects observed; a specific, rare phenotype involving microcephaly and associated brain anomalies in fetuses or infants with presumed or confirmed congenital Zika virus infection; and data that strongly support biologic plausibility, including the identification of Zika virus in the brain tissue of affected fetuses and infants. Given the recognition of this causal relationship, we need to intensify our efforts toward the prevention of adverse outcomes caused by congenital Zika virus infection. However, many questions that are critical to our prevention efforts remain, including the spectrum of defects caused by prenatal Zika virus infection, the degree of relative and absolute risks of adverse outcomes among fetuses whose mothers were infected at different times during pregnancy, and factors that might affect a woman's risk of adverse pregnancy or birth outcomes. Addressing these questions will improve our ability to reduce the burden of the effects of Zika virus infection during pregnancy.\n\n[Sections in the full article include:\n- Potential relationship between Zika virus infection and birth defects\n- Shepard's criteria\n- Other criteria\n- Assessment of criteria]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This paper presents an interesting counterpoint to the paper entitled \"Convicting Zika\" in the previous Zika virus: Americas update (ProMED-mail archive no. 20160411.4152933). That paper cautions that microcephaly has many causes, of which Zika is potentially just one. According to WHO, these include infection (e.g. toxoplasmosis, rubella, herpes, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and HIV), exposure to toxic agents, alcohol, genetic abnormalities, and severe malnutrition during pregnancy. However, the above NEJM paper makes a strong case for Zika virus' causality. The USA CDC agrees that Zika virus infections can cause microcephaly. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\nDate: Thu 14 Apr 2016\nSource: Euro Surveill. 21(15):pii=30199. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.15.30199 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21446\n\n\nGuzzetta G, Poletti P, Montarsi F, Baldacchino F, Capelli G, Rizzoli A, Ros\u00e0 R, Merler S. Assessing the potential risk of Zika virus epidemics in temperate areas with established Aedes albopictus populations.\n\nSummary\n-------\nBased on 2015 abundance of _Aedes albopictus_ in 9 northern Italian municipalities with temperate continental/oceanic climate, we estimated the basic reproductive number R0 for Zika virus (ZIKV) to be systematically below the epidemic threshold in most scenarios. Results were sensitive to the value of the probability of mosquito infection after biting a viraemic host. Therefore, further studies are required to improve models and predictions, namely evaluating vector competence and potential non-vector transmissions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The geographic distribution of _Ae. albopictus_ may well influence the areas that are at risk of Zika virus transmission to humans. These assessments will be difficult to quantify until the vector efficiency of this mosquito for Zika viruses in those areas is established and its feeding preferences are known. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus (19): Americas 20160411.4152933\nZika virus (18): Americas 20160402.4134955\nZika virus (17): Americas, Pacific 20160401.4129524\nZika virus (16): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Atlantic EUROPE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nAmericas\nMexico and Central America\n---\nMexico\nHonduras\nPanama\n\nCaribbean\n---\nCuba\nDominican Republic\nMartinique\nPuerto Rico\nSt. Lucia\nTrinidad\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz)\nBrazil microcephaly\nColombia:\n- National\n- Bucaramanga\n\nPacific\n---\nFiji\nKosrae\n\nAsia\n---\nChina (Guangdong province)\nViet Nam\n\nImported cases with no possibility of ongoing mosquito transmission\n---\nNew Zealand\nNorway\nSpain\nUruguay\n\nUSA:\n- Case numbers mainland\n- Territories and Commonwealth\n- Mosquito vectors\n\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nAmericas\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in the Americas mentioned below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574; North America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106; Central America and the Caribbean at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455; and South America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nMexico and Central America\n---\nMexico. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) 222 cases of whom 53 are pregnant; States reporting as of week 13 (week ending 2 Apr 2016): Chiapas 112 cases, Oaxaca 85 cases, remaining cases in Guerrero, Jalisco, Michoac\u00e1n, Nayarit, Nuevo Le\u00f3n, Sinaloa, Tabasco, Veracruz, Yucat\u00e1n.\nhttp://lopezdoriga.com/nacional/suman-222-casos-de-infeccion-por-zika-en-mexico-ssa/ [in Spanish]\n\nHonduras. 1 Apr 2016. (reported) more than 15 000 cases; 1st case of peripheral neuropathy in 14 year old girl; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 18 new cases.\nhttp://www.latribuna.hn/2016/04/01/se-reporta-primer-caso-neuropatia-sensitiva-provocado-zika/ [in Spanish]\n\nPanama. 8 Apr 2016. (reported) since November 2015, 201 cases; Microcephaly 4 cases [no mention if Zika virus infected mothers or fetuses - Mod.TY]; Locality most affected: comarca Guna Yala 115 cases.\nhttp://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/casos-microcefalia-asociadas-registrado-Panama_0_905909581.html [in Spanish]\n\nCaribbean\n---\nCuba. 13 Apr 2016. (conf.) 10 cases of which 9 cases imported ex Venezuela, 1 case locally acquired.\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-04/14/c_135276237.htm\n\n[Although these cases are imported, Cuba has vectors that are sufficient for ongoing transmission. - Mod.TY]\n\nDominican Republic. 7 Apr 2016. (susp.) 1035 cases, (conf.) 55 cases of whom 19 pregnant; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 1 fatal case with previous Zika virus infection.\nhttps://es-us.noticias.yahoo.com/dominicana-registra-2-muertes-vinculadas-con-zika-151856088.html?nhp=1 [in Spanish]\n\nMartinique. 8 Apr 2016. (susp.) medical consultations 16 650 patients; Zika virus infected pregnant women119, 2 with fetuses with microcephaly (ultrasound); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 7 cases, 6 of whom confirmed post Zika virus infection; Localities affected: all except Lorrain.\nhttp://la1ere.francetvinfo.fr/martinique/zika-1260-cas-en-une-semaine-et-une-tendance-generale-la-baisse-348220.html [in French, trans. Corr.SB]\n\nPuerto Rico. 9 Apr 2016. (conf.) 436 cases, 8 of whom hospitalized, 60 pregnant (38 symptomatic of infection, 22 asymptomatic); Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome 5 cases.\nhttps://twitter.com/HelenBranswell/status/718557255961022464 [in Spanish]\n\nSt. Lucia. 8 Apr 2016. (conf.) 2 cases, locally acquired, the 1st cases on the Island.\nhttp://www.enca.com/world/zika-hits-caribbean-island-st-lucia\n\nTrinidad. 31 Mar 2016. (conf.) 9 cases.\nhttps://m.facebook.com/notes/ministry-of-health-trinidad-and-tobago/update-on-zika-virus/966139170108604/\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz). 1 Apr 2016. (reported) 16 cases; No new cases recently.\nhttp://www.la-razon.com/sociedad/Aumentan-chikunguna-Santa-Cruz-semana_0_2464553599.html [in Spanish]\n\nBrazil microcephaly. 12 Apr 2016. (under investigation) for the week 2-9 Apr 2016, 3836 cases, (conf.) 1113 cases.\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/images/pdf/2016/abril/12/COES-Microcefalias---Informe-Epidemiol--gico-21--SE-14-2016--12abril2016--11h24.pdf [in Portuguese]\n\nColombia:\n- National. 9 Apr 2016. (reported) 64 839 cases of whom 11 776 are pregnant; Microcephaly 30 cases under study, no officially reported cases due to Zika virus infection; Guillain-Barr\u00e9 sybdrome 416 cases with a history of febrile disease compatible with Zika virus infection.\nhttp://www.swissinfo.ch/spa/colombia-investiga-30-casos-de-microcefalia-sospechosos-de-estar-asociados-con-zika/42078100 [in Spanish]\n\n- Bucaramanga. 14 Apr 2016. (reported) 1028 cases of whom 75 pregnant.\nhttp://caracol.com.co/emisora/2016/04/13/bucaramanga/1460582583_703064.html [in Spanish]\n\nPacific\n---\nFiji. 10 Apr 2016. (conf.) 13 cases.\nhttp://fijisun.com.fj/2016/04/10/how-to-be-proactive-when-it-comes-to-dengue-fever-chikungunya-zika-virus/\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167. - Mod.TY]\n\nKosrae, Federated States of Micronesia. 1 Apr 2016. (reports) local transmission [case numbers and dates of occurrence not given]; Travel notice issued by USA CDC.\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/cdc-issues-travel-notice-for-the-island-of-kosrae-due-to-zika-transmission-31946/\n\n[A map of the Federated States of Micronesia showing the location of Kosrae can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/fm.htm. - Mod.TY]\n\nAsia\n---\nChina (Guangdong province) 10 Apr 2016. (reported) 11 cases, several ex Venezuela.\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-04/10/c_135265628.htm\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of China can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/348. - Mod.TY]\n\nViet Nam. 5 Apr 2016. (conf.) 2 cases, one of whom pregnant; 1st cases in country; Unclear if imported or locally acquired.\nhttp://www.thanhniennews.com/health/zika-virus-spreads-to-vietnam-with-first-2-confirmed-cases-60915.html\n\n[Maps of Viet Nam can be seen at http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCountries with cases but no ongoing transmission\n---\nNew Zealand. 13 Apr 2016. (reported) 85 imported cases, 2 (conf.) new cases, one ex Venezuela.\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/news/bites/301424/two-more-zika-cases-reported-in-nz\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New Zealand can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164. - Mod.TY]\n\nNorway. 13 Apr 2016. (conf.) 12 cases of whom 5 are pregnant [all are presumed imported cases].\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-04/13/c_135275665.htm\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Norway can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/107 - Mod.TY]\n\nSpain. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) 88 cases of whom 11 are pregnant, all ex countries with active virus transmission; Localities with cases: Catalonia 28 cases, Madrid 23 cases, Castile 9 cases, Leon 9 cases, Aragon 7 cases, 3 cases each in Valencia Galicia, Andalusia, 2 cases each in Asturias, Murcia, Canaries, La Rioja and 1 in Basque country.\nhttp://www.plenglish.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4778881&Itemid=1\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Spain can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43. - Mod.TY]\n\nUruguay. 6 Apr 2016. (conf.) 1st case in the country, ex Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.\nhttp://www.prensa-latina.cu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4762611&Itemid=1 [in Spanish]\n\n[Although no ongoing transmission has been reported, Uruguay recently has had locally acquired dengue cases, indicating that the mosquito vector is present, with potential risk of local cases. Roland Hubner is thanked for sending in this report. - Mod.TY]\nhttp://www.plenglish.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4778881&Itemid=1\n\nUSA:\n- Case numbers mainland. Zika virus disease in the United States, 2015-2016 as of 13 Apr 2016\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html\nState/no. imported cases\nAlabama 2\nArizona 1\nArkansas 2\nCalifornia 29, 1 locally sexually transmitted case\nColorado 2\nConnecticut 1\nDelaware 3\nDistrict of Columbia 3\nFlorida 85\nGeorgia 11\nHawaii 5\nIllinois 10\nIndiana 6\nIowa 4\nKansas 1\nKentucky 3\nLouisiana 4\nMaine 1\nMaryland 7\nMassachusetts 7\nMichigan 2\nMinnesota 12\nMississippi 3\nMissouri 3\nMontana 1\nNebraska 2\nNevada 2\nNew Hampshire 2\nNew Jersey 8\nNew York 54\nNorth Carolina 9\nOhio 9\nOklahoma 3\nOregon 6\nPennsylvania 12\nTennessee 2\nTexas 27*\nUtah 2\nVirginia 8\nWashington 2\nWest Virginia 5\nTotal 358\n\n*One case of male to male sexual transmission in Dallas (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6514a3.htm?s_cid=mm6514a3_e)\n\n- Territories and Commonwealth\nAmerican Samoa 14 locally acquired\nPuerto Rico 3 imported 445 locally acquired\nUS Virgin Islands 1 imported, 12 locally acquired\nTotal locally acquired 471\n\n[A map of the USA showing the states mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Mosquito vectors. 11 Apr 2016. (reported) Federal health officials said in a joint conference today [11 Apr 2016] the mosquitoes species that spread the Zika virus are now in 30 states. This is more than double the 12 states they had been found previously.\nhttp://6abc.com/news/health-officials-says-mosquitos-that-spread-zika-now-in-30-states/1286128/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2016\nSource: The New England Journal of Medicine DOI: 10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 [edited]\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsr1604338?query=featured_home\n\n\nSonja A. Rasmussen, M.D., Denise J. Jamieson, M.D., M.P.H., Margaret A. Honein, Ph.D., M.P.H., and Lyle R. Petersen, M.D., M.P.H. Zika Virus and Birth Defects -- Reviewing the Evidence for Causality.\n\nSummary\n-------\nThe Zika virus has spread rapidly in the Americas since its 1st identification in Brazil in early 2015. Prenatal Zika virus infection has been linked to adverse pregnancy and birth outcomes, most notably microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. To determine whether Zika virus infection during pregnancy causes these adverse outcomes, we evaluated available data using criteria that have been proposed for the assessment of potential teratogens. On the basis of this review, we conclude that a causal relationship exists between prenatal Zika virus infection and microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. Evidence that was used to support this causal relationship included Zika virus infection at times during prenatal development that were consistent with the defects observed; a specific, rare phenotype involving microcephaly and associated brain anomalies in fetuses or infants with presumed or confirmed congenital Zika virus infection; and data that strongly support biologic plausibility, including the identification of Zika virus in the brain tissue of affected fetuses and infants. Given the recognition of this causal relationship, we need to intensify our efforts toward the prevention of adverse outcomes caused by congenital Zika virus infection. However, many questions that are critical to our prevention efforts remain, including the spectrum of defects caused by prenatal Zika virus infection, the degree of relative and absolute risks of adverse outcomes among fetuses whose mothers were infected at different times during pregnancy, and factors that might affect a woman's risk of adverse pregnancy or birth outcomes. Addressing these questions will improve our ability to reduce the burden of the effects of Zika virus infection during pregnancy.\n\n[Sections in the full article include:\n- Potential relationship between Zika virus infection and birth defects\n- Shepard's criteria\n- Other criteria\n- Assessment of criteria]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This paper presents an interesting counterpoint to the paper entitled \"Convicting Zika\" in the previous Zika virus: Americas update (ProMED-mail archive no. 20160411.4152933). That paper cautions that microcephaly has many causes, of which Zika is potentially just one. According to WHO, these include infection (e.g. toxoplasmosis, rubella, herpes, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and HIV), exposure to toxic agents, alcohol, genetic abnormalities, and severe malnutrition during pregnancy. However, the above NEJM paper makes a strong case for Zika virus' causality. The USA CDC agrees that Zika virus infections can cause microcephaly. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\nDate: Thu 14 Apr 2016\nSource: Euro Surveill. 21(15):pii=30199. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.15.30199 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21446\n\n\nGuzzetta G, Poletti P, Montarsi F, Baldacchino F, Capelli G, Rizzoli A, Ros\u00e0 R, Merler S. Assessing the potential risk of Zika virus epidemics in temperate areas with established Aedes albopictus populations.\n\nSummary\n-------\nBased on 2015 abundance of _Aedes albopictus_ in 9 northern Italian municipalities with temperate continental/oceanic climate, we estimated the basic reproductive number R0 for Zika virus (ZIKV) to be systematically below the epidemic threshold in most scenarios. Results were sensitive to the value of the probability of mosquito infection after biting a viraemic host. Therefore, further studies are required to improve models and predictions, namely evaluating vector competence and potential non-vector transmissions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The geographic distribution of _Ae. albopictus_ may well influence the areas that are at risk of Zika virus transmission to humans. These assessments will be difficult to quantify until the vector efficiency of this mosquito for Zika viruses in those areas is established and its feeding preferences are known. - Mod.TY]\nSee (reported) Federal health officials said in a joint conference today [11 Apr 2016] the mosquitoes species that spread the Zika virus are now in 30 states. This is more than double the 12 states they had been found previously.\nhttp://6abc.com/news/health-officials-says-mosquitos-that-spread-zika-now-in-30-states/1286128/\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Zika, birth defects, causality\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2016\nSource: The New England Journal of Medicine DOI: 10.1056/NEJMsr1604338 [edited]\nhttp://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsr1604338?query=featured_home\n\n\nSonja A. Rasmussen, M.D., Denise J. Jamieson, M.D., M.P.H., Margaret A. Honein, Ph.D., M.P.H., and Lyle R. Petersen, M.D., M.P.H. Zika Virus and Birth Defects -- Reviewing the Evidence for Causality.\n\nSummary\n-------\nThe Zika virus has spread rapidly in the Americas since its 1st identification in Brazil in early 2015. Prenatal Zika virus infection has been linked to adverse pregnancy and birth outcomes, most notably microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. To determine whether Zika virus infection during pregnancy causes these adverse outcomes, we evaluated available data using criteria that have been proposed for the assessment of potential teratogens. On the basis of this review, we conclude that a causal relationship exists between prenatal Zika virus infection and microcephaly and other serious brain anomalies. Evidence that was used to support this causal relationship included Zika virus infection at times during prenatal development that were consistent with the defects observed; a specific, rare phenotype involving microcephaly and associated brain anomalies in fetuses or infants with presumed or confirmed congenital Zika virus infection; and data that strongly support biologic plausibility, including the identification of Zika virus in the brain tissue of affected fetuses and infants. Given the recognition of this causal relationship, we need to intensify our efforts toward the prevention of adverse outcomes caused by congenital Zika virus infection. However, many questions that are critical to our prevention efforts remain, including the spectrum of defects caused by prenatal Zika virus infection, the degree of relative and absolute risks of adverse outcomes among fetuses whose mothers were infected at different times during pregnancy, and factors that might affect a woman's risk of adverse pregnancy or birth outcomes. Addressing these questions will improve our ability to reduce the burden of the effects of Zika virus infection during pregnancy.\n\n[Sections in the full article include:\n- Potential relationship between Zika virus infection and birth defects\n- Shepard's criteria\n- Other criteria\n- Assessment of criteria]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This paper presents an interesting counterpoint to the paper entitled \"Convicting Zika\" in the previous Zika virus: Americas update (ProMED-mail archive no. 20160411.4152933). That paper cautions that microcephaly has many causes, of which Zika is potentially just one. According to WHO, these include infection (e.g. toxoplasmosis, rubella, herpes, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and HIV), exposure to toxic agents, alcohol, genetic abnormalities, and severe malnutrition during pregnancy. However, the above NEJM paper makes a strong case for Zika virus' causality. The USA CDC agrees that Zika virus infections can cause microcephaly. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] _Aedes albopictus_ as vectors, Europe\nDate: Thu 14 Apr 2016\nSource: Euro Surveill. 21(15):pii=30199. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.15.30199 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21446\n\n\nGuzzetta G, Poletti P, Montarsi F, Baldacchino F, Capelli G, Rizzoli A, Ros\u00e0 R, Merler S. Assessing the potential risk of Zika virus epidemics in temperate areas with established Aedes albopictus populations.\n\nSummary\n-------\nBased on 2015 abundance of _Aedes albopictus_ in 9 northern Italian municipalities with temperate continental/oceanic climate, we estimated the basic reproductive number R0 for Zika virus (ZIKV) to be systematically below the epidemic threshold in most scenarios. Results were sensitive to the value of the probability of mosquito infection after biting a viraemic host. Therefore, further studies are required to improve models and predictions, namely evaluating vector competence and potential non-vector transmissions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The geographic distribution of _Ae. albopictus_ may well influence the areas that are at risk of Zika virus transmission to humans. These assessments will be difficult to quantify until the vector efficiency of this mosquito for Zika viruses in those areas is established and its feeding preferences are known. - Mod.TY]\nSee
