I do not know whether there have always been the large numbers of microcephalic [children] or whether the system became more sensitive by the existence of the current suspicion of Zika virus infections.\n\n--\nThiago Fructuoso\nBradesco\n<thiago.fructuoso@gmail.com>\n\n[The fundamental question is whether cases of microencephaly are occurring coincident with maternal infection with Zika virus. There seems to be no standard, fixed measurement for microencephaly. I consulted a pediatrician at a large USA medical center to clarify the criteria used to define microencephaly. He wrote: \"The definition of microcephaly is not standardized. It is sometimes defined as an occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) more than 3 standard deviations (SD) below the mean for a given age, sex, and gestation. Other times, it is defined as an OFC of more than 2 SD below the appropriate mean (that is, less than the 3rd percentile). It is important to record measurements rather than percentiles, as head circumference charts vary, especially up to the age of 3 years, and to use the most recent culturally and ethnically relevant charts to determine percentiles.\n\n\"If microcephaly is defined as a head size less than 3 SD below the appropriate mean, it is more likely to be associated with genetic and non-genetic disorders affecting brain development. In contrast, if microcephaly is defined as more than 2 SD below the mean, many intellectually normal individuals who have a head circumference at the low end of the population distribution will be included.\"\n\nProMED-mail would appreciate receiving additional information on this case. Was the daughter truly microencephalic per the criteria given above (any standard deviations from the mean for her cohort)? Was there any evidence of Zika virus persistence in the correspondent's daughter after her birth? Was Zika virus infection of the wife confirmed serologically or by presence of the virus by PCR or virus isolation?\n\nProMED-mail would be very interested in receiving information from knowledgeable sources about the other Bahia cases of microencephaly mentioned, and their relationship to maternal Zika virus infection, if any. Given the substantial increase in Zika virus infections in Brazil and now in Colombia, informed observations on occurrence of microencephaly would be of interest as well. Meanwhile, physicians attending women who have been infected with Zika virus while pregnant might be aware of this apparent association and report cases of microencephaly.\n\nPerinatal transmission of Zika virus has been observed (Besnard M, Last\u00e8re S, Teissier A, Cao-Lormeau VM, Musso D. Evidence of perinatal transmission of Zika virus, French Polynesia, December 2013 and February 2014 . Euro Surveill. 2014;19(13):pii=20751. Article DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES2014.19.13.20751, but there have been no reports of transplacental transmission earlier in gestation.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Brazil can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus - Brazil (13): (MT, AL) 20151014.3714950\nZika virus - Brazil (12): (MT) 20150921.3660532\nZika virus - Brazil (11): (AL) 20150903.3621836\nZika virus - Brazil (10): (PR) 20150830.3611318\nZika virus - Brazil (09): conf., Guatemala susp. 20150723.3531482\nZika virus - Brazil (08): 20150716.3513770\nZika virus - Brazil (07): 20150630.3473420\nZika virus - Brazil (06): (BA) 20150619.3449500\nZika virus - Brazil (05) 20150612.3431148\nZika virus - Americas: PAHO alert, country alerts, Brazil update 20150609.3422423\nZika virus - Brazil (04): (RJ): 20150608.3420363\nZika virus - Brazil (03): (RR) 20150604.3408349\nZika virus - Brazil (02): (SP) 20150524.3382529\nZika virus - Brazil: confirmed 20150519.3370768\nUndiagnosed illness - Brazil (02): Zika virus conf 20150515.3364149\nUndiagnosed illness - Brazil: (Northeast, RJ) Zika virus susp, RFI 20150501.3334749\n.................................................lm/ty/jw/ty/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "rubella", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2015-11-16 00:00:00", "2013-12-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colombia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BRAZIL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "microcephaly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guatemala", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3781280", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus - Colombia (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3781280", "date": "2015-11-06 12:28:04", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - BRAZIL (14): (BAHIA) MICROENCEPHALY SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 31 Oct 2015\nFrom: Thiago Fructuoso [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\n<thiago.fructuoso@gmail.com>\n\n\nI lived outside of Brazil for 4 years, and in March [2015], I moved to Bahia. My wife, 3-4 months pregnant, was hit by [a] Zika [virus infection], and at this time, my [fetal] daughter was diagnosed with microcephaly at the 5th [gestational] month.\n\nThe 2 ultrasonographers who we visited stated that these cases have increased a lot in their practices. Last year [2014], neither of the 2 had any cases [of microcephaly] in Bahia, and this year [2015], each have had more than 8 cases due to be born in October-November 2015. My daughter was due to be born on 5 Nov [2015].\n\nI am convinced that there is a relationship [between Zika virus infection and microencephaly] and that we are not the only ones. A number of cases in Bahia, all related to Zika [virus infections] between the 4th and 5th month of gestation, coincided with due dates for births in October and November 2015.\n\n[2 days later, the contributor added these comments:]\n\nAt the time of the examination, dengue and other diseases were all negative. Symptoms appeared at the time that there was a great Zika epidemic in the north east, leading doctors to diagnose the disease without much difficulty. We also did tests for cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, HIV, syphilis, rubella, and all were negative. I have pictures of my pregnant wife with patches on the skin characteristic of Zika.\n\nI found out that the government of Pernambuco created a page for the reporting of all cases born with microcephaly but are classifying such illnesses as an HC [head circumference] less than 33 cm, with which I do not agree. I have a friend here in Bahia and in Rio de Janeiro who had children born with an HC of 31cm and today are normal children 4 years old. I do not know whether there have always been the large numbers of microcephalic [children] or whether the system became more sensitive by the existence of the current suspicion of Zika virus infections.\n\n--\nThiago Fructuoso\nBradesco\n<thiago.fructuoso@gmail.com>\n\n[The fundamental question is whether cases of microencephaly are occurring coincident with maternal infection with Zika virus. There seems to be no standard, fixed measurement for microencephaly. I consulted a pediatrician at a large USA medical center to clarify the criteria used to define microencephaly. He wrote: \"The definition of microcephaly is not standardized. It is sometimes defined as an occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) more than 3 standard deviations (SD) below the mean for a given age, sex, and gestation. Other times, it is defined as an OFC of more than 2 SD below the appropriate mean (that is, less than the 3rd percentile). It is important to record measurements rather than percentiles, as head circumference charts vary, especially up to the age of 3 years, and to use the most recent culturally and ethnically relevant charts to determine percentiles.\n\n\"If microcephaly is defined as a head size less than 3 SD below the appropriate mean, it is more likely to be associated with genetic and non-genetic disorders affecting brain development. In contrast, if microcephaly is defined as more than 2 SD below the mean, many intellectually normal individuals who have a head circumference at the low end of the population distribution will be included.\"\n\nProMED-mail would appreciate receiving additional information on this case. Was the daughter truly microencephalic per the criteria given above (any standard deviations from the mean for her cohort)? Was there any evidence of Zika virus persistence in the correspondent's daughter after her birth? Was Zika virus infection of the wife confirmed serologically or by presence of the virus by PCR or virus isolation?\n\nProMED-mail would be very interested in receiving information from knowledgeable sources about the other Bahia cases of microencephaly mentioned, and their relationship to maternal Zika virus infection, if any. Given the substantial increase in Zika virus infections in Brazil and now in Colombia, informed observations on occurrence of microencephaly would be of interest as well. Meanwhile, physicians attending women who have been infected with Zika virus while pregnant might be aware of this apparent association and report cases of microencephaly.\n\nPerinatal transmission of Zika virus has been observed (Besnard M, Last\u00e8re S, Teissier A, Cao-Lormeau VM, Musso D. Evidence of perinatal transmission of Zika virus, French Polynesia, December 2013 and February 2014 . Euro Surveill. 2014;19(13):pii=20751. Article DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES2014.19.13.20751, but there have been no reports of transplacental transmission earlier in gestation.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Brazil can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus - Brazil (13): (MT, AL) 20151014.3714950\nZika virus - Brazil (12): (MT) 20150921.3660532\nZika virus - Brazil (11): (AL) 20150903.3621836\nZika virus - Brazil (10): (PR) 20150830.3611318\nZika virus - Brazil (09): conf., Guatemala susp. 20150723.3531482\nZika virus - Brazil (08): 20150716.3513770\nZika virus - Brazil (07): 20150630.3473420\nZika virus - Brazil (06): (BA) 20150619.3449500\nZika virus - Brazil (05) 20150612.3431148\nZika virus - Americas: PAHO alert, country alerts, Brazil update 20150609.3422423\nZika virus - Brazil (04): (RJ): 20150608.3420363\nZika virus - Brazil (03): (RR) 20150604.3408349\nZika virus - Brazil (02): (SP) 20150524.3382529\nZika virus - Brazil: confirmed 20150519.3370768\nUndiagnosed illness - Brazil (02): Zika virus conf 20150515.3364149\nUndiagnosed illness - Brazil: (Northeast, RJ) Zika virus susp, RFI 20150501.3334749\n.................................................lm/ty/jw/ty/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "rubella", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2015-11-16 00:00:00", "2013-12-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colombia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BRAZIL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "microcephaly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guatemala", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3775023", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus - Colombia (04): (AT) susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3775023", "date": "2015-11-06 12:28:04", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - BRAZIL (14): (BAHIA) MICROENCEPHALY SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 31 Oct 2015\nFrom: Thiago Fructuoso [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\n<thiago.fructuoso@gmail.com>\n\n\nI lived outside of Brazil for 4 years, and in March [2015], I moved to Bahia. My wife, 3-4 months pregnant, was hit by [a] Zika [virus infection], and at this time, my [fetal] daughter was diagnosed with microcephaly at the 5th [gestational] month.\n\nThe 2 ultrasonographers who we visited stated that these cases have increased a lot in their practices. Last year [2014], neither of the 2 had any cases [of microcephaly] in Bahia, and this year [2015], each have had more than 8 cases due to be born in October-November 2015. My daughter was due to be born on 5 Nov [2015].\n\nI am convinced that there is a relationship [between Zika virus infection and microencephaly] and that we are not the only ones. A number of cases in Bahia, all related to Zika [virus infections] between the 4th and 5th month of gestation, coincided with due dates for births in October and November 2015.\n\n[2 days later, the contributor added these comments:]\n\nAt the time of the examination, dengue and other diseases were all negative. Symptoms appeared at the time that there was a great Zika epidemic in the north east, leading doctors to diagnose the disease without much difficulty. We also did tests for cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, HIV, syphilis, rubella, and all were negative. I have pictures of my pregnant wife with patches on the skin characteristic of Zika.\n\nI found out that the government of Pernambuco created a page for the reporting of all cases born with microcephaly but are classifying such illnesses as an HC [head circumference] less than 33 cm, with which I do not agree. I have a friend here in Bahia and in Rio de Janeiro who had children born with an HC of 31cm and today are normal children 4 years old. I do not know whether there have always been the large numbers of microcephalic [children] or whether the system became more sensitive by the existence of the current suspicion of Zika virus infections.\n\n--\nThiago Fructuoso\nBradesco\n<thiago.fructuoso@gmail.com>\n\n[The fundamental question is whether cases of microencephaly are occurring coincident with maternal infection with Zika virus. There seems to be no standard, fixed measurement for microencephaly. I consulted a pediatrician at a large USA medical center to clarify the criteria used to define microencephaly. He wrote: \"The definition of microcephaly is not standardized. It is sometimes defined as an occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) more than 3 standard deviations (SD) below the mean for a given age, sex, and gestation. Other times, it is defined as an OFC of more than 2 SD below the appropriate mean (that is, less than the 3rd percentile). It is important to record measurements rather than percentiles, as head circumference charts vary, especially up to the age of 3 years, and to use the most recent culturally and ethnically relevant charts to determine percentiles.\n\n\"If microcephaly is defined as a head size less than 3 SD below the appropriate mean, it is more likely to be associated with genetic and non-genetic disorders affecting brain development. In contrast, if microcephaly is defined as more than 2 SD below the mean, many intellectually normal individuals who have a head circumference at the low end of the population distribution will be included.\"\n\nProMED-mail would appreciate receiving additional information on this case. Was the daughter truly microencephalic per the criteria given above (any standard deviations from the mean for her cohort)? Was there any evidence of Zika virus persistence in the correspondent's daughter after her birth? Was Zika virus infection of the wife confirmed serologically or by presence of the virus by PCR or virus isolation?\n\nProMED-mail would be very interested in receiving information from knowledgeable sources about the other Bahia cases of microencephaly mentioned, and their relationship to maternal Zika virus infection, if any. Given the substantial increase in Zika virus infections in Brazil and now in Colombia, informed observations on occurrence of microencephaly would be of interest as well. Meanwhile, physicians attending women who have been infected with Zika virus while pregnant might be aware of this apparent association and report cases of microencephaly.\n\nPerinatal transmission of Zika virus has been observed (Besnard M, Last\u00e8re S, Teissier A, Cao-Lormeau VM, Musso D. Evidence of perinatal transmission of Zika virus, French Polynesia, December 2013 and February 2014 . Euro Surveill. 2014;19(13):pii=20751. Article DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES2014.19.13.20751, but there have been no reports of transplacental transmission earlier in gestation.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Brazil can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Other times, it is defined as an OFC of more than 2 SD below the appropriate mean (that is, less than the 3rd percentile). We also did tests for cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, HIV, syphilis, rubella, and all were negative. I have pictures of my pregnant wife with patches on the skin characteristic of Zika.\n\nI found out that the government of Pernambuco created a page for the reporting of all cases born with microcephaly but are classifying such illnesses as an HC [head circumference] less than 33 cm, with which I do not agree. I have a friend here in Bahia and in Rio de Janeiro who had children born with an HC of 31cm and today are normal children 4 years old. I do not know whether there have always been the large numbers of microcephalic [children] or whether the system became more sensitive by the existence of the current suspicion of Zika virus infections.\n\n--\nThiago Fructuoso\nBradesco\n<thiago.fructuoso@gmail.com>\n\n[The fundamental question is whether cases of microencephaly are occurring coincident with maternal infection with Zika virus. There seems to be no standard, fixed measurement for microencephaly. I consulted a pediatrician at a large USA medical center to clarify the criteria used to define microencephaly. He wrote: \"The definition of microcephaly is not standardized. It is sometimes defined as an occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) more than 3 standard deviations (SD) below the mean for a given age, sex, and gestation. Other times, it is defined as an OFC of more than 2 SD below the appropriate mean (that is, less than the 3rd percentile). It is important to record measurements rather than percentiles, as head circumference charts vary, especially up to the age of 3 years, and to use the most recent culturally and ethnically relevant charts to determine percentiles.\n\n\"If microcephaly is defined as a head size less than 3 SD below the appropriate mean, it is more likely to be associated with genetic and non-genetic disorders affecting brain development. In contrast, if microcephaly is defined as more than 2 SD below the mean, many intellectually normal individuals who have a head circumference at the low end of the population distribution will be included.\"\n\nProMED-mail would appreciate receiving additional information on this case. Was the daughter truly microencephalic per the criteria given above (any standard deviations from the mean for her cohort)? Was there any evidence of Zika virus persistence in the correspondent's daughter after her birth? Was Zika virus infection of the wife confirmed serologically or by presence of the virus by PCR or virus isolation?\n\nProMED-mail would be very interested in receiving information from knowledgeable sources about the other Bahia cases of microencephaly mentioned, and their relationship to maternal Zika virus infection, if any. Given the substantial increase in Zika virus infections in Brazil and now in Colombia, informed observations on occurrence of microencephaly would be of interest as well. Meanwhile, physicians attending women who have been infected with Zika virus while pregnant might be aware of this apparent association and report cases of microencephaly.\n\nPerinatal transmission of Zika virus has been observed (Besnard M, Last\u00e8re S, Teissier A, Cao-Lormeau VM, Musso D. Evidence of perinatal transmission of Zika virus, French Polynesia, December 2013 and February 2014 . Euro Surveill. 2014;19(13):pii=20751. Article DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES2014.19.13.20751, but there have been no reports of transplacental transmission earlier in gestation.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Brazil can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus - Brazil (13): (MT, AL) 20151014.3714950\nZika virus - Brazil (12): (MT) 20150921.3660532\nZika virus - Brazil (11): (AL) 20150903.3621836\nZika virus - Brazil (10): (PR) 20150830.3611318\nZika virus - Brazil (09): conf., Guatemala susp. 20150723.3531482\nZika virus - Brazil (08): 20150716.3513770\nZika virus - Brazil (07): 20150630.3473420\nZika virus - Brazil (06): (BA) 20150619.3449500\nZika virus - Colombia (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3760111", "date": "2015-08-30 11:00:54", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - BRAZIL (10): (PARANA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 27 Aug 2015\nSource: G1 [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://g1.globo.com/pr/oeste-sudoeste/noticia/2015/08/governo-do-parana-confirma-segundo-caso-de-zika-virus-no-estado.html\n\n\nThe Parana Secretariat of Health (SESA) this Thursday (27 [Aug 2015]) confirmed a new case of Zika virus infection [laboratory confirmed? symptoms began and case notified when? - Mod.RNA].\n\nThe patient lives in Sao Miguel city, in the western part of the state, the same place where the 1st patient lives who had a confirmed [Zika virus] infection in July of this year [2015]. The disease causes a type of fever in infected individuals.\n\nAccording to SESA, another 2 patients in Parana also were diagnosed with a disease. One lives in Curitiba and the other in Telemaco Borba, in the central region. However, the Secretariat stated that the 2 acquired their infection outside of Parana [Where? In which state? When? - Mod.RNA], and arrived in the state presenting with the symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Confirmation of the 2nd case characterized the outbreak, which possibly may have much larger numbers of cases that were not detected and/or investigated. - Mod.RNA]\n\n[Laboratory confirmation of Zika virus infections is critical because the symptoms are sufficiently similar to those of dengue and chikungunya virus infections that making a differential diagnosis is difficult on clinical grounds alone.\n\nMaps of Brazil showing the location of Parana state can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Brazil (11): (AL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3621836", "date": "2015-08-30 11:00:54", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - BRAZIL (10): (PARANA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 27 Aug 2015\nSource: G1 [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://g1.globo.com/pr/oeste-sudoeste/noticia/2015/08/governo-do-parana-confirma-segundo-caso-de-zika-virus-no-estado.html\n\n\nThe Parana Secretariat of Health (SESA) this Thursday (27 [Aug 2015]) confirmed a new case of Zika virus infection [laboratory confirmed? symptoms began and case notified when? - Mod.RNA].\n\nThe patient lives in Sao Miguel city, in the western part of the state, the same place where the 1st patient lives who had a confirmed [Zika virus] infection in July of this year [2015]. The disease causes a type of fever in infected individuals.\n\nAccording to SESA, another 2 patients in Parana also were diagnosed with a disease. One lives in Curitiba and the other in Telemaco Borba, in the central region. However, the Secretariat stated that the 2 acquired their infection outside of Parana [Where? In which state? When? - Mod.RNA], and arrived in the state presenting with the symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Confirmation of the 2nd case characterized the outbreak, which possibly may have much larger numbers of cases that were not detected and/or investigated. - Brazil (09): conf., Guatemala susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3531482", "date": "2015-06-08 22:12:14", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - BRAZIL (04): (RIO DE JANEIRO)\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 2 Jun 2015 [ProMED regrets the delay in posting]\nSource: Globo G1 [in Portuguese, trans.JW, edited]\nhttp://g1.globo.com/rio-de-janeiro/noticia/2015/06/rj-registra-oficialmente-o-primeiro-caso-de-zika.html\n\n\nThe 1st case of Zika -- the new disease transmitted by _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes -- was recorded the weekend of [30-31 May 2015] in the state of Rio de Janeiro.\n\nAccording to the State Health Undersecretary Alexander Chieppe, the [dengue-]like symptoms hinder the proper diagnosis. \"This is a concern for us not to neglect those dengue cases that occur with greater lethality. It is important [for] clarity in diagnosis and, if in doubt, treat it as dengue,\" the Undersecretary said.\n\nThe case identified over the weekend was diagnosed through laboratory examination. \"The confirmation came on Sunday (31) [May 2015] at night, confirming the 1st Zika transmission here in the state of Rio de Janeiro. There was no history of travel and it evolved well clinically, \"said Chieppe.\n\nAccording to the [Under-]Secretary, despite the lethality not being like that of dengue, it is important to go to a health service to seek appropriate treatment. \"Treatment is supportive based on the signs and symptoms, and as it does not have the lethality of dengue, vigorous rehydration as used for dengue is not necessary\" said Chieppe.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\nhttp://www.promedmail.org/pt\n\n[In fact, in the light of current knowledge, lethality associated with Zika is not considered high. However, in a result quite similar to clinical dengue and limitations -- including possible cross-reaction in tests for detection of antibodies against dengue -- for research/ laboratory diagnosis, clinical management should be in line with the recommendations for suspected cases of dengue. - Mod.RNA\n\nCases had been reported earlier from states in Brazil`s northeast -- see ProMED archive for 1 May 2015 below.\n\nMaps of Brazil showing the location of the states mentioned can be accessed at\nhttp://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/33007. - There was no history of travel and it evolved well clinically, \"said Chieppe.\n\nAccording to the [Under-]Secretary, despite the lethality not being like that of dengue, it is important to go to a health service to seek appropriate treatment. \"Treatment is supportive based on the signs and symptoms, and as it does not have the lethality of dengue, vigorous rehydration as used for dengue is not necessary\" said Chieppe.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\nhttp://www.promedmail.org/pt\n\n[In fact, in the light of current knowledge, lethality associated with Zika is not considered high. Brazil (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3431148", "date": "2015-06-08 22:12:14", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - BRAZIL (04): (RIO DE JANEIRO)\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 2 Jun 2015 [ProMED regrets the delay in posting]\nSource: Globo G1 [in Portuguese, trans.JW, edited]\nhttp://g1.globo.com/rio-de-janeiro/noticia/2015/06/rj-registra-oficialmente-o-primeiro-caso-de-zika.html\n\n\nThe 1st case of Zika -- the new disease transmitted by _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes -- was recorded the weekend of [30-31 May 2015] in the state of Rio de Janeiro.\n\nAccording to the State Health Undersecretary Alexander Chieppe, the [dengue-]like symptoms hinder the proper diagnosis. \"This is a concern for us not to neglect those dengue cases that occur with greater lethality. It is important [for] clarity in diagnosis and, if in doubt, treat it as dengue,\" the Undersecretary said.\n\nThe case identified over the weekend was diagnosed through laboratory examination. \"The confirmation came on Sunday (31) [May 2015] at night, confirming the 1st Zika transmission here in the state of Rio de Janeiro. There was no history of travel and it evolved well clinically, \"said Chieppe.\n\nAccording to the [Under-]Secretary, despite the lethality not being like that of dengue, it is important to go to a health service to seek appropriate treatment. \"Treatment is supportive based on the signs and symptoms, and as it does not have the lethality of dengue, vigorous rehydration as used for dengue is not necessary\" said Chieppe.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\nhttp://www.promedmail.org/pt\n\n[In fact, in the light of current knowledge, lethality associated with Zika is not considered high. However, in a result quite similar to clinical dengue and limitations -- including possible cross-reaction in tests for detection of antibodies against dengue -- for research/ laboratory diagnosis, clinical management should be in line with the recommendations for suspected cases of dengue. - Mod.RNA\n\nCases had been reported earlier from states in Brazil`s northeast -- see ProMED archive for 1 May 2015 below.\n\nMaps of Brazil showing the location of the states mentioned can be accessed at\nhttp://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/33007. - It is important [for] clarity in diagnosis and, if in doubt, treat it as dengue,\" the Undersecretary said.\n\nThe case identified over the weekend was diagnosed through laboratory examination. \"The confirmation came on Sunday (31) [May 2015] at night, confirming the 1st Zika transmission here in the state of Rio de Janeiro. There was no history of travel and it evolved well clinically, \"said Chieppe.\n\nAccording to the [Under-]Secretary, despite the lethality not being like that of dengue, it is important to go to a health service to seek appropriate treatment. \"Treatment is supportive based on the signs and symptoms, and as it does not have the lethality of dengue, vigorous rehydration as used for dengue is not necessary\" said Chieppe.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\nhttp://www.promedmail.org/pt\n\n[In fact, in the light of current knowledge, lethality associated with Zika is not considered high. However, in a result quite similar to clinical dengue and limitations -- including possible cross-reaction in tests for detection of antibodies against dengue -- for research/ laboratory diagnosis, clinical management should be in line with the recommendations for suspected cases of dengue. - Mod.RNA\n\nCases had been reported earlier from states in Brazil`s northeast -- see ProMED archive for 1 May 2015 below.\n\nMaps of Brazil showing the location of the states mentioned can be accessed at\nhttp://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/33007. - Germany ex Malaysia 20150517.3367412\nZika virus: possible sexual transmission 20150516.3367156\nUndiagnosed illness - Brazil (02): Zika virus conf 20150515.3364149\nUndiagnosed illness - Brazil: (Northeast, RJ) Zika virus susp, RFI 20150501.3334749\nZika virus - Pacific: Vanuatu 20150501.3334549\n2014\n----\nDengue, chikungunya, Zika viruses - Pacific 20141016.2870853\nZika virus - Pacific (15): Chile (Easter Island) ex Tahiti 20140925.2804821\nZika virus - Pacific (14): New Zealand ex Cook Islands, comment 20140912.2769285\nand earlier\n.................................................jw/pg/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2015-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2015-05-16 00:00:00", "2015-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BRAZIL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "under-]secretary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3412519", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Zika virus - Dominican Republic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3412519", "date": "2015-05-01 10:36:31", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - BRAZIL: (NORTHEAST, RIO DE JANEIRO) ZIKA VIRUS SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\n\n******\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\nDate: Wed 29 Apr 2015\nSource: Secretariat of Health Surveillance, Ministry of Health of Brazil [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/index.php/o-ministerio/principal/secretarias/svs/noticias-svs/17524-svs-monitora-casos-de-doenca-exantematica-no-nordeste\n\n\nSVS (Secretariat of Health Surveillance) monitors cases of rash illness in the Northeast\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nSVS communicates that since the end of February [2015] it has been monitoring reported cases of a rash illness in the Northeast. According to reports shared by the Health Departments of the states of Bahia, Maranhao, Pernambuco, Rio Grande do Norte, Paraiba, and Sergipe, all cases have a benign course with spontaneous recovery, even without treatment. According to information passed to the Ministry of Health, 6807 cases of rash illness so far have been identified in the region. It is noteworthy that there have been no serious cases or deaths.\n\nThe most common signs and symptoms are rash (red spots) and pruritus (itching). To a lesser extent, cases with low-grade fever or no fever, with or without headache, pain or swelling in the joints, and muscle pain. The age group 20-40 years was the most affected. But there are reports of a patients 4 months old and another 98 years old.\n\nAccording to the clinical features, the main assumptions in the investigations are: dengue, rubella, parvovirus B19, chikungunya, and measles, and other arboviruses and enteroviruses. So far, among 425 samples collected and tested, approximately 13 percent were positive for dengue. However, the clinical features available for now are not only characteristic of dengue cases. However, some samples tested for measles, rubella, chikungunya, and parvovirus were negative.\n\nIn order to identify the causative agent of this rash illness and to propose appropriate prevention and control measures, the SVS is conducting field investigations in collaboration with the Health Departments of Maranhao, Rio Grande do Norte, and Paraiba. In these investigations, they are including clinical aspects of patients and collecting samples, principally blood, which will be forwarded to the state and national reference laboratories.\n\nSimultaneously, all health surveillances states and Northeast municipalities continue investigating and monitoring cases. The SVS and the Health Departments of the states of Alagoas, Bahia, Ceara, Maranhao, Paraiba, Piaui, Rio Grande do Norte, and Sergipe are conducting systematic monitoring through the Strategic Information Centres of Health Surveillance (CIEVS).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\nData: Mon 13 Apr 2015\nSource: Globo [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://g1.globo.com/rj/sul-do-rio-costa-verde/noticia/2015/04/surto-de-alergia-atinge-moradores-de-pinheiral-rj-diz-vigilancia-de-saude.html\n\n\nAllergy outbreak reaches residents of Pinheiral, RJ [Rio de Janeiro], says Health Surveillance\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nPinheiral residents in southern Rio de Janeiro state are facing an allergy outbreak. For the past 30 days, hundreds were treated at municipal First Aid post with similar symptoms. \"An average 250 to 300 visits a day, most with joint pain, pain behind the eyes, fever, and itching, a rash on the body,\" explained Dr Erica Quintal Teixeira Fernandes [at present, dengue would be the most likely case. - Mod.RNA]\n\nIt happened with a merchant who 3 weeks ago began to feel discomfort [what type of discomfort? - Mod.RNA], followed by itching in the legs. Small bubbles and then spots began to appear [on his body], and the malaise worsened. After consulting the medical unit, he was treated for allergy and the itching decreased, but the marks on the body continued. Days later, his sons also went through the same problem. \"We had headache, dizziness, shortness of breath, and vomiting,\" they said.\n\nAccording to Health Surveillance, the prime suspect is that this is a new mutation of the dengue virus [based on what evidence? - Mod.RNA]. \"With the investigations which the surveillance performs in relation to the symptoms, we can guarantee that 70 percent of these cases are dengue [confirmed by laboratory testing? And the other 30 percent? - Mod.RNA],\" said Adriane Garcia da Rosa.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are, at the very least, worrying statements/speculations like \"a new mutation of the dengue virus,\" used to attribute to dengue events/cases that perhaps are not even being investigated and (laboratory confirmed or discounted) systematically.\n\nInvestigations conducted by the Departments of Health of the states and the Ministry of Health are essential for elucidating and understanding the outbreaks that have been described.\n\nUse of standardized case definitions and research lab protocols (sample collection and laboratory analysis) is mandatory, especially now that Zika virus has been announced as having been confirmed by a research laboratory (see below).\n\nQuestion: Would the Zika virus be the \"only\" agent to be implicated in the cases/outbreaks that have been reported in the Northeast? Would it be circulating in (and infecting) other states? Let's keep our eyes open. - Mod.RNA\n\nSince 8 Feb 2015 ProMED-PORT has posted reports in Portuguese of hundreds of cases of fever with rash and joint pains in several northeastern states of Brazil: Bahia, Maranhao, Paraiba, Pernambuco and Piaui (see map at\nhttp://viajerobrasil.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/mapa-brasil-2-839x735.jpg\n\nNow a Brazilian research group has reported identifying the cause as the mosquito-borne Zika virus:\nSource: Globo (in Portuguese)\nhttp://g1.globo.com/bahia/noticia/2015/04/identificado-virus-causador-de-doenca-misteriosa-em-salvador-e-rms.html.\n\nOther mosquito-borne viruses with similar symptoms such as dengue and chikungunya were excluded previously. They identified the virus by the PCR test, which detects signature portions of viral RNA. But Zika virus belongs to the group known as flaviviruses, which are notorious among virologists for their cross-reactions in lab tests. Until the actual virus is isolated, we cannot be certain it is not a totally new agent of the flavivirus group.\n\nZika seems unlikely, because it up to now it has only been detected in Africa, Asia, and the Pacific. One suggestion is that it was imported by a football fan incubating it who was visiting Brazil for the World Cup. But the cup final was in mid-July 2014 -- where could the virus have been hiding since then? Until its identity is confirmed, this is all speculation. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nDengue, chikungunya, Zika viruses - Pacific 20141016.2870853\nZika virus - Pacific (15): Easter Island ex Tahiti 20140925.2804821\nZika virus - New Zealand ex Cook Islands, comment 20140912.2769285\nZika virus - Japan ex Thailand (02): comment 20140826.2725061\nZika virus - Pacific (12): French Polynesia, donated blood 20140411.2397091\nZika virus - Pacific (10): Australia ex Cook Islands 20140403.2378034\nZika virus - Africa: Gabon 20140216.2280898\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): alert 20140210.2268533\n2013\n----\nZika virus - Germany ex Thailand 20131227.2139786\nZika virus - Japan: ex French Polynesia 20131219.2126046\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): ex French Polynesia 20131203.2089681\nZika virus - Canada ex Thailand 20130529.1744108\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................rna/jw/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "measles", "rubella", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-02-08 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alagoas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ceara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Grande", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maranhao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3408349", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Zika virus - Brazil (03): (RR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3408349", "date": "2015-05-01 10:36:31", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - BRAZIL: (NORTHEAST, RIO DE JANEIRO) ZIKA VIRUS SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\n\n******\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\nDate: Wed 29 Apr 2015\nSource: Secretariat of Health Surveillance, Ministry of Health of Brazil [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/index.php/o-ministerio/principal/secretarias/svs/noticias-svs/17524-svs-monitora-casos-de-doenca-exantematica-no-nordeste\n\n\nSVS (Secretariat of Health Surveillance) monitors cases of rash illness in the Northeast\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nSVS communicates that since the end of February [2015] it has been monitoring reported cases of a rash illness in the Northeast. According to reports shared by the Health Departments of the states of Bahia, Maranhao, Pernambuco, Rio Grande do Norte, Paraiba, and Sergipe, all cases have a benign course with spontaneous recovery, even without treatment. According to information passed to the Ministry of Health, 6807 cases of rash illness so far have been identified in the region. It is noteworthy that there have been no serious cases or deaths.\n\nThe most common signs and symptoms are rash (red spots) and pruritus (itching). To a lesser extent, cases with low-grade fever or no fever, with or without headache, pain or swelling in the joints, and muscle pain. The age group 20-40 years was the most affected. But there are reports of a patients 4 months old and another 98 years old.\n\nAccording to the clinical features, the main assumptions in the investigations are: dengue, rubella, parvovirus B19, chikungunya, and measles, and other arboviruses and enteroviruses. So far, among 425 samples collected and tested, approximately 13 percent were positive for dengue. However, the clinical features available for now are not only characteristic of dengue cases. However, some samples tested for measles, rubella, chikungunya, and parvovirus were negative.\n\nIn order to identify the causative agent of this rash illness and to propose appropriate prevention and control measures, the SVS is conducting field investigations in collaboration with the Health Departments of Maranhao, Rio Grande do Norte, and Paraiba. In these investigations, they are including clinical aspects of patients and collecting samples, principally blood, which will be forwarded to the state and national reference laboratories.\n\nSimultaneously, all health surveillances states and Northeast municipalities continue investigating and monitoring cases. The SVS and the Health Departments of the states of Alagoas, Bahia, Ceara, Maranhao, Paraiba, Piaui, Rio Grande do Norte, and Sergipe are conducting systematic monitoring through the Strategic Information Centres of Health Surveillance (CIEVS).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\nData: Mon 13 Apr 2015\nSource: Globo [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://g1.globo.com/rj/sul-do-rio-costa-verde/noticia/2015/04/surto-de-alergia-atinge-moradores-de-pinheiral-rj-diz-vigilancia-de-saude.html\n\n\nAllergy outbreak reaches residents of Pinheiral, RJ [Rio de Janeiro], says Health Surveillance\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nPinheiral residents in southern Rio de Janeiro state are facing an allergy outbreak. For the past 30 days, hundreds were treated at municipal First Aid post with similar symptoms. \"An average 250 to 300 visits a day, most with joint pain, pain behind the eyes, fever, and itching, a rash on the body,\" explained Dr Erica Quintal Teixeira Fernandes [at present, dengue would be the most likely case. - Mod.RNA]\n\nIt happened with a merchant who 3 weeks ago began to feel discomfort [what type of discomfort? - Mod.RNA], followed by itching in the legs. Small bubbles and then spots began to appear [on his body], and the malaise worsened. After consulting the medical unit, he was treated for allergy and the itching decreased, but the marks on the body continued. Days later, his sons also went through the same problem. \"We had headache, dizziness, shortness of breath, and vomiting,\" they said.\n\nAccording to Health Surveillance, the prime suspect is that this is a new mutation of the dengue virus [based on what evidence? - Mod.RNA]. \"With the investigations which the surveillance performs in relation to the symptoms, we can guarantee that 70 percent of these cases are dengue [confirmed by laboratory testing? And the other 30 percent? - Mod.RNA],\" said Adriane Garcia da Rosa.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are, at the very least, worrying statements/speculations like \"a new mutation of the dengue virus,\" used to attribute to dengue events/cases that perhaps are not even being investigated and (laboratory confirmed or discounted) systematically.\n\nInvestigations conducted by the Departments of Health of the states and the Ministry of Health are essential for elucidating and understanding the outbreaks that have been described.\n\nUse of standardized case definitions and research lab protocols (sample collection and laboratory analysis) is mandatory, especially now that Zika virus has been announced as having been confirmed by a research laboratory (see below).\n\nQuestion: Would the Zika virus be the \"only\" agent to be implicated in the cases/outbreaks that have been reported in the Northeast? Would it be circulating in (and infecting) other states? Let's keep our eyes open. - Mod.RNA\n\nSince 8 Feb 2015 ProMED-PORT has posted reports in Portuguese of hundreds of cases of fever with rash and joint pains in several northeastern states of Brazil: Bahia, Maranhao, Paraiba, Pernambuco and Piaui (see map at\nhttp://viajerobrasil.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/mapa-brasil-2-839x735.jpg\n\nNow a Brazilian research group has reported identifying the cause as the mosquito-borne Zika virus:\nSource: Globo (in Portuguese)\nhttp://g1.globo.com/bahia/noticia/2015/04/identificado-virus-causador-de-doenca-misteriosa-em-salvador-e-rms.html.\n\nOther mosquito-borne viruses with similar symptoms such as dengue and chikungunya were excluded previously. They identified the virus by the PCR test, which detects signature portions of viral RNA. But Zika virus belongs to the group known as flaviviruses, which are notorious among virologists for their cross-reactions in lab tests. Until the actual virus is isolated, we cannot be certain it is not a totally new agent of the flavivirus group.\n\nZika seems unlikely, because it up to now it has only been detected in Africa, Asia, and the Pacific. One suggestion is that it was imported by a football fan incubating it who was visiting Brazil for the World Cup. But the cup final was in mid-July 2014 -- where could the virus have been hiding since then? Until its identity is confirmed, this is all speculation. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nDengue, chikungunya, Zika viruses - Pacific 20141016.2870853\nZika virus - Pacific (15): Easter Island ex Tahiti 20140925.2804821\nZika virus - New Zealand ex Cook Islands, comment 20140912.2769285\nZika virus - Japan ex Thailand (02): comment 20140826.2725061\nZika virus - Pacific (12): French Polynesia, donated blood 20140411.2397091\nZika virus - Pacific (10): Australia ex Cook Islands 20140403.2378034\nZika virus - Africa: Gabon 20140216.2280898\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): alert 20140210.2268533\n2013\n----\nZika virus - Brazil: confirmed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3370768", "date": "2015-05-01 10:36:31", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - BRAZIL: (NORTHEAST, RIO DE JANEIRO) ZIKA VIRUS SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\n\n******\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\nDate: Wed 29 Apr 2015\nSource: Secretariat of Health Surveillance, Ministry of Health of Brazil [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/index.php/o-ministerio/principal/secretarias/svs/noticias-svs/17524-svs-monitora-casos-de-doenca-exantematica-no-nordeste\n\n\nSVS (Secretariat of Health Surveillance) monitors cases of rash illness in the Northeast\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nSVS communicates that since the end of February [2015] it has been monitoring reported cases of a rash illness in the Northeast. According to reports shared by the Health Departments of the states of Bahia, Maranhao, Pernambuco, Rio Grande do Norte, Paraiba, and Sergipe, all cases have a benign course with spontaneous recovery, even without treatment. According to information passed to the Ministry of Health, 6807 cases of rash illness so far have been identified in the region. It is noteworthy that there have been no serious cases or deaths.\n\nThe most common signs and symptoms are rash (red spots) and pruritus (itching). To a lesser extent, cases with low-grade fever or no fever, with or without headache, pain or swelling in the joints, and muscle pain. The age group 20-40 years was the most affected. But there are reports of a patients 4 months old and another 98 years old.\n\nAccording to the clinical features, the main assumptions in the investigations are: dengue, rubella, parvovirus B19, chikungunya, and measles, and other arboviruses and enteroviruses. So far, among 425 samples collected and tested, approximately 13 percent were positive for dengue. However, the clinical features available for now are not only characteristic of dengue cases. However, some samples tested for measles, rubella, chikungunya, and parvovirus were negative.\n\nIn order to identify the causative agent of this rash illness and to propose appropriate prevention and control measures, the SVS is conducting field investigations in collaboration with the Health Departments of Maranhao, Rio Grande do Norte, and Paraiba. In these investigations, they are including clinical aspects of patients and collecting samples, principally blood, which will be forwarded to the state and national reference laboratories.\n\nSimultaneously, all health surveillances states and Northeast municipalities continue investigating and monitoring cases. The SVS and the Health Departments of the states of Alagoas, Bahia, Ceara, Maranhao, Paraiba, Piaui, Rio Grande do Norte, and Sergipe are conducting systematic monitoring through the Strategic Information Centres of Health Surveillance (CIEVS).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\nData: Mon 13 Apr 2015\nSource: Globo [in Portuguese, trans. Until its identity is confirmed, this is all speculation. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nDengue, chikungunya, Zika viruses - Pacific 20141016.2870853\nZika virus - Pacific (15): Easter Island ex Tahiti 20140925.2804821\nZika virus - New Zealand ex Cook Islands, comment 20140912.2769285\nZika virus - Japan ex Thailand (02): comment 20140826.2725061\nZika virus - Pacific (12): French Polynesia, donated blood 20140411.2397091\nZika virus - Pacific (10): Australia ex Cook Islands 20140403.2378034\nZika virus - Africa: Gabon 20140216.2280898\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): alert 20140210.2268533\n2013\n----\nZika virus - Germany ex Thailand 20131227.2139786\nZika virus - Japan: ex French Polynesia 20131219.2126046\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): ex French Polynesia 20131203.2089681\nZika virus - Canada ex Thailand 20130529.1744108\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................rna/jw/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "measles", "rubella", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-02-08 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alagoas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ceara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Grande", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maranhao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3367412", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Zika virus, 2014 - Germany ex Malaysia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3367412", "date": "2015-05-01 10:36:31", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - BRAZIL: (NORTHEAST, RIO DE JANEIRO) ZIKA VIRUS SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\n\n******\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\nDate: Wed 29 Apr 2015\nSource: Secretariat of Health Surveillance, Ministry of Health of Brazil [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/index.php/o-ministerio/principal/secretarias/svs/noticias-svs/17524-svs-monitora-casos-de-doenca-exantematica-no-nordeste\n\n\nSVS (Secretariat of Health Surveillance) monitors cases of rash illness in the Northeast\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nSVS communicates that since the end of February [2015] it has been monitoring reported cases of a rash illness in the Northeast. According to reports shared by the Health Departments of the states of Bahia, Maranhao, Pernambuco, Rio Grande do Norte, Paraiba, and Sergipe, all cases have a benign course with spontaneous recovery, even without treatment. According to information passed to the Ministry of Health, 6807 cases of rash illness so far have been identified in the region. It is noteworthy that there have been no serious cases or deaths.\n\nThe most common signs and symptoms are rash (red spots) and pruritus (itching). To a lesser extent, cases with low-grade fever or no fever, with or without headache, pain or swelling in the joints, and muscle pain. The age group 20-40 years was the most affected. But there are reports of a patients 4 months old and another 98 years old.\n\nAccording to the clinical features, the main assumptions in the investigations are: dengue, rubella, parvovirus B19, chikungunya, and measles, and other arboviruses and enteroviruses. So far, among 425 samples collected and tested, approximately 13 percent were positive for dengue. However, the clinical features available for now are not only characteristic of dengue cases. However, some samples tested for measles, rubella, chikungunya, and parvovirus were negative.\n\nIn order to identify the causative agent of this rash illness and to propose appropriate prevention and control measures, the SVS is conducting field investigations in collaboration with the Health Departments of Maranhao, Rio Grande do Norte, and Paraiba. In these investigations, they are including clinical aspects of patients and collecting samples, principally blood, which will be forwarded to the state and national reference laboratories.\n\nSimultaneously, all health surveillances states and Northeast municipalities continue investigating and monitoring cases. The SVS and the Health Departments of the states of Alagoas, Bahia, Ceara, Maranhao, Paraiba, Piaui, Rio Grande do Norte, and Sergipe are conducting systematic monitoring through the Strategic Information Centres of Health Surveillance (CIEVS).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\nData: Mon 13 Apr 2015\nSource: Globo [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://g1.globo.com/rj/sul-do-rio-costa-verde/noticia/2015/04/surto-de-alergia-atinge-moradores-de-pinheiral-rj-diz-vigilancia-de-saude.html\n\n\nAllergy outbreak reaches residents of Pinheiral, RJ [Rio de Janeiro], says Health Surveillance\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nPinheiral residents in southern Rio de Janeiro state are facing an allergy outbreak. For the past 30 days, hundreds were treated at municipal First Aid post with similar symptoms. \"An average 250 to 300 visits a day, most with joint pain, pain behind the eyes, fever, and itching, a rash on the body,\" explained Dr Erica Quintal Teixeira Fernandes [at present, dengue would be the most likely case. - Mod.RNA]\n\nIt happened with a merchant who 3 weeks ago began to feel discomfort [what type of discomfort? - Mod.RNA], followed by itching in the legs. Small bubbles and then spots began to appear [on his body], and the malaise worsened. After consulting the medical unit, he was treated for allergy and the itching decreased, but the marks on the body continued. Days later, his sons also went through the same problem. \"We had headache, dizziness, shortness of breath, and vomiting,\" they said.\n\nAccording to Health Surveillance, the prime suspect is that this is a new mutation of the dengue virus [based on what evidence? - Mod.RNA]. \"With the investigations which the surveillance performs in relation to the symptoms, we can guarantee that 70 percent of these cases are dengue [confirmed by laboratory testing? And the other 30 percent? - Mod.RNA],\" said Adriane Garcia da Rosa.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are, at the very least, worrying statements/speculations like \"a new mutation of the dengue virus,\" used to attribute to dengue events/cases that perhaps are not even being investigated and (laboratory confirmed or discounted) systematically.\n\nInvestigations conducted by the Departments of Health of the states and the Ministry of Health are essential for elucidating and understanding the outbreaks that have been described.\n\nUse of standardized case definitions and research lab protocols (sample collection and laboratory analysis) is mandatory, especially now that Zika virus has been announced as having been confirmed by a research laboratory (see below).\n\nQuestion: Would the Zika virus be the \"only\" agent to be implicated in the cases/outbreaks that have been reported in the Northeast? Would it be circulating in (and infecting) other states? Let's keep our eyes open. - Mod.RNA\n\nSince 8 Feb 2015 ProMED-PORT has posted reports in Portuguese of hundreds of cases of fever with rash and joint pains in several northeastern states of Brazil: Bahia, Maranhao, Paraiba, Pernambuco and Piaui (see map at\nhttp://viajerobrasil.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/mapa-brasil-2-839x735.jpg\n\nNow a Brazilian research group has reported identifying the cause as the mosquito-borne Zika virus:\nSource: Globo (in Portuguese)\nhttp://g1.globo.com/bahia/noticia/2015/04/identificado-virus-causador-de-doenca-misteriosa-em-salvador-e-rms.html.\n\nOther mosquito-borne viruses with similar symptoms such as dengue and chikungunya were excluded previously. They identified the virus by the PCR test, which detects signature portions of viral RNA. But Zika virus belongs to the group known as flaviviruses, which are notorious among virologists for their cross-reactions in lab tests. Until the actual virus is isolated, we cannot be certain it is not a totally new agent of the flavivirus group.\n\nZika seems unlikely, because it up to now it has only been detected in Africa, Asia, and the Pacific. One suggestion is that it was imported by a football fan incubating it who was visiting Brazil for the World Cup. But the cup final was in mid-July 2014 -- where could the virus have been hiding since then? Until its identity is confirmed, this is all speculation. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nDengue, chikungunya, Zika viruses - Pacific 20141016.2870853\nZika virus - Pacific (15): Easter Island ex Tahiti 20140925.2804821\nZika virus - New Zealand ex Cook Islands, comment 20140912.2769285\nZika virus - Japan ex Thailand (02): comment 20140826.2725061\nZika virus - Pacific (12): French Polynesia, donated blood 20140411.2397091\nZika virus - Pacific (10): Australia ex Cook Islands 20140403.2378034\nZika virus - Africa: Gabon 20140216.2280898\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): alert 20140210.2268533\n2013\n----\nZika virus - Brazil (02): Zika virus conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3364149", "date": "2015-05-01 10:36:31", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - BRAZIL: (NORTHEAST, RIO DE JANEIRO) ZIKA VIRUS SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\n\n******\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\nDate: Wed 29 Apr 2015\nSource: Secretariat of Health Surveillance, Ministry of Health of Brazil [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/index.php/o-ministerio/principal/secretarias/svs/noticias-svs/17524-svs-monitora-casos-de-doenca-exantematica-no-nordeste\n\n\nSVS (Secretariat of Health Surveillance) monitors cases of rash illness in the Northeast\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nSVS communicates that since the end of February [2015] it has been monitoring reported cases of a rash illness in the Northeast.
