But the cup final was in mid-July 2014 -- where could the virus have been hiding since then? Until its identity is confirmed, this is all speculation. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nDengue, chikungunya, Zika viruses - Pacific 20141016.2870853\nZika virus - Pacific (15): Easter Island ex Tahiti 20140925.2804821\nZika virus - New Zealand ex Cook Islands, comment 20140912.2769285\nZika virus - Japan ex Thailand (02): comment 20140826.2725061\nZika virus - Pacific (12): French Polynesia, donated blood 20140411.2397091\nZika virus - Pacific (10): Australia ex Cook Islands 20140403.2378034\nZika virus - Africa: Gabon 20140216.2280898\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): alert 20140210.2268533\n2013\n----\nZika virus - Germany ex Thailand 20131227.2139786\nZika virus - Japan: ex French Polynesia 20131219.2126046\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): ex French Polynesia 20131203.2089681\nZika virus - Canada ex Thailand 20130529.1744108\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................rna/jw/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "measles", "rubella", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-02-08 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alagoas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ceara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Grande", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maranhao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3334749", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed illness - Brazil: (Northeast, RJ) Zika virus susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3334749", "date": "2015-05-01 10:36:31", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - BRAZIL: (NORTHEAST, RIO DE JANEIRO) ZIKA VIRUS SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\n\n******\n[1] Brazil: (Northeast) official information\nDate: Wed 29 Apr 2015\nSource: Secretariat of Health Surveillance, Ministry of Health of Brazil [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://portalsaude.saude.gov.br/index.php/o-ministerio/principal/secretarias/svs/noticias-svs/17524-svs-monitora-casos-de-doenca-exantematica-no-nordeste\n\n\nSVS (Secretariat of Health Surveillance) monitors cases of rash illness in the Northeast\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nSVS communicates that since the end of February [2015] it has been monitoring reported cases of a rash illness in the Northeast. According to reports shared by the Health Departments of the states of Bahia, Maranhao, Pernambuco, Rio Grande do Norte, Paraiba, and Sergipe, all cases have a benign course with spontaneous recovery, even without treatment. According to information passed to the Ministry of Health, 6807 cases of rash illness so far have been identified in the region. It is noteworthy that there have been no serious cases or deaths.\n\nThe most common signs and symptoms are rash (red spots) and pruritus (itching). To a lesser extent, cases with low-grade fever or no fever, with or without headache, pain or swelling in the joints, and muscle pain. The age group 20-40 years was the most affected. But there are reports of a patients 4 months old and another 98 years old.\n\nAccording to the clinical features, the main assumptions in the investigations are: dengue, rubella, parvovirus B19, chikungunya, and measles, and other arboviruses and enteroviruses. So far, among 425 samples collected and tested, approximately 13 percent were positive for dengue. However, the clinical features available for now are not only characteristic of dengue cases. However, some samples tested for measles, rubella, chikungunya, and parvovirus were negative.\n\nIn order to identify the causative agent of this rash illness and to propose appropriate prevention and control measures, the SVS is conducting field investigations in collaboration with the Health Departments of Maranhao, Rio Grande do Norte, and Paraiba. In these investigations, they are including clinical aspects of patients and collecting samples, principally blood, which will be forwarded to the state and national reference laboratories.\n\nSimultaneously, all health surveillances states and Northeast municipalities continue investigating and monitoring cases. The SVS and the Health Departments of the states of Alagoas, Bahia, Ceara, Maranhao, Paraiba, Piaui, Rio Grande do Norte, and Sergipe are conducting systematic monitoring through the Strategic Information Centres of Health Surveillance (CIEVS).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Brazil can be seen at http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: (Rio de Janeiro) RFI\nData: Mon 13 Apr 2015\nSource: Globo [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://g1.globo.com/rj/sul-do-rio-costa-verde/noticia/2015/04/surto-de-alergia-atinge-moradores-de-pinheiral-rj-diz-vigilancia-de-saude.html\n\n\nAllergy outbreak reaches residents of Pinheiral, RJ [Rio de Janeiro], says Health Surveillance\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nPinheiral residents in southern Rio de Janeiro state are facing an allergy outbreak. For the past 30 days, hundreds were treated at municipal First Aid post with similar symptoms. \"An average 250 to 300 visits a day, most with joint pain, pain behind the eyes, fever, and itching, a rash on the body,\" explained Dr Erica Quintal Teixeira Fernandes [at present, dengue would be the most likely case. - Mod.RNA]\n\nIt happened with a merchant who 3 weeks ago began to feel discomfort [what type of discomfort? - Mod.RNA], followed by itching in the legs. Small bubbles and then spots began to appear [on his body], and the malaise worsened. After consulting the medical unit, he was treated for allergy and the itching decreased, but the marks on the body continued. Days later, his sons also went through the same problem. \"We had headache, dizziness, shortness of breath, and vomiting,\" they said.\n\nAccording to Health Surveillance, the prime suspect is that this is a new mutation of the dengue virus [based on what evidence? - Mod.RNA]. \"With the investigations which the surveillance performs in relation to the symptoms, we can guarantee that 70 percent of these cases are dengue [confirmed by laboratory testing? And the other 30 percent? - Mod.RNA],\" said Adriane Garcia da Rosa.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n<promed-port@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are, at the very least, worrying statements/speculations like \"a new mutation of the dengue virus,\" used to attribute to dengue events/cases that perhaps are not even being investigated and (laboratory confirmed or discounted) systematically.\n\nInvestigations conducted by the Departments of Health of the states and the Ministry of Health are essential for elucidating and understanding the outbreaks that have been described.\n\nUse of standardized case definitions and research lab protocols (sample collection and laboratory analysis) is mandatory, especially now that Zika virus has been announced as having been confirmed by a research laboratory (see below).\n\nQuestion: Would the Zika virus be the \"only\" agent to be implicated in the cases/outbreaks that have been reported in the Northeast? Would it be circulating in (and infecting) other states? Let's keep our eyes open. - Mod.RNA\n\nSince 8 Feb 2015 ProMED-PORT has posted reports in Portuguese of hundreds of cases of fever with rash and joint pains in several northeastern states of Brazil: Bahia, Maranhao, Paraiba, Pernambuco and Piaui (see map at\nhttp://viajerobrasil.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/mapa-brasil-2-839x735.jpg\n\nNow a Brazilian research group has reported identifying the cause as the mosquito-borne Zika virus:\nSource: Globo (in Portuguese)\nhttp://g1.globo.com/bahia/noticia/2015/04/identificado-virus-causador-de-doenca-misteriosa-em-salvador-e-rms.html.\n\nOther mosquito-borne viruses with similar symptoms such as dengue and chikungunya were excluded previously. They identified the virus by the PCR test, which detects signature portions of viral RNA. But Zika virus belongs to the group known as flaviviruses, which are notorious among virologists for their cross-reactions in lab tests. Until the actual virus is isolated, we cannot be certain it is not a totally new agent of the flavivirus group.\n\nZika seems unlikely, because it up to now it has only been detected in Africa, Asia, and the Pacific. One suggestion is that it was imported by a football fan incubating it who was visiting Brazil for the World Cup. But the cup final was in mid-July 2014 -- where could the virus have been hiding since then? Until its identity is confirmed, this is all speculation. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nDengue, chikungunya, Zika viruses - Pacific 20141016.2870853\nZika virus - Pacific (15): Easter Island ex Tahiti 20140925.2804821\nZika virus - New Zealand ex Cook Islands, comment 20140912.2769285\nZika virus - Japan ex Thailand (02): comment 20140826.2725061\nZika virus - Pacific (12): French Polynesia, donated blood 20140411.2397091\nZika virus - Pacific (10): Australia ex Cook Islands 20140403.2378034\nZika virus - Africa: Gabon 20140216.2280898\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): alert 20140210.2268533\n2013\n----\nZika virus - Germany ex Thailand 20131227.2139786\nZika virus - Japan: ex French Polynesia 20131219.2126046\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): ex French Polynesia 20131203.2089681\nZika virus - Canada ex Thailand 20130529.1744108\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................rna/jw/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "measles", "rubella", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-02-08 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bahia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "- Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alagoas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ceara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Grande", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maranhao", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3334549", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus - Pacific: Vanuatu", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3334549", "date": "2014-04-11 15:14:18", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - PACIFIC (12): FRENCH POLYNESIA, DONATED BLOOD\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Apr 2014\nSource: Eurosurveillance Volume 19, Issue 14 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20761\n\n\nMusso D, Nhan T, Robin E, Roche C, Bierlaire D, Zisou K, et al. Potential for Zika virus transmission through blood transfusion demonstrated during an outbreak in French Polynesia, November 2013 to February 2014.\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nSummary\n-------\nSince October 2013, French Polynesia has experienced the largest documented outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKAV) infection. To prevent transmission of ZIKAV by blood transfusion, specific nucleic acid testing of blood donors was implemented. From November 2013 to February 2014: 42 (3 per cent) of 1505 blood donors, although asymptomatic at the time of blood donation, were found positive for ZIKAV by PCR. Our results serve to alert blood safety authorities about the risk of post-transfusion Zika fever.\n\nZika virus infection in French Polynesia: implications for blood transfusion\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nFrench Polynesia, in the South Pacific, has experienced the largest reported outbreak of ZIKAV infection, which began in October 2013, with an estimated 28 000 cases in February 2014 (about 11 per cent of the population), concomitantly with the circulation of dengue virus (DENV) serotypes 1 and 3. To the best of our knowledge, the occurrence of ZIKAV infection resulting from transfusion of infected blood has not been investigated. Since other arboviruses have been reported to be transmitted by blood transfusion, several prevention procedures were implemented in date to prevent transfusion of ZIKAV through transmission in French Polynesia, including nucleic acid testing (NAT) of blood donors. We report here the detection of ZIKAV in 42 of 1505 blood donors, who were asymptomatic at the time of blood donation.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe main challenge in the prevention of arbovirus transfusion-derived transmission is the high rate of asymptomatic infections: this has been estimated at over 75 per cent for DENV and West Nile virus (WNV). For ZIKAV, there is no estimate available of the percentage of asymptomatic infections.\n\nArbovirus transfusion-derived transmission has been reported principally for WNV, DENV and chikungunya virus (CHIKV). For CHIKV, the risk was evaluated as high.\n\nDuring the outbreaks of CHIKV infection in Italy (2007) and in Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean (2005-2007), blood donation was discontinued and blood products were imported from blood bank centres elsewhere. In French Polynesia, due to its geographically isolated location, it was impossible to be supplied with fresh blood products from blood bank centres outside French Polynesia.\n\nDue to the potential risk of ZIKAV transfusion-derived transmission, the need to continue blood donations and the lack of a licensed test for ZIKAV diagnosis, we decided to implement ZIKAV NAT as soon as possible, using a modified RT-PCR. The protocol was implemented in November 2013, when agreement from the French Polynesian health authorities was obtained. The specificity of this RT-PCR assay has been previously evaluated and was confirmed by sequencing analysis conducted during the outbreak in French Polynesia and its sensitivity was similar to that previously evaluated.\n\nWe detected an unexpectedly high number of positive asymptomatic blood donors (42/1505; 3 per cent). To date, no post-transfusion ZIKAV infection has been reported in recipients of ZIKAV-positive blood in French Polynesia; however, haemovigilance studies are still ongoing.\n\nDue to concomitant circulation of DENV serotypes 1 and 3 since early 2013, multiplex NAT testing for DENV has been implemented from April 2013: no DENV-positive donor has yet been detected. While this might be related to a low level of viraemia in asymptomatic donors, we consider it was probably due to the low level of DENV-1 and DENV-3 circulation. Pathogen inactivation of platelet concentrates using a photochemical treatment (amotosalen) of blood products and ultraviolet A light inactivation was also implemented.\n\nThe management of a dual outbreak of ZIKAV and DENV infection was challenging because we had to test all blood donors for both pathogens, which was time consuming and expensive. In addition, in our blood bank centre, the mean delay between blood donation and production of fresh blood product available for transfusion is generally 24 hours. During the outbreaks, the mean delay was 3 days.\n\nThis report serves as a reminder of the importance of quickly adapting blood donation safety procedures to the local epidemiological context. Moreover, it should help in anticipating the needs in other parts of the Pacific region, such as in New Caledonia (South Pacific), where an outbreak of ZIKAV infection started in February 2014.\n\nOur findings suggest that ZIKAV NAT should be used to prevent blood transfusion-transmitted ZIKAV. As recommended by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, blood safety authorities need to be vigilant and should consider deferral of blood donors returning from areas with an outbreak of ZIKAV infection. In areas endemic for _Aedes_ species, a preparedness plan to respond to future outbreaks of ZIKAV infection should include emergency plans to sustain the blood supply.\n\n[The full report with references may be found at the URL above. - Mod.SH]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The response of the health authorities in French Polynesia in dealing with maintenance of a safe blood supply during a significant outbreak of a virus disease new to the area is outstanding. The logistical complications due to the geographic isolation of the islands were overcome with scientifically sound, innovative approaches for blood screening.\n\nMaps showing the location of the island archipelagos in French Polynesia mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/pf.htm and at http://healthmap.org/r/4tD1. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus - Pacific (11): French Polynesia, perinatal transmission 20140405.2383237\nZika virus - Pacific (09) 20140328.2365267\nZika virus - Pacific (08) 20140316.2335754\nZika virus - Pacific (07): Chile (Easter Island), French Polynesia 20140309.2322907\nZika virus - Pacific (06): French Polynesia, New Caledonia 20140303.2309965\nZika virus - Pacific (04): French Polynesia 20140123.2227452\nZika virus - Pacific (02): French Polynesia 20140110.2165365\nZika virus - Pacific: French Polynesia 20140108.2159822\n.................................................mpp/sh/ty/je/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "west nile virus", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2013-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "1505-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-10-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2013-04-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bierlaire D", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2870853", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Dengue, chikungunya, Zika viruses - Pacific (15): Chile (Easter Island) ex Tahiti", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2804821", "date": "2014-04-11 15:14:18", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - PACIFIC (12): FRENCH POLYNESIA, DONATED BLOOD\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Apr 2014\nSource: Eurosurveillance Volume 19, Issue 14 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20761\n\n\nMusso D, Nhan T, Robin E, Roche C, Bierlaire D, Zisou K, et al. Potential for Zika virus transmission through blood transfusion demonstrated during an outbreak in French Polynesia, November 2013 to February 2014.\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nSummary\n-------\nSince October 2013, French Polynesia has experienced the largest documented outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKAV) infection. To prevent transmission of ZIKAV by blood transfusion, specific nucleic acid testing of blood donors was implemented. From November 2013 to February 2014: 42 (3 per cent) of 1505 blood donors, although asymptomatic at the time of blood donation, were found positive for ZIKAV by PCR. Our results serve to alert blood safety authorities about the risk of post-transfusion Zika fever.\n\nZika virus infection in French Polynesia: implications for blood transfusion\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nFrench Polynesia, in the South Pacific, has experienced the largest reported outbreak of ZIKAV infection, which began in October 2013, with an estimated 28 000 cases in February 2014 (about 11 per cent of the population), concomitantly with the circulation of dengue virus (DENV) serotypes 1 and 3. To the best of our knowledge, the occurrence of ZIKAV infection resulting from transfusion of infected blood has not been investigated. Since other arboviruses have been reported to be transmitted by blood transfusion, several prevention procedures were implemented in date to prevent transfusion of ZIKAV through transmission in French Polynesia, including nucleic acid testing (NAT) of blood donors. We report here the detection of ZIKAV in 42 of 1505 blood donors, who were asymptomatic at the time of blood donation.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe main challenge in the prevention of arbovirus transfusion-derived transmission is the high rate of asymptomatic infections: this has been estimated at over 75 per cent for DENV and West Nile virus (WNV). For ZIKAV, there is no estimate available of the percentage of asymptomatic infections.\n\nArbovirus transfusion-derived transmission has been reported principally for WNV, DENV and chikungunya virus (CHIKV). For CHIKV, the risk was evaluated as high.\n\nDuring the outbreaks of CHIKV infection in Italy (2007) and in Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean (2005-2007), blood donation was discontinued and blood products were imported from blood bank centres elsewhere. In French Polynesia, due to its geographically isolated location, it was impossible to be supplied with fresh blood products from blood bank centres outside French Polynesia.\n\nDue to the potential risk of ZIKAV transfusion-derived transmission, the need to continue blood donations and the lack of a licensed test for ZIKAV diagnosis, we decided to implement ZIKAV NAT as soon as possible, using a modified RT-PCR. The protocol was implemented in November 2013, when agreement from the French Polynesian health authorities was obtained. The specificity of this RT-PCR assay has been previously evaluated and was confirmed by sequencing analysis conducted during the outbreak in French Polynesia and its sensitivity was similar to that previously evaluated.\n\nWe detected an unexpectedly high number of positive asymptomatic blood donors (42/1505; 3 per cent). To date, no post-transfusion ZIKAV infection has been reported in recipients of ZIKAV-positive blood in French Polynesia; however, haemovigilance studies are still ongoing.\n\nDue to concomitant circulation of DENV serotypes 1 and 3 since early 2013, multiplex NAT testing for DENV has been implemented from April 2013: no DENV-positive donor has yet been detected. While this might be related to a low level of viraemia in asymptomatic donors, we consider it was probably due to the low level of DENV-1 and DENV-3 circulation. Pathogen inactivation of platelet concentrates using a photochemical treatment (amotosalen) of blood products and ultraviolet A light inactivation was also implemented.\n\nThe management of a dual outbreak of ZIKAV and DENV infection was challenging because we had to test all blood donors for both pathogens, which was time consuming and expensive. In addition, in our blood bank centre, the mean delay between blood donation and production of fresh blood product available for transfusion is generally 24 hours. During the outbreaks, the mean delay was 3 days.\n\nThis report serves as a reminder of the importance of quickly adapting blood donation safety procedures to the local epidemiological context. Moreover, it should help in anticipating the needs in other parts of the Pacific region, such as in New Caledonia (South Pacific), where an outbreak of ZIKAV infection started in February 2014.\n\nOur findings suggest that ZIKAV NAT should be used to prevent blood transfusion-transmitted ZIKAV. As recommended by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, blood safety authorities need to be vigilant and should consider deferral of blood donors returning from areas with an outbreak of ZIKAV infection. In areas endemic for _Aedes_ species, a preparedness plan to respond to future outbreaks of ZIKAV infection should include emergency plans to sustain the blood supply.\n\n[The full report with references may be found at the URL above. - Mod.SH]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The response of the health authorities in French Polynesia in dealing with maintenance of a safe blood supply during a significant outbreak of a virus disease new to the area is outstanding. The logistical complications due to the geographic isolation of the islands were overcome with scientifically sound, innovative approaches for blood screening.\n\nMaps showing the location of the island archipelagos in French Polynesia mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/pf.htm and at http://healthmap.org/r/4tD1. - Pacific (02): French Polynesia 20140110.2165365\nZika virus - Pacific: French Polynesia 20140108.2159822\n.................................................mpp/sh/ty/je/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "west nile virus", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2013-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "1505-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-10-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2013-04-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bierlaire D", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2769285", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus - Pacific (14): New Zealand ex Cook Islands, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2769285", "date": "2014-04-11 15:14:18", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - PACIFIC (12): FRENCH POLYNESIA, DONATED BLOOD\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Apr 2014\nSource: Eurosurveillance Volume 19, Issue 14 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20761\n\n\nMusso D, Nhan T, Robin E, Roche C, Bierlaire D, Zisou K, et al. Potential for Zika virus transmission through blood transfusion demonstrated during an outbreak in French Polynesia, November 2013 to February 2014.\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nSummary\n-------\nSince October 2013, French Polynesia has experienced the largest documented outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKAV) infection. To prevent transmission of ZIKAV by blood transfusion, specific nucleic acid testing of blood donors was implemented. From November 2013 to February 2014: 42 (3 per cent) of 1505 blood donors, although asymptomatic at the time of blood donation, were found positive for ZIKAV by PCR. Our results serve to alert blood safety authorities about the risk of post-transfusion Zika fever.\n\nZika virus infection in French Polynesia: implications for blood transfusion\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nFrench Polynesia, in the South Pacific, has experienced the largest reported outbreak of ZIKAV infection, which began in October 2013, with an estimated 28 000 cases in February 2014 (about 11 per cent of the population), concomitantly with the circulation of dengue virus (DENV) serotypes 1 and 3. To the best of our knowledge, the occurrence of ZIKAV infection resulting from transfusion of infected blood has not been investigated. Since other arboviruses have been reported to be transmitted by blood transfusion, several prevention procedures were implemented in date to prevent transfusion of ZIKAV through transmission in French Polynesia, including nucleic acid testing (NAT) of blood donors. We report here the detection of ZIKAV in 42 of 1505 blood donors, who were asymptomatic at the time of blood donation.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe main challenge in the prevention of arbovirus transfusion-derived transmission is the high rate of asymptomatic infections: this has been estimated at over 75 per cent for DENV and West Nile virus (WNV). For ZIKAV, there is no estimate available of the percentage of asymptomatic infections.\n\nArbovirus transfusion-derived transmission has been reported principally for WNV, DENV and chikungunya virus (CHIKV). For CHIKV, the risk was evaluated as high.\n\nDuring the outbreaks of CHIKV infection in Italy (2007) and in Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean (2005-2007), blood donation was discontinued and blood products were imported from blood bank centres elsewhere. In French Polynesia, due to its geographically isolated location, it was impossible to be supplied with fresh blood products from blood bank centres outside French Polynesia.\n\nDue to the potential risk of ZIKAV transfusion-derived transmission, the need to continue blood donations and the lack of a licensed test for ZIKAV diagnosis, we decided to implement ZIKAV NAT as soon as possible, using a modified RT-PCR. The protocol was implemented in November 2013, when agreement from the French Polynesian health authorities was obtained. The specificity of this RT-PCR assay has been previously evaluated and was confirmed by sequencing analysis conducted during the outbreak in French Polynesia and its sensitivity was similar to that previously evaluated.\n\nWe detected an unexpectedly high number of positive asymptomatic blood donors (42/1505; 3 per cent). To date, no post-transfusion ZIKAV infection has been reported in recipients of ZIKAV-positive blood in French Polynesia; however, haemovigilance studies are still ongoing.\n\nDue to concomitant circulation of DENV serotypes 1 and 3 since early 2013, multiplex NAT testing for DENV has been implemented from April 2013: no DENV-positive donor has yet been detected. While this might be related to a low level of viraemia in asymptomatic donors, we consider it was probably due to the low level of DENV-1 and DENV-3 circulation. Pathogen inactivation of platelet concentrates using a photochemical treatment (amotosalen) of blood products and ultraviolet A light inactivation was also implemented.\n\nThe management of a dual outbreak of ZIKAV and DENV infection was challenging because we had to test all blood donors for both pathogens, which was time consuming and expensive. In addition, in our blood bank centre, the mean delay between blood donation and production of fresh blood product available for transfusion is generally 24 hours. During the outbreaks, the mean delay was 3 days.\n\nThis report serves as a reminder of the importance of quickly adapting blood donation safety procedures to the local epidemiological context. Moreover, it should help in anticipating the needs in other parts of the Pacific region, such as in New Caledonia (South Pacific), where an outbreak of ZIKAV infection started in February 2014.\n\nOur findings suggest that ZIKAV NAT should be used to prevent blood transfusion-transmitted ZIKAV. As recommended by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, blood safety authorities need to be vigilant and should consider deferral of blood donors returning from areas with an outbreak of ZIKAV infection. In areas endemic for _Aedes_ species, a preparedness plan to respond to future outbreaks of ZIKAV infection should include emergency plans to sustain the blood supply.\n\n[The full report with references may be found at the URL above. - Mod.SH]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The response of the health authorities in French Polynesia in dealing with maintenance of a safe blood supply during a significant outbreak of a virus disease new to the area is outstanding. In addition, in our blood bank centre, the mean delay between blood donation and production of fresh blood product available for transfusion is generally 24 hours. During the outbreaks, the mean delay was 3 days.\n\nThis report serves as a reminder of the importance of quickly adapting blood donation safety procedures to the local epidemiological context. Moreover, it should help in anticipating the needs in other parts of the Pacific region, such as in New Caledonia (South Pacific), where an outbreak of ZIKAV infection started in February 2014.\n\nOur findings suggest that ZIKAV NAT should be used to prevent blood transfusion-transmitted ZIKAV. As recommended by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, blood safety authorities need to be vigilant and should consider deferral of blood donors returning from areas with an outbreak of ZIKAV infection. In areas endemic for _Aedes_ species, a preparedness plan to respond to future outbreaks of ZIKAV infection should include emergency plans to sustain the blood supply.\n\n[The full report with references may be found at the URL above. - Mod.SH]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The response of the health authorities in French Polynesia in dealing with maintenance of a safe blood supply during a significant outbreak of a virus disease new to the area is outstanding. From November 2013 to February 2014: 42 (3 per cent) of 1505 blood donors, although asymptomatic at the time of blood donation, were found positive for ZIKAV by PCR. Our results serve to alert blood safety authorities about the risk of post-transfusion Zika fever.\n\nZika virus infection in French Polynesia: implications for blood transfusion\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nFrench Polynesia, in the South Pacific, has experienced the largest reported outbreak of ZIKAV infection, which began in October 2013, with an estimated 28 000 cases in February 2014 (about 11 per cent of the population), concomitantly with the circulation of dengue virus (DENV) serotypes 1 and 3. To the best of our knowledge, the occurrence of ZIKAV infection resulting from transfusion of infected blood has not been investigated. Since other arboviruses have been reported to be transmitted by blood transfusion, several prevention procedures were implemented in date to prevent transfusion of ZIKAV through transmission in French Polynesia, including nucleic acid testing (NAT) of blood donors. We report here the detection of ZIKAV in 42 of 1505 blood donors, who were asymptomatic at the time of blood donation.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe main challenge in the prevention of arbovirus transfusion-derived transmission is the high rate of asymptomatic infections: this has been estimated at over 75 per cent for DENV and West Nile virus (WNV). For ZIKAV, there is no estimate available of the percentage of asymptomatic infections.\n\nArbovirus transfusion-derived transmission has been reported principally for WNV, DENV and chikungunya virus (CHIKV). For CHIKV, the risk was evaluated as high.\n\nDuring the outbreaks of CHIKV infection in Italy (2007) and in Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean (2005-2007), blood donation was discontinued and blood products were imported from blood bank centres elsewhere. In French Polynesia, due to its geographically isolated location, it was impossible to be supplied with fresh blood products from blood bank centres outside French Polynesia.\n\nDue to the potential risk of ZIKAV transfusion-derived transmission, the need to continue blood donations and the lack of a licensed test for ZIKAV diagnosis, we decided to implement ZIKAV NAT as soon as possible, using a modified RT-PCR. The protocol was implemented in November 2013, when agreement from the French Polynesian health authorities was obtained. The specificity of this RT-PCR assay has been previously evaluated and was confirmed by sequencing analysis conducted during the outbreak in French Polynesia and its sensitivity was similar to that previously evaluated.\n\nWe detected an unexpectedly high number of positive asymptomatic blood donors (42/1505; 3 per cent). To date, no post-transfusion ZIKAV infection has been reported in recipients of ZIKAV-positive blood in French Polynesia; however, haemovigilance studies are still ongoing.\n\nDue to concomitant circulation of DENV serotypes 1 and 3 since early 2013, multiplex NAT testing for DENV has been implemented from April 2013: no DENV-positive donor has yet been detected. While this might be related to a low level of viraemia in asymptomatic donors, we consider it was probably due to the low level of DENV-1 and DENV-3 circulation. Pathogen inactivation of platelet concentrates using a photochemical treatment (amotosalen) of blood products and ultraviolet A light inactivation was also implemented.\n\nThe management of a dual outbreak of ZIKAV and DENV infection was challenging because we had to test all blood donors for both pathogens, which was time consuming and expensive. In addition, in our blood bank centre, the mean delay between blood donation and production of fresh blood product available for transfusion is generally 24 hours. During the outbreaks, the mean delay was 3 days.\n\nThis report serves as a reminder of the importance of quickly adapting blood donation safety procedures to the local epidemiological context. Moreover, it should help in anticipating the needs in other parts of the Pacific region, such as in New Caledonia (South Pacific), where an outbreak of ZIKAV infection started in February 2014.\n\nOur findings suggest that ZIKAV NAT should be used to prevent blood transfusion-transmitted ZIKAV. As recommended by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, blood safety authorities need to be vigilant and should consider deferral of blood donors returning from areas with an outbreak of ZIKAV infection. In areas endemic for _Aedes_ species, a preparedness plan to respond to future outbreaks of ZIKAV infection should include emergency plans to sustain the blood supply.\n\n[The full report with references may be found at the URL above. - Mod.SH]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The response of the health authorities in French Polynesia in dealing with maintenance of a safe blood supply during a significant outbreak of a virus disease new to the area is outstanding. The logistical complications due to the geographic isolation of the islands were overcome with scientifically sound, innovative approaches for blood screening.\n\nMaps showing the location of the island archipelagos in French Polynesia mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/pf.htm and at http://healthmap.org/r/4tD1. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus - Pacific (11): French Polynesia, perinatal transmission 20140405.2383237\nZika virus - Pacific (09) 20140328.2365267\nZika virus - Pacific (08) 20140316.2335754\nZika virus - Pacific (07): Chile (Easter Island), French Polynesia 20140309.2322907\nZika virus - Pacific (06): French Polynesia, New Caledonia 20140303.2309965\nZika virus - Pacific (04): French Polynesia 20140123.2227452\nZika virus - Pacific (02): French Polynesia 20140110.2165365\nZika virus - Pacific: French Polynesia 20140108.2159822\n.................................................mpp/sh/ty/je/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "west nile virus", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2013-10-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "1505-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-10-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-16 00:00:00", "2013-04-16 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bierlaire D", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2397091", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus - Pacific (12): French Polynesia, donated blood", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2397091", "date": "2014-04-11 15:14:18", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - PACIFIC (12): FRENCH POLYNESIA, DONATED BLOOD\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Apr 2014\nSource: Eurosurveillance Volume 19, Issue 14 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20761\n\n\nMusso D, Nhan T, Robin E, Roche C, Bierlaire D, Zisou K, et al. Potential for Zika virus transmission through blood transfusion demonstrated during an outbreak in French Polynesia, November 2013 to February 2014.\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nSummary\n-------\nSince October 2013, French Polynesia has experienced the largest documented outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKAV) infection. To prevent transmission of ZIKAV by blood transfusion, specific nucleic acid testing of blood donors was implemented. From November 2013 to February 2014: 42 (3 per cent) of 1505 blood donors, although asymptomatic at the time of blood donation, were found positive for ZIKAV by PCR. Our results serve to alert blood safety authorities about the risk of post-transfusion Zika fever.\n\nZika virus infection in French Polynesia: implications for blood transfusion\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nFrench Polynesia, in the South Pacific, has experienced the largest reported outbreak of ZIKAV infection, which began in October 2013, with an estimated 28 000 cases in February 2014 (about 11 per cent of the population), concomitantly with the circulation of dengue virus (DENV) serotypes 1 and 3. To the best of our knowledge, the occurrence of ZIKAV infection resulting from transfusion of infected blood has not been investigated. Since other arboviruses have been reported to be transmitted by blood transfusion, several prevention procedures were implemented in date to prevent transfusion of ZIKAV through transmission in French Polynesia, including nucleic acid testing (NAT) of blood donors. We report here the detection of ZIKAV in 42 of 1505 blood donors, who were asymptomatic at the time of blood donation.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe main challenge in the prevention of arbovirus transfusion-derived transmission is the high rate of asymptomatic infections: this has been estimated at over 75 per cent for DENV and West Nile virus (WNV). For ZIKAV, there is no estimate available of the percentage of asymptomatic infections.\n\nArbovirus transfusion-derived transmission has been reported principally for WNV, DENV and chikungunya virus (CHIKV). For CHIKV, the risk was evaluated as high.\n\nDuring the outbreaks of CHIKV infection in Italy (2007) and in Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean (2005-2007), blood donation was discontinued and blood products were imported from blood bank centres elsewhere. In French Polynesia, due to its geographically isolated location, it was impossible to be supplied with fresh blood products from blood bank centres outside French Polynesia.\n\nDue to the potential risk of ZIKAV transfusion-derived transmission, the need to continue blood donations and the lack of a licensed test for ZIKAV diagnosis, we decided to implement ZIKAV NAT as soon as possible, using a modified RT-PCR. The protocol was implemented in November 2013, when agreement from the French Polynesian health authorities was obtained. The specificity of this RT-PCR assay has been previously evaluated and was confirmed by sequencing analysis conducted during the outbreak in French Polynesia and its sensitivity was similar to that previously evaluated.\n\nWe detected an unexpectedly high number of positive asymptomatic blood donors (42/1505; 3 per cent). To date, no post-transfusion ZIKAV infection has been reported in recipients of ZIKAV-positive blood in French Polynesia; however, haemovigilance studies are still ongoing.\n\nDue to concomitant circulation of DENV serotypes 1 and 3 since early 2013, multiplex NAT testing for DENV has been implemented from April 2013: no DENV-positive donor has yet been detected. While this might be related to a low level of viraemia in asymptomatic donors, we consider it was probably due to the low level of DENV-1 and DENV-3 circulation. Pathogen inactivation of platelet concentrates using a photochemical treatment (amotosalen) of blood products and ultraviolet A light inactivation was also implemented.\n\nThe management of a dual outbreak of ZIKAV and DENV infection was challenging because we had to test all blood donors for both pathogens, which was time consuming and expensive. In addition, in our blood bank centre, the mean delay between blood donation and production of fresh blood product available for transfusion is generally 24 hours. During the outbreaks, the mean delay was 3 days.\n\nThis report serves as a reminder of the importance of quickly adapting blood donation safety procedures to the local epidemiological context. Moreover, it should help in anticipating the needs in other parts of the Pacific region, such as in New Caledonia (South Pacific), where an outbreak of ZIKAV infection started in February 2014.\n\nOur findings suggest that ZIKAV NAT should be used to prevent blood transfusion-transmitted ZIKAV. As recommended by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, blood safety authorities need to be vigilant and should consider deferral of blood donors returning from areas with an outbreak of ZIKAV infection. In areas endemic for _Aedes_ species, a preparedness plan to respond to future outbreaks of ZIKAV infection should include emergency plans to sustain the blood supply.\n\n[The full report with references may be found at the URL above. - Mod.SH]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The response of the health authorities in French Polynesia in dealing with maintenance of a safe blood supply during a significant outbreak of a virus disease new to the area is outstanding. Pacific (11): French Polynesia, perinatal transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2383237", "date": "2014-02-10 22:00:50", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - PACIFIC (05): NEW CALEDONIA, ALERT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 9 Feb 2014\nSource: Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/article/cdc-travelers-to-new-caledonia-warned-of-zika-fever-outbreak\n\n\nThe southwest Pacific islands of New Caledonia are reporting an outbreak of the mosquito borne viral disease Zika fever, prompting the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to issue a travel notice for the archipelago on 7 Feb 2014.\n\nHealth officials in New Caledonia report that as of Monday [3 Feb 2014], 49 cases have been laboratory confirmed. Of the 49 cases, 30 occurred in people with a travel history to French Polynesia, where an outbreak of Zika fever is ongoing.\n\nSome of the confirmed cases are considered autochthonous, i.e. indigenous or locally transmitted in the population.\n\nThere is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent Zika fever. Because of this, CDC recommends that travelers to New Caledonia protect themselves from mosquito bites. This includes covering exposed skin, using insect repellent that contains DEET, staying and sleeping in screened or air-conditioned rooms, and using a bed net if the area where you are sleeping is exposed to the outdoors.\n\nZika infection is a mild febrile viral illness transmitted by mosquitoes. A few outbreaks have been reported in tropical Africa and in some areas in Southeast Asia, according to the European Centre of Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC).\n\nZika virus is transmitted to humans mainly by certain species of _Aedes_ mosquitoes and is closely related to the dengue viruses.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak of Zika virus infections has been the source of cases with illnesses in 3 individuals on New Caledonia reported on 2 Dec 2013 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20131203.2089681) and with more imported cases since then. On 21 Jan 2014, the occurrence of the 1st indigenous infection with the Zika virus was confirmed by the Pasteur Institute. This is the 1st time a person has been infected with Zika virus on New Caledonian territory. The other 26 cases reported at that time had been imported from French Polynesia, where more than 35 000 cases have been detected. Now, the count of imported cases has increased to 30, with the remaining 19 cases locally acquired. That number is expected to climb in the coming days.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Caledonia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/4wEV.\nMaps showing the location of the island archipelagos in French Polynesia mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/pf.htm and at http://healthmap.org/r/4tD1. - That number is expected to climb in the coming days.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Caledonia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/4wEV.\nMaps showing the location of the island archipelagos in French Polynesia mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/pf.htm and at http://healthmap.org/r/4tD1. - Pacific: French Polynesia 20140108.2159822\n2013\n----\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): ex French Polynesia 20131203.2089681\n.................................................sb/jw/ty/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-02-03 00:00:00", "2013-12-02 00:00:00", "2014-01-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2322907", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus - Pacific (07): Chile (Easter Island), French Polynesia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2322907", "date": "2014-02-10 22:00:50", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - PACIFIC (05): NEW CALEDONIA, ALERT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 9 Feb 2014\nSource: Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/article/cdc-travelers-to-new-caledonia-warned-of-zika-fever-outbreak\n\n\nThe southwest Pacific islands of New Caledonia are reporting an outbreak of the mosquito borne viral disease Zika fever, prompting the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to issue a travel notice for the archipelago on 7 Feb 2014.\n\nHealth officials in New Caledonia report that as of Monday [3 Feb 2014], 49 cases have been laboratory confirmed. Of the 49 cases, 30 occurred in people with a travel history to French Polynesia, where an outbreak of Zika fever is ongoing.\n\nSome of the confirmed cases are considered autochthonous, i.e. indigenous or locally transmitted in the population.\n\nThere is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent Zika fever. Because of this, CDC recommends that travelers to New Caledonia protect themselves from mosquito bites. This includes covering exposed skin, using insect repellent that contains DEET, staying and sleeping in screened or air-conditioned rooms, and using a bed net if the area where you are sleeping is exposed to the outdoors.\n\nZika infection is a mild febrile viral illness transmitted by mosquitoes. A few outbreaks have been reported in tropical Africa and in some areas in Southeast Asia, according to the European Centre of Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC).\n\nZika virus is transmitted to humans mainly by certain species of _Aedes_ mosquitoes and is closely related to the dengue viruses.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak of Zika virus infections has been the source of cases with illnesses in 3 individuals on New Caledonia reported on 2 Dec 2013 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20131203.2089681) and with more imported cases since then. On 21 Jan 2014, the occurrence of the 1st indigenous infection with the Zika virus was confirmed by the Pasteur Institute. This is the 1st time a person has been infected with Zika virus on New Caledonian territory. The other 26 cases reported at that time had been imported from French Polynesia, where more than 35 000 cases have been detected. Now, the count of imported cases has increased to 30, with the remaining 19 cases locally acquired. That number is expected to climb in the coming days.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Caledonia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/4wEV.\nMaps showing the location of the island archipelagos in French Polynesia mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/pf.htm and at http://healthmap.org/r/4tD1. - Of the 49 cases, 30 occurred in people with a travel history to French Polynesia, where an outbreak of Zika fever is ongoing.\n\nSome of the confirmed cases are considered autochthonous, i.e. indigenous or locally transmitted in the population.\n\nThere is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent Zika fever. This includes covering exposed skin, using insect repellent that contains DEET, staying and sleeping in screened or air-conditioned rooms, and using a bed net if the area where you are sleeping is exposed to the outdoors.\n\nZika infection is a mild febrile viral illness transmitted by mosquitoes. A few outbreaks have been reported in tropical Africa and in some areas in Southeast Asia, according to the European Centre of Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC).\n\nZika virus is transmitted to humans mainly by certain species of _Aedes_ mosquitoes and is closely related to the dengue viruses.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak of Zika virus infections has been the source of cases with illnesses in 3 individuals on New Caledonia reported on 2 Dec 2013 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20131203.2089681) and with more imported cases since then. On 21 Jan 2014, the occurrence of the 1st indigenous infection with the Zika virus was confirmed by the Pasteur Institute. This is the 1st time a person has been infected with Zika virus on New Caledonian territory. The other 26 cases reported at that time had been imported from French Polynesia, where more than 35 000 cases have been detected. Pacific (05): New Caledonia, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2268533", "date": "2014-02-10 22:00:50", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - PACIFIC (05): NEW CALEDONIA, ALERT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 9 Feb 2014\nSource: Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/article/cdc-travelers-to-new-caledonia-warned-of-zika-fever-outbreak\n\n\nThe southwest Pacific islands of New Caledonia are reporting an outbreak of the mosquito borne viral disease Zika fever, prompting the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to issue a travel notice for the archipelago on 7 Feb 2014.\n\nHealth officials in New Caledonia report that as of Monday [3 Feb 2014], 49 cases have been laboratory confirmed. Of the 49 cases, 30 occurred in people with a travel history to French Polynesia, where an outbreak of Zika fever is ongoing.\n\nSome of the confirmed cases are considered autochthonous, i.e. indigenous or locally transmitted in the population.\n\nThere is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent Zika fever. Because of this, CDC recommends that travelers to New Caledonia protect themselves from mosquito bites. This includes covering exposed skin, using insect repellent that contains DEET, staying and sleeping in screened or air-conditioned rooms, and using a bed net if the area where you are sleeping is exposed to the outdoors.\n\nZika infection is a mild febrile viral illness transmitted by mosquitoes. A few outbreaks have been reported in tropical Africa and in some areas in Southeast Asia, according to the European Centre of Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC).\n\nZika virus is transmitted to humans mainly by certain species of _Aedes_ mosquitoes and is closely related to the dengue viruses.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak of Zika virus infections has been the source of cases with illnesses in 3 individuals on New Caledonia reported on 2 Dec 2013 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20131203.2089681) and with more imported cases since then. On 21 Jan 2014, the occurrence of the 1st indigenous infection with the Zika virus was confirmed by the Pasteur Institute. This is the 1st time a person has been infected with Zika virus on New Caledonian territory. The other 26 cases reported at that time had been imported from French Polynesia, where more than 35 000 cases have been detected. Now, the count of imported cases has increased to 30, with the remaining 19 cases locally acquired. That number is expected to climb in the coming days.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Caledonia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/4wEV.\nMaps showing the location of the island archipelagos in French Polynesia mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/pf.htm and at http://healthmap.org/r/4tD1. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus - Pacific (04): French Polynesia 20140123.2227452\nZika virus - Pacific (03): New Caledonia 20140122.2224823\nZika virus - Pacific (02): French Polynesia 20140110.2165365\nZika virus - Pacific: French Polynesia 20140108.2159822\n2013\n----\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): ex French Polynesia 20131203.2089681\n.................................................sb/jw/ty/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2014-02-03 00:00:00", "2013-12-02 00:00:00", "2014-01-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2227452", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus - Pacific (04): French Polynesia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2227452", "date": "2013-12-03 12:23:48", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - NEW CALEDONIA (02) ex FRENCH POLYNESIA\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Dec 2013\nFrom: Sylvie Laumond <alerte.dass@gouv.nc> [edited]\n\n\nFollowing a confirmed outbreak in French Polynesia: 3 cases of Zika fever have been reported in New Caledonia. All cases were imported from French Polynesia.\n\nSymptoms of Zika fever include high temperature, headache, red eyes, skin rash, muscle aches, and joint pains.\n\nThe mosquito [capable of] carrying the virus in New Caledonia is _Aedes aegypti_ that can bite during the day but not night, both inside and out, and lives around buildings in urban areas.\n\nTravellers coming from French Polynesia when arriving in New Caledonia are being advised to use insect repellants, during 7 days after landing, and wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants, and to consult a general practitioner if symptoms are occurring. Sleeping in screened rooms or under bed nets is recommended only for young children and sick people.\n\nIf these individuals were viremic on arrival, there is a significant risk of ongoing transmission of Zika virus in New Caledonia.\n\n--\nDr Sylvie Laumond\nEpidemiologist, Sanitary Action Department\nNew Caledonia Health and Social Affairs Department\n<alerte.dass@gouv.nc>\n\n[The number of reported Zika virus infection cases imported into New Caledonia has increased from 2 to 3. The islands in French Polynesia affected by the Zika virus outbreak this year (2013) are: Tahiti, Moorea, Raiatea, Tahaa, Bora Bora, Nuku Hiva, and Arutua. There was a major outbreak of Zika virus infections on Yap and nearby islands of the Federated Republic of Micronesia in 2007. The vector mosquito of this flavivirus virus is _Aedes aegypti_.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Sylvie Laumond for sending in this new report, along with the URL for the Government of New Caledonia's Department of Health and Social Affairs brief report of these cases (in French) (http://www.dass.gouv.nc/portal/page/portal/dass/alertes). ProMED would welcome any additional reports of new imported Zika virus infections or locally acquired ones.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Caledonia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/4wEV. A map of Micronesia showing the location of Yap can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/islands_oceans_poles/micronesia_pol99.jpg and maps showing the location of the island archipelagos in French Polynesia mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/pf.htm and at http://healthmap.org/r/4tD1. - Pacific (02): French Polynesia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2165365", "date": "2013-12-03 12:23:48", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - NEW CALEDONIA (02) ex FRENCH POLYNESIA\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Dec 2013\nFrom: Sylvie Laumond <alerte.dass@gouv.nc> [edited]\n\n\nFollowing a confirmed outbreak in French Polynesia: 3 cases of Zika fever have been reported in New Caledonia. All cases were imported from French Polynesia.\n\nSymptoms of Zika fever include high temperature, headache, red eyes, skin rash, muscle aches, and joint pains.\n\nThe mosquito [capable of] carrying the virus in New Caledonia is _Aedes aegypti_ that can bite during the day but not night, both inside and out, and lives around buildings in urban areas.\n\nTravellers coming from French Polynesia when arriving in New Caledonia are being advised to use insect repellants, during 7 days after landing, and wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants, and to consult a general practitioner if symptoms are occurring. Sleeping in screened rooms or under bed nets is recommended only for young children and sick people.\n\nIf these individuals were viremic on arrival, there is a significant risk of ongoing transmission of Zika virus in New Caledonia.\n\n--\nDr Sylvie Laumond\nEpidemiologist, Sanitary Action Department\nNew Caledonia Health and Social Affairs Department\n<alerte.dass@gouv.nc>\n\n[The number of reported Zika virus infection cases imported into New Caledonia has increased from 2 to 3. The islands in French Polynesia affected by the Zika virus outbreak this year (2013) are: Tahiti, Moorea, Raiatea, Tahaa, Bora Bora, Nuku Hiva, and Arutua. There was a major outbreak of Zika virus infections on Yap and nearby islands of the Federated Republic of Micronesia in 2007. The vector mosquito of this flavivirus virus is _Aedes aegypti_.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Sylvie Laumond for sending in this new report, along with the URL for the Government of New Caledonia's Department of Health and Social Affairs brief report of these cases (in French) (http://www.dass.gouv.nc/portal/page/portal/dass/alertes). ProMED would welcome any additional reports of new imported Zika virus infections or locally acquired ones.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Caledonia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/4wEV. A map of Micronesia showing the location of Yap can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/islands_oceans_poles/micronesia_pol99.jpg and maps showing the location of the island archipelagos in French Polynesia mentioned above can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/pf.htm and at http://healthmap.org/r/4tD1. - All cases were imported from French Polynesia.\n\nSymptoms of Zika fever include high temperature, headache, red eyes, skin rash, muscle aches, and joint pains.\n\nThe mosquito [capable of] carrying the virus in New Caledonia is _Aedes aegypti_ that can bite during the day but not night, both inside and out, and lives around buildings in urban areas.\n\nTravellers coming from French Polynesia when arriving in New Caledonia are being advised to use insect repellants, during 7 days after landing, and wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants, and to consult a general practitioner if symptoms are occurring. Sleeping in screened rooms or under bed nets is recommended only for young children and sick people.\n\nIf these individuals were viremic on arrival, there is a significant risk of ongoing transmission of Zika virus in New Caledonia.\n\n--\nDr Sylvie Laumond\nEpidemiologist, Sanitary Action Department\nNew Caledonia Health and Social Affairs Department\n<alerte.dass@gouv.nc>\n\n[The number of reported Zika virus infection cases imported into New Caledonia has increased from 2 to 3. The islands in French Polynesia affected by the Zika virus outbreak this year (2013) are: Tahiti, Moorea, Raiatea, Tahaa, Bora Bora, Nuku Hiva, and Arutua. There was a major outbreak of Zika virus infections on Yap and nearby islands of the Federated Republic of Micronesia in 2007. The vector mosquito of this flavivirus virus is _Aedes aegypti_.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Sylvie Laumond for sending in this new report, along with the URL for the Government of New Caledonia's Department of Health and Social Affairs brief report of these cases (in French) (http://www.dass.gouv.nc/portal/page/portal/dass/alertes). There was a major outbreak of Zika virus infections on Yap and nearby islands of the Federated Republic of Micronesia in 2007. The vector mosquito of this flavivirus virus is _Aedes aegypti_.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Sylvie Laumond for sending in this new report, along with the URL for the Government of New Caledonia's Department of Health and Social Affairs brief report of these cases (in French) (http://www.dass.gouv.nc/portal/page/portal/dass/alertes). New Caledonia: ex French Polynesia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2082225", "date": "2007-07-03 15:00:03", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - MICRONESIA: GUAM ex YAP, SUSPECTED\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 29 Jun 2007\nSource: KUAM News [edited]\n<http://www.kuam.com/news/23289.aspx>\n\nThere have now been 2 probable cases of the Zika virus reported in\nGuam. The probable cases are not laboratory confirmed, but do meet\nthe current case definition. According to the Guam Department of\nPublic Health, the 2 probable cases are from adults who had recently\ntraveled to Yap. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the\nWorld Health Organization (WHO), and Yap Health Department scientists\ncontinue to investigate the Zika outbreak in Yap State. A total of 86\nconfirmed and probable cases have been recorded as of Tuesday [26 Jun\n2007].\nBecause this is a relatively unknown disease, they are now collecting\ndata to better define the course of illness and how it is\ntransmitted. Since there is no vaccination or specific medical\ntreatment for Zika virus infection, Guam Public Health advises the\npublic to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes that transmit the disease.\nGuam residents are especially urged to remove old tires, cans,\nbottles, coconut shells, and other items in which mosquitoes may\nbreed from around their homes.\nThe symptoms of the Zika virus are mild and generally last for 2-4\ndays, consisting of a rash that starts on the face that may spread to\nthe rest of the body, conjunctivitis (pink eye), and joint pain\nmostly affecting the smaller joints of the hands and feet.\n[Byline: Sabrina Salas Matanane]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAlice E. Hadley, AHIP\nU.S. Naval Hospital, Guam\nMedical Library\n<alice.hadley@med.navy.mil>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Alice Hadley for sending in this report. The\ntravel of 2 individuals possibly infected with Zika virus is another\nillustration of the ease with which pathogens can be disseminated. If\nthese individuals were viremic on arrival in Guam, and competent\nvector mosquitoes were present and abundant, the risk of spread of\nZika virus could be relatively high. Transport of infected mosquitoes\nin commercial aircraft is another potential mechanism for\ndissemination of Zika and other arboviruses (see references below).\nReferences:\n1. Tatem AJ, Hay SI, Rogers DJ. 2006: Global traffic and disease\nvector dispersal. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 18, 103 (16): 6242-7.\n2. Eritja R, da Cunha Ramos H, Aranda C. 2000: Aircraft-mediated\nmosquito transport: new direct evidence. J Am Mosq Control Assoc.:\n16: 339.\n3. Service MW. 1997: Mosquito (Diptera: Culicidae) dispersal -- the\nlong and short of it. J Med Entomol. 34: 579-88.\n4. Goh KT, Ng SK, Kumarapathy S. 1985: Disease-bearing insects\nbrought in by international aircraft into Singapore. Southeast Asian\nJ Trop Med Public Health. 16: 49-53.\nA map of Micronesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/islands_oceans_poles/micronesia_pol99.jpg>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus outbreak - Micronesia (Yap) (02): confirmed 20070702.2108\nZika virus outbreak - Micronesia (Yap): susp, RFI 20070627.2065\n....................................lm/ty/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The probable cases are not laboratory confirmed, but do meet\nthe current case definition. According to the Guam Department of\nPublic Health, the 2 probable cases are from adults who had recently\ntraveled to Yap. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the\nWorld Health Organization (WHO), and Yap Health Department scientists\ncontinue to investigate the Zika outbreak in Yap State. A total of 86\nconfirmed and probable cases have been recorded as of Tuesday [26 Jun\n2007].\nBecause this is a relatively unknown disease, they are now collecting\ndata to better define the course of illness and how it is\ntransmitted. Since there is no vaccination or specific medical\ntreatment for Zika virus infection, Guam Public Health advises the\npublic to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes that transmit the disease.\nGuam residents are especially urged to remove old tires, cans,\nbottles, coconut shells, and other items in which mosquitoes may\nbreed from around their homes.\nThe symptoms of the Zika virus are mild and generally last for 2-4\ndays, consisting of a rash that starts on the face that may spread to\nthe rest of the body, conjunctivitis (pink eye), and joint pain\nmostly affecting the smaller joints of the hands and feet.\n[Byline: Sabrina Salas Matanane]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAlice E. Hadley, AHIP\nU.S. Naval Hospital, Guam\nMedical Library\n<alice.hadley@med.navy.mil>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Alice Hadley for sending in this report. The\ntravel of 2 individuals possibly infected with Zika virus is another\nillustration of the ease with which pathogens can be disseminated. If\nthese individuals were viremic on arrival in Guam, and competent\nvector mosquitoes were present and abundant, the risk of spread of\nZika virus could be relatively high. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "6242-07-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Singapore", "country": "Singapore"}, {"location": "Guam", "country": "Guam"}, {"location": "Yap State", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "16416", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Zika virus - Micronesia: Yap (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=16416", "date": "2007-07-03 15:00:03", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS - MICRONESIA: GUAM ex YAP, SUSPECTED\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 29 Jun 2007\nSource: KUAM News [edited]\n<http://www.kuam.com/news/23289.aspx>\n\nThere have now been 2 probable cases of the Zika virus reported in\nGuam. The probable cases are not laboratory confirmed, but do meet\nthe current case definition. According to the Guam Department of\nPublic Health, the 2 probable cases are from adults who had recently\ntraveled to Yap. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the\nWorld Health Organization (WHO), and Yap Health Department scientists\ncontinue to investigate the Zika outbreak in Yap State. A total of 86\nconfirmed and probable cases have been recorded as of Tuesday [26 Jun\n2007].\nBecause this is a relatively unknown disease, they are now collecting\ndata to better define the course of illness and how it is\ntransmitted. Since there is no vaccination or specific medical\ntreatment for Zika virus infection, Guam Public Health advises the\npublic to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes that transmit the disease.\nGuam residents are especially urged to remove old tires, cans,\nbottles, coconut shells, and other items in which mosquitoes may\nbreed from around their homes.\nThe symptoms of the Zika virus are mild and generally last for 2-4\ndays, consisting of a rash that starts on the face that may spread to\nthe rest of the body, conjunctivitis (pink eye), and joint pain\nmostly affecting the smaller joints of the hands and feet.\n[Byline: Sabrina Salas Matanane]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAlice E. Hadley, AHIP\nU.S. Naval Hospital, Guam\nMedical Library\n<alice.hadley@med.navy.mil>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Alice Hadley for sending in this report. The\ntravel of 2 individuals possibly infected with Zika virus is another\nillustration of the ease with which pathogens can be disseminated. If\nthese individuals were viremic on arrival in Guam, and competent\nvector mosquitoes were present and abundant, the risk of spread of\nZika virus could be relatively high. Transport of infected mosquitoes\nin commercial aircraft is another potential mechanism for\ndissemination of Zika and other arboviruses (see references below).\nReferences:\n1. Tatem AJ, Hay SI, Rogers DJ. 2006: Global traffic and disease\nvector dispersal. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 18, 103 (16): 6242-7.\n2. Eritja R, da Cunha Ramos H, Aranda C. 2000: Aircraft-mediated\nmosquito transport: new direct evidence. J Am Mosq Control Assoc.:\n16: 339.\n3. Service MW. 1997: Mosquito (Diptera: Culicidae) dispersal -- the\nlong and short of it. J Med Entomol. 34: 579-88.\n4. Goh KT, Ng SK, Kumarapathy S. 1985: Disease-bearing insects\nbrought in by international aircraft into Singapore. Southeast Asian\nJ Trop Med Public Health. 16: 49-53.\nA map of Micronesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/islands_oceans_poles/micronesia_pol99.jpg>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus outbreak - Micronesia (Yap) (02): confirmed 20070702.2108\nZika virus outbreak - Micronesia (Yap): susp, RFI 20070627.2065\n....................................lm/ty/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
