The probable cases are not laboratory confirmed, but do meet\nthe current case definition. According to the Guam Department of\nPublic Health, the 2 probable cases are from adults who had recently\ntraveled to Yap. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the\nWorld Health Organization (WHO), and Yap Health Department scientists\ncontinue to investigate the Zika outbreak in Yap State. A total of 86\nconfirmed and probable cases have been recorded as of Tuesday [26 Jun\n2007].\nBecause this is a relatively unknown disease, they are now collecting\ndata to better define the course of illness and how it is\ntransmitted. Since there is no vaccination or specific medical\ntreatment for Zika virus infection, Guam Public Health advises the\npublic to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes that transmit the disease.\nGuam residents are especially urged to remove old tires, cans,\nbottles, coconut shells, and other items in which mosquitoes may\nbreed from around their homes.\nThe symptoms of the Zika virus are mild and generally last for 2-4\ndays, consisting of a rash that starts on the face that may spread to\nthe rest of the body, conjunctivitis (pink eye), and joint pain\nmostly affecting the smaller joints of the hands and feet.\n[Byline: Sabrina Salas Matanane]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAlice E. Hadley, AHIP\nU.S. Naval Hospital, Guam\nMedical Library\n<alice.hadley@med.navy.mil>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Alice Hadley for sending in this report. The\ntravel of 2 individuals possibly infected with Zika virus is another\nillustration of the ease with which pathogens can be disseminated. If\nthese individuals were viremic on arrival in Guam, and competent\nvector mosquitoes were present and abundant, the risk of spread of\nZika virus could be relatively high. Transport of infected mosquitoes\nin commercial aircraft is another potential mechanism for\ndissemination of Zika and other arboviruses (see references below).\nReferences:\n1. Tatem AJ, Hay SI, Rogers DJ. 2006: Global traffic and disease\nvector dispersal. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 18, 103 (16): 6242-7.\n2. Eritja R, da Cunha Ramos H, Aranda C. 2000: Aircraft-mediated\nmosquito transport: new direct evidence. J Am Mosq Control Assoc.:\n16: 339.\n3. Service MW. 1997: Mosquito (Diptera: Culicidae) dispersal -- the\nlong and short of it. J Med Entomol. 34: 579-88.\n4. Goh KT, Ng SK, Kumarapathy S. 1985: Disease-bearing insects\nbrought in by international aircraft into Singapore. Southeast Asian\nJ Trop Med Public Health. 16: 49-53.\nA map of Micronesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/islands_oceans_poles/micronesia_pol99.jpg>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nZika virus outbreak - Micronesia (Yap) (02): confirmed 20070702.2108\nZika virus outbreak - Micronesia (Yap): susp, RFI 20070627.2065\n....................................lm/ty/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "6242-07-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Singapore", "country": "Singapore"}, {"location": "Guam", "country": "Guam"}, {"location": "Yap State", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "15686", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Zika virus outbreak - Micronesia (Yap) (02): confirmed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=15686", "date": "2007-06-27 04:00:02", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS OUTBREAK - MICRONESIA (YAP): SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 24 Jun 2007\nSource: Guam Pacific Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.guampdn.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070624/NEWS01/706240308/1002>\n\nZika virus outbreak hits Yap\n----------------------------\nA mosquitoborne virus, which was 1st isolated in Africa and is similar to\ndengue, has found its way to Micronesia.\n\"An outbreak of illness on the island of Yap in the Federated States of\nMicronesia (FSM) caused by the Zika virus has been confirmed,\" according to\na World Health Organization statement made on behalf of Dr Marcus Samo of\nthe FSM national government and Dr Martin Bel of Yap State.\nThere have been no cases reported on Guam, said Dr Robert Haddock, the\nterritorial epidemiologist with the Guam Department of Public Health and\nSocial Services. But public health officials are urging Guam residents to\ntake necessary steps to avoid mosquito bites.\nSymptoms of Zika fever include a skin rash that starts on the face and then\nspreads throughout the body, conjuctivitis, more commonly known as pink\neye; and pain in the smaller joints of the hands and feet, according to WHO\nofficials.\nAs of Friday [22 Jun 2007], 73 patients who were processed by the\noutpatient department at Yap's public hospital exhibited at least 2 of the\n3 symptoms of Zika fever.\nControl measures similar to those for dengue are already being taken in\nYap. Officials said quarantine measures are not necessary since this is a\n[relatively] milder form of dengue [-like disease. - Mod.TY].\nZika, named after the forest in Uganda where the virus was 1st isolated, is\na flavivirus similar to the dengue virus. Zika causes similar but milder\nsymptoms, according to WHO's Office for the South Pacific. While commonly\nfound in Africa, the Zika virus has also been found in Malaysia.\nThe outbreak in Yap reportedly started in April [2007] and peaked in late\nMay. Zika fever symptoms are mild, according to WHO, and generally last for\n2 to 4 days. \"Some (Yap) patients also have low grade fever,\" according to\nthe WHO statement. \"No patients had to be admitted to the hospital and\nthere have been no deaths. Because the disease is mild, many more\ninfections are thought to have occurred in the community that did not seek\nmedical attention. An initial assessment in the community indicates that a\nsignificant proportion of the population has been affected. Geographically,\ncases have occurred all over the island.\"\nPublic health officials said a joint investigation is being carried out by\nthe public health authorities of Yap State and the FSM national government,\nthe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and WHO.\n\"The investigation is continuing to better characterize the clinical\npresentation of the illness, the magnitude of the outbreak and the mode of\ntransmission in order to determine the best control measures,\" the WHO\nstatement said. \"We continue to see new cases, and the neighboring islands\nare under active surveillance.\"\nOn Guam, Haddock said while there have been no cases of dengue or Zika\nfever on island, \"it would be prudent for Guam residents to avoid mosquito\nbites as much as possible._Aedes_ mosquitoes, the mosquito group likely to\nspread viral diseases in our region, are usually most active in the early\nmorning and late afternoon hours but they may be encountered any time\nduring the day in shady areas or if they can gain access to homes,\" he said.\nGuam public health officials advise residents to use mosquito netting over\nbeds. \"Use mosquito repellents and wear appropriate clothing such as\nlong-sleeved shirts and long pants that reduce exposure to mosquito bites\nwhen venturing outdoors, especially during the late afternoon or early\nmorning hours,\" they said.\nMosquitoes breed in containers -- such as discarded tin cans, coconut\nhalf-shells and old tires -- so residents should keep their homes free from\nsuch litter. \"Saucers under potted plants are another area where these\nmosquitoes may breed so water should not be allowed to accumulate there for\nmore than a few days,\" Guam health officials said.\n[byline: David V Crisostomo]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Zika virus has been isolated from humans, non-human primates in Africa,\nand mosquitoes (_Aedes aegypti_, and _Ae. africanus_). Epidemics in Africa\nhave been documented in Uganda and Nigeria and in South East Asia in\nMalaysia and Indonesia. There is some serological evidence of Zika virus\ninfections in humans and in nonhuman primates in other countries, but\nresults from flavivirus serological tests need to be interpreted with some\ncaution due to cross-reactions among this virus family. It would be of\ninterest to know which _Aedes_ spp vectors are involved in Zika virus\ntransmission in Yap, and what the results of the clinical studies are when\nthey become available.\nReferences:\n1. McCrae A, Kira B. Zika virus epizootics and enzootics in Uganda. - Trans\nRoy Soc Trop Med Hyg 1982; 76: 552-62.\n2. Olson J, et al. Zika virus, a cause of fever in Central Java, Indonesia.\n- Trans Roy Soc Trop Med Hyg 1981; 75: 389-93.\n3. Fagbami A. Zika virus infections in Nigeria: virological and\nseroepidemiological investigations. - J Hyg (London) 1979; 83: 213-19.\n4. Marchette N, et al. Isolation of Zika virus from _Aedes aegypti_\nmosquitoes in Malayasia. - Am J Trop Med Hyg 1964; 18: 411-5.\n5. Haddow J, et al. Twelve Isolations of Zika virus from _Aedes (Stegomyia)\nafricanus (Theobald) taken in and above a Uganda forest. - Bull World\nHealth Organ 1964; 31: 57-69.\nA map of Micronesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/islands_oceans_poles/micronesia_pol99.jpg>.\n- Mod.TY]\n...............mpp/jw/ty/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00", "1979-03-16 00:00:00", "1964-03-16 00:00:00", "1964-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Central Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Yap State", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Malayasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "the Federated States", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Guam", "country": "Guam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "14974", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Zika virus outbreak - Micronesia (Yap): susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=14974", "date": "2007-06-27 04:00:02", "main_text": "ZIKA VIRUS OUTBREAK - MICRONESIA (YAP): SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 24 Jun 2007\nSource: Guam Pacific Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.guampdn.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070624/NEWS01/706240308/1002>\n\nZika virus outbreak hits Yap\n----------------------------\nA mosquitoborne virus, which was 1st isolated in Africa and is similar to\ndengue, has found its way to Micronesia.\n\"An outbreak of illness on the island of Yap in the Federated States of\nMicronesia (FSM) caused by the Zika virus has been confirmed,\" according to\na World Health Organization statement made on behalf of Dr Marcus Samo of\nthe FSM national government and Dr Martin Bel of Yap State.\nThere have been no cases reported on Guam, said Dr Robert Haddock, the\nterritorial epidemiologist with the Guam Department of Public Health and\nSocial Services. But public health officials are urging Guam residents to\ntake necessary steps to avoid mosquito bites.\nSymptoms of Zika fever include a skin rash that starts on the face and then\nspreads throughout the body, conjuctivitis, more commonly known as pink\neye; and pain in the smaller joints of the hands and feet, according to WHO\nofficials.\nAs of Friday [22 Jun 2007], 73 patients who were processed by the\noutpatient department at Yap's public hospital exhibited at least 2 of the\n3 symptoms of Zika fever.\nControl measures similar to those for dengue are already being taken in\nYap. Officials said quarantine measures are not necessary since this is a\n[relatively] milder form of dengue [-like disease. - Mod.TY].\nZika, named after the forest in Uganda where the virus was 1st isolated, is\na flavivirus similar to the dengue virus. Zika causes similar but milder\nsymptoms, according to WHO's Office for the South Pacific. While commonly\nfound in Africa, the Zika virus has also been found in Malaysia.\nThe outbreak in Yap reportedly started in April [2007] and peaked in late\nMay. Zika fever symptoms are mild, according to WHO, and generally last for\n2 to 4 days. \"Some (Yap) patients also have low grade fever,\" according to\nthe WHO statement. \"No patients had to be admitted to the hospital and\nthere have been no deaths. Because the disease is mild, many more\ninfections are thought to have occurred in the community that did not seek\nmedical attention. An initial assessment in the community indicates that a\nsignificant proportion of the population has been affected. Geographically,\ncases have occurred all over the island.\"\nPublic health officials said a joint investigation is being carried out by\nthe public health authorities of Yap State and the FSM national government,\nthe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and WHO.\n\"The investigation is continuing to better characterize the clinical\npresentation of the illness, the magnitude of the outbreak and the mode of\ntransmission in order to determine the best control measures,\" the WHO\nstatement said. \"We continue to see new cases, and the neighboring islands\nare under active surveillance.\"\nOn Guam, Haddock said while there have been no cases of dengue or Zika\nfever on island, \"it would be prudent for Guam residents to avoid mosquito\nbites as much as possible._Aedes_ mosquitoes, the mosquito group likely to\nspread viral diseases in our region, are usually most active in the early\nmorning and late afternoon hours but they may be encountered any time\nduring the day in shady areas or if they can gain access to homes,\" he said.\nGuam public health officials advise residents to use mosquito netting over\nbeds. \"Use mosquito repellents and wear appropriate clothing such as\nlong-sleeved shirts and long pants that reduce exposure to mosquito bites\nwhen venturing outdoors, especially during the late afternoon or early\nmorning hours,\" they said.\nMosquitoes breed in containers -- such as discarded tin cans, coconut\nhalf-shells and old tires -- so residents should keep their homes free from\nsuch litter. \"Saucers under potted plants are another area where these\nmosquitoes may breed so water should not be allowed to accumulate there for\nmore than a few days,\" Guam health officials said.\n[byline: David V Crisostomo]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Zika virus has been isolated from humans, non-human primates in Africa,\nand mosquitoes (_Aedes aegypti_, and _Ae. africanus_). Epidemics in Africa\nhave been documented in Uganda and Nigeria and in South East Asia in\nMalaysia and Indonesia. There is some serological evidence of Zika virus\ninfections in humans and in nonhuman primates in other countries, but\nresults from flavivirus serological tests need to be interpreted with some\ncaution due to cross-reactions among this virus family. It would be of\ninterest to know which _Aedes_ spp vectors are involved in Zika virus\ntransmission in Yap, and what the results of the clinical studies are when\nthey become available.\nReferences:\n1. McCrae A, Kira B. Zika virus epizootics and enzootics in Uganda. - Trans\nRoy Soc Trop Med Hyg 1982; 76: 552-62.\n2. Olson J, et al. Zika virus, a cause of fever in Central Java, Indonesia.\n- Trans Roy Soc Trop Med Hyg 1981; 75: 389-93.\n3. Fagbami A. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00", "1979-03-16 00:00:00", "1964-03-16 00:00:00", "1964-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Central Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Yap State", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Malayasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "the Federated States", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Guam", "country": "Guam"}]}]}]}
